PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Herron will be absent from question time today as a result of personal matters. During his absence, Senator Newman will take questions relating to health and I will take questions relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I propose to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a new list of shadow ministry representation and parliamentary secretaries for the opposition in both chambers following the reshuffle that was announced by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, earlier today.

SPEECH.PARA: I would particularly like to draw the Senate's attention to the resignation of Senator Bob Collins from the shadow frontbench. Obviously, we will greatly miss his outstanding contribution. I would also like to draw to the Senate's attention the appointment of Senator Kate Lundy and Senator Sue Mackay to the frontbench. Senator Lundy has been appointed parliamentary secretary to the shadow minister for sport and tourism, and assistant to the shadow ministers for science and information technology, youth affairs and the arts. Senator Mackay has been appointed as parliamentary secretary to the shadow ministers for employment and training and industrial relations. I seek leave to incorporate the new list in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, did you receive from DEETYA advice about the data you used to make comparisons between public and private schools on the basis of employment outcomes? If so, what was the nature of the advice? Were your comments that public school leavers are 10 times more likely to be unemployed than their private school counterparts based, as your spokesperson indicated, on ABS data? Is it correct, Minister, that this ABS data was unpublished and, if so, what cautions were associated with its use?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of other senators, Senator Faulkner is referring to a speech made some weeks ago to the American Chamber of Commerce outlining, as I indicated yesterday, a very broad picture for the need for schools to respond to the needs of their students. In that speech, ABS figures were used in relation to the destination of school leavers, indicating that X per cent of year 12 school leavers—I think it was in 1995—from government schools would go in one direction and another percentage in another direction, with a similar sort of arrangement for the non‐government schools.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole point of the speech was to indicate that schools have to respond to the changing labour market—something I indicat‐

BREAK.PARA: ed yesterday. I think I pointed out yesterday that over about a decade—and it is a bit more than a decade—the size of the youth employment labour force has reduced dramatically—by about a half, I would think—indicating that if you leave school leavers to go straight from school into that market, they are going into a market with an ever reducing number of jobs.

Subsequent to that speech, I have received some advice from my department in relation to figures for school leavers, but I do not have it in front of me. I will have a look at it; I will come back and I will give Senator Faulkner as much information as I can in relation to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I asked Senator Vanstone—and I ask again—whether the ABS data was unpublished data and, if so, what cautions were associated with its use. Given that you have now indicated to the Senate that you have received advice from your department, I ask you: did that advice draw any conclusions? If not, Minister, did you interpret the data yourself or was some other advice sought?

—I repeat to you what I told you in the first place: I do not have the advice in front of me. I will have a look at it and I will come back to you with such information as is appropriate from that advice. It is as simple as that.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Minister, the coalition government has found that the taxation system is in urgent need of reform and is inappropriate to Australia's needs as we move towards the 20th century. What are the criteria that the government's taxation task force is using to ensure that Australia has a fairer and more modern tax system which provides incentives to work and save, and which will promote jobs, exports and investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important question. Yes, this government is a government of reform and leadership. We tackled first the fiscal mess that we inherited—$10.3 billion of deficit and we will turn that into a surplus within three years. We tackled interest rates which burdened so many within the Australian economy, particularly small business, and have achieved five reductions in the first 15 months of government. We tackled industrial relations with the most significant reforms for decades in the Workplace Relations Act and achieved goals that will benefit both employers and employees.

ANSWER.PARA: We are now tackling tax reform—that area that all have agreed for so long is in need of reform but governments have not had the courage to tackle. This government has the courage. What has happened is that the Prime Minister has instructed the taxation task force to prepare options in accordance with key criteria. The criteria—and it is important to emphasis this to the Australian public—include the following: the overall tax burden must not be increased. Contrast that with Gareth Evans, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party. He wants to put back death duties. He wants to see state income taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Yes, he does, Senator Cook. He told the states, `Increase your payroll taxes. That is the answer to your problems.' That shows how interested he is in employment, I would suggest. Anyway, under the coalition the overall tax burden must not be increased.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, personal income tax has to be reduced and families have to receive special attention. That is not surprising because it was this government that produced the family tax package and delivered it in full and on time. So our second criteria is that personal income tax be reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about jobs? How many jobs?
—When we talk about tax reform, we talk about reductions in taxation.
—What about the superannuation tax?
—Order! Senator Hill—
—That is something we never heard from the Labor Party. The Labor Party—the higher tax alternative.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill, I am not surprised you cannot hear me because of the level of noise on my left. A reasonable interjection from time to time is not something anyone would rule out of order but the sort of shouting that is going on today makes it impossible for me to hear Senator Hill or for him to hear me.

—The third criteria is that consideration be given to a broad based indirect tax to replace some or all of the existing indirect taxes. How could you look at broad based tax reform without looking at that issue? Of course you cannot. Labor Party advisers are telling them that you cannot. Labor Party spokesmen say that they would have introduced a GST if they had won the last election. Anyway, we have the courage to look at the broad based indirect alternatives because it is in the national interest to do so.

BREAK.PARA: Fourthly, compensation must be made available to those deserving special consideration—low income earners, for example. It is important that their interests are taken into account. Fifthly, it is seen as an opportunity to reform Commonwealth‐state financial relations—something that has been called for for years. But under Labor did it occur? No. Did Labor face up to that challenge? No.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Kennett call Costello?
—Senator Sherry, if you are going to shriek, at least use the proper terminology for members of the other place.

—It is not surprising that they are embarrassed by this because in all their years in government they were not prepared to face up to this key area of economic reform. They never had the courage to take the hard decisions in this area. The last criteria—this is very important; this is one of the most important criteria—is restoring fairness in the taxation system. They are the criteria within which the government is tackling this important reform package. Just contrast that with Labor—(Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of members of the Malaysian branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association led by the Minister for Science, Technology and Environment, the Hon. Dato Abu Bakar Bin Daud. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit here will be both informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Why has the government changed the definition of an employment placement for the purposes of paying a success fee for new private employment agencies from 20 hours a week to 15 hours a week? Does the government believe 15 hours a week is a real job? Isn't it true, as was pointed out in the Sydney Morning Herald on 8 August, that you have had to lower the hurdle to a pathetic level in order to try to make your scheme a success?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator Childs, that is simply not correct, as you know from the announcement in the budget last year about the radical reforms we were to make to employment services. We have indicated that from that time on we would be consulting with the relevant stakeholders—that means obviously those within the department with experience in these matters, through the CES and the very broad network we have there. As you know, we have established a public employment placement enterprise that will, in a sense, be the old CES newly corporatised but with private providers and community providers as well.

ANSWER.PARA: Against that you will understand, Senator, that the Bureau of Statistics monthly unemployment figures consider that you are employed if you have one hour a week or more in work.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about—

—Senator, I am coming to your answer. I actually think you are quite interested in it. For the purposes of the Bureau of Statistics that is an internation ally recognised standard measurement of whether you are employed or not. Obviously that would not be a satisfactory measure to use in terms of paying outcome fees.
—You are dropping the current measure.
—Madam President, I am trying to answer this question but if you allow the cacklers over there to keep at it, it does make it a little more difficult for Senator Childs to get his answer.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have done through the consultations is ascertain, as best we think is possible, what would the levels of hours worked per week be that would take you either off benefit or substantially off benefit. In other words, the purpose of the employment services reforms is to make you independent, to give you sufficient work that you could at least say, `I am now responsible for myself,' and no longer be dependent. The calculation is that about that level of hours a week is when you will be in that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is this the way your government proposes to solve the unemployment crisis, by redefining what it means to be employed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you were poorly advised to take that question from whomever you did. I have already indicated to you that the ABS—
—You haven't answered it yet.

—The question is answered, Senator, so let me repeat it for you. It is a little bit difficult with whom you are sitting behind, Senator, to look past that face that is snarling at me, but nonetheless. The Bureau of Statistics definitions of employment and unemployment are not being touched by this government in any way whatsoever. They remain exactly the same as they were when you were in government. So let us get rid of that little red herring that someone might be asking you to toss in in ignorance. We are not changing the definitions of employment or unemployment in any way whatsoever.

ANSWER.PARA: All we are doing is ascertaining the point at which we will say to an employment place ment enterprise, `Yes, we believe you've got this person a job' and we believe that it is at the point at which someone will be 70 per cent or more off benefit. That is, they will more likely than not be independent. That is all the calculation is for, nothing more than that. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Senator Alston. Minister, before the 1983 election, the then opposition leader, Mr Bob Hawke, said:

QUESTION.PARA: I promise you that only a Labor Government can be trusted to build the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line.

Minister, now 14 years later, it has taken a federal coalition government to progress an agreement with the Northern Territory and South Australian governments to pledge $300 million to develop this important rail link. Minister, what is the significance of the rail link to the nation as a whole? How many jobs will be created during the construction and operation period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, it has taken 14 years to get there and it is only a coalition government that can deliver the goods. The fact is that many people have talked about this project, many people have seen the potential for it, but it has only been the coalition government that has been prepared to grasp the nettle. What we would expect is that it will provide a brand new pathway for freight to travel through a new Asian gateway and create enormous opportunities to open up the bulk of the country in a way that has not happened before.

ANSWER.PARA: If you look at what the Wran report had to say back in 1995 you will see that it predicted that the railway would become economic early next century. It clearly does involve a significant level of private sector involvement. We have made it very clear that the private sector must build, own and operate this line. The predictions are that during the construction phase there will be in the order of 2,000 jobs and during the operation stage there will be at least 200 jobs, a very significant contri bution to employment but, much more importantly, a very major contribution to the opening up of the centre of Australia and to making sure that the southern states have access to the north in a way that they have not had before.

What is particularly significant about this commitment is that Labor pretends that somehow it is on the bandwagon, that somehow it would like to go out there and say that it would have done even more. As Senator Ferguson quite rightly pointed out, you have to go back to 1983 to come across the original weasel words. I suspect what Hawke was doing at the time was having a bit of a dry run for the l-a-w, law, tax cuts repeal because, having given that solemn promise, what did he do? Within a matter of weeks, he reneged. They said it was not on and they would not proceed with the rail link.

There was an outcry and the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, committed the government to spending $5 million on design work. They completed that, and by 28 March 1984 you had the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, describing the railway as totally unrealistic and uneconomic. That is basically where it has been ever since as far as Labor is concerned. We then had Senator Walsh getting up in here and calling it another bout of cargo cultism and saying that it was a waste of $160 million worth of taxpayers' money on a white elephant—all those sorts of expressions that made it absolutely clear that they had no intention of going down this path.

In fact, Senator Bob Collins on several occasions made it abundantly clear that he had the same approach as the opposition—unless and until the private sector committed, they were not interested. That is why it is the absolute height of hypocrisy to find that Senator Collins—and I see he is back in the Territory campaigning, presumably using federal taxpayers' funds, in a Territory election—has finally thrown in the towel. And we know why he threw in the towel—because Kim Beazley, in his usual burst of leadership, removed one of his additional staffers from him and he said he just was not prepared to hack it any longer.

BREAK.PARA: What that shows up is the absolute barrenness of the Labor Party frontbench which cannot even find anyone to replace a person of the calibre of Senator Collins. Here you have Senator Collins saying, `The Hawke government offered a 60:40 deal with the Northern Territory government and that figure would mean $600 million in today's dollars.'

It is absolutely extraordinary that this outfit thinks that they can persuade people that something they could not get around to doing for 14 years, something that was not only too hard but something that they bagged on a regular basis, is now not only their policy but something on which they would have spent hundreds of millions of dollars more than we are committing to this project. It is totally unbelievable. You cannot regard this as a substitute for leadership. In no shape or form is that going to delude anyone into thinking that you have anything other than contempt for the voters' credibility. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, is it a fact that the tender documents for the government's plan to outsource CES duties state that DEETYA `will not pay the provider for any FLEX 1 outcomes that exceed the contracted number'? Isn't it a fact that this means that job placement firms replacing the CES will not be paid for exceeding levels specified in their job contracts?

—Senator, as I recall, this is a question canvassed by you quite fully at estimates. I do not know whether you are asking it again because you do not remember the answer or whether you have just collectively got nothing more important to ask about than things that are already on the record. I am tempted, Senator, simply to refer you to the Senate estimates Hansard record.
—Tell us again if you have told us before.

—Senator Crowley, you do tempt me. Madam President, Senator Crowley is really seeking that I waste the time of the Senate. The estimates committees are held outside of Senate sitting time; they are held outside of Senate sitting time for the express purpose of stopping things being hashed and hashed and hashed through estimates and then rehashed through here. Senator, I refer you to the Senate estimates Hansard where you will see that the representation you have put is incorrect. You are either being misleading or you were not listening at the time. It is one or the other.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that we were given the great grace of the details of this program the Friday before the estimates program began and we were not given adequate time to look at this in order to ask questions on estimates. Nevertheless, I think we did a reasonable job. But I am seeking clarification of the implications of the terms of the contract. Can you confirm my understanding of the situation, which is that unemployed people will be turned away from any private job placement firms that have spent the funds allocated to them?

—On the basis of the answer given to you at the estimates committee, I assert that that is an incorrect assertion for you to be putting, and I refer you to the Hansard . As I recall, you were present at the time.

—My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, can you confirm that Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary‐General, recently sent a communication to Prime Minister Howard expressing the view that Australia must stay in the climate change convention and cooperate with the rest of the world in curbing greenhouse gas emissions? Can you also confirm that this communication was sent on or about 6 August?
—No, Senator, you are apparently in error.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I did give you some notice of this question. Indeed, I would not have asked it unless we were very certain that this communique had occurred. I will move on and ask a related question. Have you or any other minister received advice from any government department on the implications of Australia pulling out of the climate change convention? If so, what was that advice, and can you please table it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been helpful if you had given me notice of the supplementary as well and then I could have done some research on that. Our interest is to stay in the negotiations to contribute to a good Kyoto outcome. By that I mean a good outcome in terms of the global environment and one that is not unfair as it relates to Australia. They are the dual objectives that we have been seeking throughout this process.

ANSWER.PARA: I know the issues of jobs, employment growth, economic growth and the benefits that can flow from that may not be of great importance to the Australian Democrats, but they are issues of importance to the Australian government. We will continue to work for the dual objectives of a good global greenhouse outcome and the preservation of Australia's employment base.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Minister, why has the government increased the working holiday maker program by 10 per cent to 55,000 places when youth unemployment is running at 27.8 per cent? How is this going to help young unemployed Australians?
—Senator Collins, I do not have in my brief an indication of—
—You are the minister. You are supposed to know. Don't you know?
—Order! Senator Cook!

—Thank you very much, Madam President. In the brief provided by the immigration minister, I do not have an indication of a change there, but I do recall a change being made last year. I do not know if that is the change you are referring to. There might have been a subsequent one but, if there was, I have not been advised of it, to the best of my knowledge anyway.

BREAK.PARA: Senator, it is a traditional problem for what you would call seasonal picking work. There is enormous difficulty in getting the appropriate labour force. For a variety of reasons, that is not always attractive to people who are looking for work. If you are a young unemployed teenager in Melbourne, it might be of assistance for you to get some short‐term work picking grapes in Victoria somewhere for a limited period of time, but perhaps you are more likely to be looking for a more permanent arrangement. So there are circumstances under which this sort of seasonal work is not as attractive.

But, without doubt, it is a problem for those industries that require this seasonal work to fill that employment need. It is always a difficulty for them. We have had to make some special arrangements vis-a-vis the new employment services market because of that specific difficulty. It is because of the difficulty in filling that need, of people choosing to look for other work, shall I put it, rather than taking that work, that in the past those visa entitlements have been increased. At the same time, we are always looking for our young Australians to be able to go overseas and get visas for short-term work—not a situation that we can readily encourage and enhance if the reciprocal opportunity is not made available.

Having said that I do not have a brief on it, I will raise this matter with the immigration minister. If there is any more information he wishes to raise with you, I will come back to you. If, as a consequence of the information given to me, there is anything further I should add to it, I will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you know whether the working holiday maker program involves predominantly seasonal jobs, as your answer has perhaps suggested? Could you please on notice provide an answer to the question asked and also comment on how this change, this increase of 10 per cent in our climate of youth unemployment, relates to the election pledge that reducing youth unemployment would be Mr Howard's highest priority?

—I do not know when you people are going to get too embarrassed to ask about employment issues. You had 13 years to fix the problem, and look at your appalling record. You had an average unemployment rate of 8.5 per cent. Under which party did youth unemployment go to its highest record ever? Under that party—the Labor Party, the guilty party. So I will have a good look at it, Senator, and I will come back to you if there is anything I want to add.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. In respect of the announcement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on 1 July concerning new tax incentives for Landcare, is it the case that these incentives will be paid for from the Natural Heritage Trust, rather than from general revenue? How much are these incentives expected to cost per annum? What will occur after the majority of the money in the Natural Heritage Trust is depleted? Are any of these incentives effective replacements of existing incentives, and does this mean that the money now coming from general revenue as revenue forgone will have to be paid for from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister representing the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, I can remind the honourable senator that, in the sustainable agricultural election policy statement, the government proposed to give farmers a choice between claiming accelerated depreciation for Landcare works under sections 75B and 75D of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and claiming a tax rebate credit set at a rate of 34c in the dollar.

ANSWER.PARA: On 1 July 1997, the minister announced that the new Landcare tax measure of 34c in the dollar was available for expenditures that qualified for the existing Landcare tax deductions and that were incurred from 1 July. Specific details of eligibility were to be announced in the future.

BREAK.PARA: The government is committed to the sustainable development of our primary industries and to providing for a productive base on which to develop that industry, including by arresting land degradation. While there is widespread appreciation of the need for improved resource management, economic factors limit the ability of farmers to address this issue, and this is putting Landcare at risk.

Yes, Landcare is an important part of the Natural Heritage Trust and a part of the trust that is administered by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. We trust that these changes—and the specific details of eligibility are still to be announced—will lead to better Landcare outcomes, and that should be applauded.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister did not answer the part of the question in relation to what happens when this trust fund runs out and you have a tax deduction. By way of a supplementary question, I ask him to answer that question which he has not answered, as well as to answer this next question. Does the existing tax deduction come from a departmental budget? Specifically, does the existing Landcare deduction come from the environment budget? If not, why is this so-called environment fund, which you touted as being a big plus for the environment, suddenly providing money for tax deductions which would normally come from general revenue?

—Senator Margetts refuses to acknowledge that the Natural Heritage Trust has an objective of sustainable agriculture. It is to produce a better biodiversity outcome consistent with improved sustainable agriculture. There has been no secret about that. Landcare funding, as I recall it, is made up in part from recurrent expenditure and in part from the capital funding to be provided under the Natural Heritage Trust.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, was Dr Kemp officially advised by ANTA recently `that the number of government funded VET clients would have to grow by between 30,226 and 84,992 in 1998' in order to satisfy the requirements of the government's new apprenticeship scheme, an increase in young people enrolling in TAFE as a consequence of changes in youth income support policy, and the normal growth patterns in the sector from population growth? Was Dr Kemp also advised that states could not be expected to fund this rate of growth by efficiency gains alone? Why has the government simply refused to acknowledge this reality?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr, you have my commiserations on not having been promoted to the frontbench.
—He's on the frontbench.

—I mean promoted. I do not know whether your side does it by merit or by vote, and I am not really interested in how the Labor Party works. But Senator Carr might have been hoping for a promotion and, out of the goodness of my heart, I am expressing my sympathy to him for not having received that promotion.

ANSWER.PARA: Getting to Senator Carr's question, he asked me whether Dr Kemp—the junior minister in my portfolio—received some quite specific advice from ANTA, the Australian National Training Authority. The issue he seeks information about is whether advice has been received, as I understand it, with respect to the sorts of efficiencies that could be sought and whether those efficiencies would be sufficient to meet the government's aspirations. I do not see every piece of advice that Dr Kemp gets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!
—No, I do not. Nor do I want to see every piece of advice Dr Kemp gets. I will tell you what I will do, Senator Carr. I will ask Dr Kemp the question and I will get him to reply on notice to you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, isn't it true that Dr Kemp has been advised by your department that the potential efficiency gains that could be achieved at the minimum level consistent with government policy would require savings by the states in the order of $144.5 million for New South Wales, $49 million for South Australia and $34 million for Western Australia? Does the government believe that such savings are achievable, or do you accept the advice given that gains of this order would be problematic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr, I indicated to you yesterday that the government would be particularly interested in the opposition's view on whether the vocational training system was operating at 100 per cent efficiency or not—in other words, do you believe there are efficiencies there that can be applied to new places or do you not? That is probably the first point we need to get to so that members of the public understand who thinks what.

ANSWER.PARA: We have made our position abundantly clear. We believe there are efficiencies there. What you are asking me is whether Dr Kemp has had a specific piece of advice from the department in relation to that. I will take your supplementary question—which in fact was not a supplementary question; it was just an additional question—on notice and get Dr Kemp to reply to you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Since the coalition was elected to government, important initiatives have been introduced to assist small business—such as the historic reforms to industrial relations laws, a reduction in the provisional uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent, capital gains tax rollover relief and the introduction of the small business innovation fund.

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —None of these measures was ever introduced by Senator Schacht, I might add. Will the minister outline what other benefits, particularly in the area of taxation, the government is providing to small business, the hub of job creation in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Crane, for a most important and perceptive question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt in the mind of the government that small business is the heart of job creation in this country—
—Order! There are far too many persistent interjections on my left.
—Indeed, the contempt that the Labor Party felt for small business was shown in the fact that Senator Schacht was given carriage of this important area.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party record in relation to small business saw higher taxes, industrial relations laws which caused huge problems to small business and, of course, record interest rates. Our policies across the board are designed to help small business grow, invest and create jobs. Whether the issue is interest rates, industrial relations or tax reform, we are the party of small business; we are the government of small business.

The government has a very fine record in relation to small business, and many key measures are already in law to help small business. In the area of taxation, for example, we have cut the provisional uplift factor and made sure it is kept at a reasonable level, unlike Labor who, year after year, kept the uplift factor unreasonably high, damaging small business cash flows.

We have eased the FBT record‐keeping burdens on small business, something which the Labor Party never did. We have taken a number of other measures in relation to FBT to ease the burden on small business. We have also allowed small business to remit tax withholding payments quarterly rather than monthly—something else that the Labor Party never did.

We committed ourselves in the election to help small business by providing CGT rollover relief when small business owners sold their business to buy another and where owners used the proceeds of their business for retirement. From the feedback that I have received, these measures have been particularly welcome.

The reality is that, given its 13‐year record, the Labor Party is anti small business. They saddled small business with high interest rates, some reaching up to 20 per cent. They saddled small business with crippling unfair dismissal laws; they saddled them with mountains of red tape.

In the behaviour of the Senate in recent days it can be seen that the Labor Party continues to pursue anti small business policies and continues to attempt to prevent the government putting into effect its election promises to small business, as we saw last night in relation to the CGT rollover relief. We are the party of small business and, after 13 years, there is no doubt that the Labor Party continues with a record of being the most damaging to small business, and they have not changed their ways in recent months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you also inform the Senate of the very positive reaction we have had from small business, particularly after the disastrous 13 years of Labor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the appalling record of Labor in this area, I think there was a collective sigh of relief throughout the small business community when this government came in with very positive policies to help small business.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the areas which small business particularly welcomed was the low interest rate policy of this government, in contrast to the party of high interest rates, the Australian Labor Party, which raised interest rates time and time again, regardless of the cost to small business.

Small business has also welcomed the tax changes that we have made in relation to things like fringe benefits to ease the burden of record keeping. This party has a very proud record in relation to small business—in absolute, stark contrast to the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It seems to me, Senator Crane, that that question ought to have been directed to Senator Alston, who has responsibility for small business, and not Senator Kemp.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, was the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, advised by his department in a briefing paper prepared on July 1 1997 that: Australia's participation rate in vocational education programs was substantially below international benchmarks; that for 18- to 24‐year‐olds Australia would need to increase its efforts by between 27 and 86 per cent to reach international best practice; and that a national growth target of 2½ per cent in government funded clients would not address underlying demand for new apprenticeships and for TAFE places arising from youth income support changes or international benchmarks?

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, you attended the Minco meeting: did you receive a copy of this briefing paper? Did you read this briefing paper, and will you now acknowledge that your government's decision to withdraw funding for growth in TAFE was a mistake?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop, I do not accept the assertions you put at the end of your question, and the government does not accept them. We believe that there are efficiencies in the vocational training system that can be found. We wait to hear from you and your government whether you agree that efficiencies can be found.

ANSWER.PARA: You asked me whether Dr Kemp received a paper on 1 July this year. My memory is pretty good but it does not go back to 1 July this year, and it certainly does not ever try to accommodate a list of every brief that Dr Kemp has ever had. You asked me if I was at the most recent ANTA Minco meeting. Yes, I was. Did I see a lot of papers in relation to that? Yes, I did. As to the specific paper that you mention, I will have a look. I will come back to you if I have got anything to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, when you look at the briefing paper can you advise whether, in regard to vocational education and training, an expansion of participation should not be as high a priority as an increase in conversion of participation rates into qualification attainment? Doesn't this advice support industry concerns that the Commonwealth government's underfunded new apprenticeship scheme does not adequately address the issue of the quality of training provided?

—Senator, I have indicated to you that I will have a look. If you have more things, as you have indicated in your supplementary question, that you want me to check for you, I will come back and give a response to the assertions that you make. The typical form of you people when asking a question is to make an assertion. I will have a look at it. I will come back to you if I think there is anything I want to add.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Prime Minister. I ask: has the minister seen reports of allegations made on the Sunday program on 24 August that Mr Rupert Murdoch played a significant role in the Prime Minister's decision to withdraw Commonwealth support for the ACT government heroin trial? Is it the case that Mr Murdoch warned the Prime Minister that, if the heroin trial gained government support, the Prime Minister would be attacked in Mr Murdoch's media? Finally, as the Prime Minister's office called the Sunday program to deny that John Howard or Rupert Murdoch discussed the heroin trial at their Kirribilli House meeting, at which meeting did they discuss the matter?

—He played no role. I was going to say to you that I understand there was no discussion at Kirribilli House. He told that to the party room this morning, so I will accept that. I know of no other discussion between the Prime Minister and Mr Murdoch of recent times. I regard the suggestion as scurrilous.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that reassurance. Can he further assure the Senate that the Prime Minister's drug task force will take into account the views of the combined health and police ministers, the AMA, Professor Pennington and the New South Wales Police Commissioner, even though they believed that the heroin trial should go ahead, or will they be taking all their advice, as Chief Minister Kate Carnell has suggested, from people who agree with the Prime Minister, such as some of the more colourful talk‐back radio commentators?

—As has been said, the task force will look at current efforts to reduce the supply of illicit drugs, including domestic law enforcement and border control. Current efforts to reduce the demand for such drugs include community education, community organisation support programs and harm minimisation approaches for users. I am sure the task force will take advice from all those who can better inform it in its task. We regard this matter as a critical concern for the Australian community and we want to be sure we get the best response possible.

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is it correct that the government's recently announced review of Abstudy is to be budget neutral? Is it also correct, as your department has stated, that Abstudy is a demand driven program operating under special appropriations, which means that if there is an increased demand for Abstudy it will be met? Further, if recommendations from the Abstudy review are to be budget neutral, doesn't this mean that either the program will be capped or, if places are increased, they will be underfunded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Denman, for that question. There is a review of Abstudy which is about to be undertaken, which has been announced for some time. It is not a review that is seeking savings, which might be what you are wanting to get to. The details of the review were announced on 5 August. It is going to look at whether Abstudy in its current form is appropriate. You might be aware that in respect of the common youth allowance which has put together so many payments relating to youth Abstudy has, at least for the time being, been excluded because it is recognised that it is a separate payment with a separate need.

ANSWER.PARA: The review is going ahead. There will be consultations with indigenous people, community organisations and educational institutions. In particular, an indigenous consultant will be engaged to assist with the review. The review was confirmed in this year's budget. As I say, the announcement of the details was made on 5 August. We want to see how the features of Abstudy, which we believe are critical to improving outcomes for indigenous students, can be provided in the most cost‐effective way.

A discussion paper is to be circulated. I am not aware whether that has happened yet. I imagine it has not, but it should not be too far down the track. The indigenous consultant that I have already mentioned to you will, no doubt, be using the discussion paper as a basis for some of those consultations.

A steering committee has been established to guide the conduct of the review. It includes representatives of the Office of Indigenous Affairs, the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency and the Department of Social Security, as well as relevant officers from DEETYA.

As to the other aspects of your question, I will check my view of those. I will take that detailed aspect on notice and come back to you. I do not think there is any more information here that is worth adding in relation to your question, other than perhaps to say that this government, along with the previous government, is very committed to increasing educational outcomes for indigenous students.

You will understand that last year, in a very difficult budgetary climate, more money—additional money—was provided for indigenous education and some moneys were protected from savings. That package of moneys falls into two blocks. There is the IESIP funding, which is per capita funding from preschool to vocational training level. Some very particular outcomes are being achieved there in terms of the level of traineeships.

The other portion of the increased and secured moneys relates to an increase in funding for the higher education sector for indigenous students. I mention that at the end because I want it to be abundantly clear that the review process of Abstudy is not a savings measure. It has not got a brief to find savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you tell me what the rationale was for announcing the review of Abstudy after, rather than before, making a series of mean‐spirited funding cuts in the 1997‐98 budget?

—It had been indicated for some time that we would proceed with such a review. Nonetheless, there were some changes that it seemed apparent at the time could be made. In a package of savings that, as I recall—I will come back and give you the detail of these figures—is about $10 million a year over four years, which pales into insignificance compared to the increased funding that I referred to in my substantive answer, there were about 13 adjustments to be made to Abstudy to make it fairer. They are not ones that I would have thought anyone on either side of the house would disagree with. Within those 13—I will come back and very quickly give you two examples of those—there is one that we have had some trouble with, and we are negotiating with the educational institutions affected by that to ensure that they are not inappropriately disadvantaged. Let me give an example. Abstudy students can return home for compassionate leave—(Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I would first like to congratulate Senator Ellison on his appointment and wish him a long and successful ministerial career.
—It certainly couldn't be any shorter than Prosser's; let's face it.

—Senator Ellison is a very fine Western Australian senator, Senator Faulkner. In my home State of Western Australia there is deep concern, as there is throughout Australia, over the level of heroin‐related deaths. What law enforcement initiatives is the government taking to deal with this dreadful problem?

—I thank Senator Eggleston for his question. I realise that Senator Eggleston, a senator from the north-west of Australia, is vitally interested in this area. Having practised as a general practitioner, he is no stranger to this subject.

BREAK.PARA: I want to assure the Senate and the people of Australia that the government is committed to ensuring that there is an effective national effort in fighting the menace of illicit drugs. As the Prime Minister announced yesterday, he has established a task force to prepare an urgent report on a national approach to illicit drugs and an agenda for national action. This task force is to be chaired by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and includes the head of all relevant agencies. The task force will look at current efforts to reduce the supply of drugs, including domestic law enforcement and border control. It will also look at current efforts to reduce the demand for illicit drugs and advise on the allocation of resources to achieve more effective use of Commonwealth funds against illicit drugs. Its report will form the basis of the government's strategy to be put before the special meeting of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy in November.

From the point of view of the Australian Customs Service, the Customs resources specifically devoted to anti‐drug efforts have not been reduced during the time of general budget expenditure reduction. In the 1996‐97 fiscal year, a total of 174 kilograms of heroin was seized. This was double the total of the previous year's seizure. Since 1 July this year, Customs has intercepted approximately 81 kilograms of heroin at the border. Effective anti‐drug efforts at the border by Customs are not just a product of resources alone but also involve the most effective use of intelligence and the available resources it has.

The reductions in expenditure that have been referred to were part of the government's overall budget strategy and have not and will not affect the capacity of Customs to do its job. I might add that in the 1996 budget, the government provided $26 million towards technology to aid in drug detection and interception. In 1997, this year's budget, funding was provided for an upgrade in the Customs fleet, and an acquisition process for eight new vessels has commenced. Since 1 July last year, the Customs coastwatch program has been able to significantly increase its surveillance capacity. Operations are now able to be conducted up to 300 nautical miles from the coast of Australia.

As for claims by Mr Beazley and Premier Carr that cuts to the AFP budget are undermining the fight against drugs, let me say this: the Attorney-General has advised me that any cuts to the AFP budget have come from administration spending. The cut was part of an ongoing budget deficit reduction strategy applied by the federal government. The AFP is managing its expenditure to ensure that it maintains its commitment to important operations and activities within projected budget allocations for the current financial year. The AFP has in place a national framework for priority which ensures that all matters are properly and appropriately assessed and prioritised against available resources. This government is committed to addressing this issue and it will do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. As you are aware, Minister, the Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, recently stated:

QUESTION.PARA: We expect over the course of this year, unemployment will fall—and I expect that by the end of this financial year, we'll see it around or a little below the 8% mark.
Were you consulted by the Treasurer or his department over this forecast? Is it based on data provided by your department?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it might be news to you, but the Bureau of Statistics actually falls within the Treasurer's portfolio. So when I comment monthly on the labour force figures, I am actually relying on figures that are provided from Mr Costello's portfolio area. The ABS is where that information is placed. Therefore, I imagine the Treasurer gets his information both from Treasury and, to the extent he wishes, from the Bureau of Statistics. I think you will find that what the Treasurer has done is outline the government's view, with which I have no disagreement.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you able to overcome your allergy to setting targets and endorse categorically that set by the Treasurer? Do you agree categorically with him that unemployment will drop to eight per cent by the end of June this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —This government does not have an allergy to setting targets—not at all. We have said that no government should be happy with a target lower than full employment. That is what we are aiming for. We cannot tell you exactly when we are going to get there, but we know that we should be happy with nothing less. Until a government gets to the situation where every person who wants a job can get a job, a government should not be satisfied. That is quite the opposite of your notion of an allergy to setting targets.

ANSWER.PARA: We have declined to set lower targets that one could just jump for the convenience of politics, as you people did so frequently. We agree with the statement made by the then Deputy Prime Minister, now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, with respect to the futility of setting those targets. You might be able to come back and tell me whether Mr Beazley has changed his view yet again on something else, because you will understand that his view was that it was quite inappropriate to set such targets. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. The minister would be aware of criticism within the community of the practice amongst universities of relying solely on a student's tertiary education rank to determine whether the student will be offered a place at university. What is the basis of this criticism? Can the minister outline the government's position on the TER? Has the minister read the comments of the shadow minister for education, Mr Mark Latham, who asserts that the TER is a good system that rewards students who work hard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a truly remarkable statement from the shadow minister. Of all the comments that have been made on the TER recently, I have never heard anyone defend it so dogmatically as simply to say, `It is a good system that rewards students who work hard.' Why would the shadow spokesperson have such faith in the TER as an index of merit? Perhaps that is not such a mystery.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Latham has to believe in the infallibility of the TER because that is the basis of rationing publicly funded places in universities. If the TER is not accurate to two decimal places, then the reasoning behind the opposition to full fee places crumbles. People who fail to gain a place through the TER but who are just a few decimal points short, and who are willing to pay their way, cannot possibly be called, as Labor calls them, `the dumb rich'. If the TER is not an infallible measure of merit then the reliance on opposing full fee places falls apart.

I think it is actually Mr Latham who is not so smart. Medical schools—the most heavily and carefully rationed of university places—have moved beyond the TER. They use interviews and other specialised testing in the allocation of places to people from groups from which it is desirable to get doctors.

Anyone who is familiar with the TER knows that its supposed two‐decimal place accuracy is spurious. Many people can be systematically disadvantaged. The Mount Druitt students who gained prominence earlier this year through some reporting, on which there was appropriate comment, are very good examples. They suffered because of the preference in their school for vocational subjects.

Mr Latham is aware of that disadvantage and he is aware that it is apparent in TER distributions, and he has a solution. Mr Latham—your education spokesman—has a solution. He says that we should educate the parents. He knows that the TER is a problem but he does not want to admit it, so his idea is to educate the parents. He said—and you should listen to this very carefully—`In public housing estates, where people have become way too welfare reliant, they have the time and the need for those sorts of parent‐as‐educator programs.'

That is what Mr Latham thinks. In other words, he is saying that kids can be disadvantaged for a whole variety of reasons in their TER and he has a recommendation on how to fix it—educate the parents. He cannot possibly hold both positions. He cannot say that the TER is an infallible measure of a student's merit and at the same time say that some students' parents need a parent‐as‐educator program—although I have spoken to a number of parents who think they might benefit from that because of the homework they are required to assist with!

Apart from being patronising and offensive, this statement shows that Mr Latham simply does not understand TER scores. The problem is that they do not always reflect merit. You do not need to blame parents or schools. The problem is the concept of a single index of merit, not where the kids come from or who their parents are. There are other things you can do to overcome disadvantage in educational opportunities, but this does not mean, and it will never mean, that a single TER score is an appropriate measure of merit for assessment for university.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. If Mr Latham says that the TER is a good system and yet it only caters for the 30 per cent that get to university, what about the other 70 per cent? What policies does the government have, both for schools and for vocational educational training, that will cater for those who do not make it to university under this system?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Stop the clock, please. There are far too many interjections on my left. It makes it impossible to hear.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Carr has gained in height or is sitting on the edge of his seat.
—He is sitting on the edge of his seat.
—I do not know why he does that, rather than in his seat. It makes him feel particularly comfortable.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Tierney rightly raises the point that the TER is of particular relevance to students going to university. That highlights why the New South Wales government—a Labor government—in direct contrast to the views of the federal education shadow minister, accepts that the TER is not an appropriate measure of achievement for young Australians leaving school. It simply is not. That is why the New South Wales government is completely overhauling it.

As Senator Tierney rightly reminds me, about 70 per cent of school leavers do not go on to university. They require different things from their schools. That is why there has to be more vocational training in schools. That is why the apprenticeship and traineeship systems have to be modernised, and that is why we are looking for more entry‐level training places in industry to cater for students who are not going on to university.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—Madam President, I seek to make a point of explanation.
—I am not quite sure what point of order you are making. Are you seeking to make a personal explanation?

—No. At the end of my question, you made the comment that my question would have been better directed to Senator Alston in his capacity representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). If you rule me out of order, I will accept that, but I would like to get an explanation because I believe the question I asked was on taxation matters and was appropriately addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. I ask you for an explanation with regard to your comments at the end of the question.
—I will have a look at the Hansard and check, but listening to the question and answer it seemed to me that it was related to small business.
—I am seeking a point of explanation for your benefit.
—Order! I shall look at the Hansard before I make any further comment and, if I think it is appropriate, I will let you know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, yesterday Senator Harradine asked me a question without notice about a press release issued on 8 April on X‐rated and R‐rated material. In accordance with the undertaking I gave, the matter was referred to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams). The Attorney‐General has noted that the joint press release referred to must be viewed in its entirety as not only reflecting the government's decision but also providing information to the community about what the proposed new NVE category is likely to contain. It does not profess to be a detailed exposition of what is or is not currently contained in the x‐rated category.

SPEECH.PARA: The joint press release sought to communicate to the media and to the general public the decisions of cabinet on a number of classification issues. The essential message sought to be conveyed by the joint press release in respect of the proposed new NVE category was that it would be subject to tighter guidelines than currently apply to the X‐rated category.

Events have moved on since the press release was issued. Discussions have taken place with state and territory censorship ministers about the creation of the new NVE category and about the tighter guidelines that will apply to its content. Although there was broad support for tighter guidelines, some ministers expressed concerns about some aspects of the proposal and wish to clarify and discuss it further. All ministers have agreed that there should be further discussion of the issues and the matter will be considered again at the next censorship ministers meeting in December this year.

The government renews the offer made by Senator Ellison at the estimates committee hearing last week to provide a briefing for Senator Harradine on the current position reached in this matter. There is nothing that the Prime Minister wishes to add to the response that has been given by the Attorney‐General.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during question time I undertook to provide Senator Faulkner with a copy of the arrangements that were entered into between the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and Senator Herron in relation to the minimal practice that he has been allowed to continue. I table the correspondence evidencing that arrangement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Herron has provided additional information to an answer he gave to a question from Senator Reynolds during question time yesterday. I seek leave to incorporate the additional information in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
During question time yesterday, Senator Reynolds asked whether I had received a recent report relating to the proposed Jabiluka uranium mine.
I took Senator Reynolds to be referring to the environmental impact statement provided by Senator Hill to Senator Parer on Friday, 22 August.
This is the only report dealing specifically with the proposed Jabiluka uranium mine.
However, having checked the Hansard , it appears that Senator Reynolds could have been referring to the Kakadu region social impact study.

This study examined the social and cultural impact of various developments in the Kakadu region over the last 20 years, including mining, tourism, conservation and urban development—it was not limited to Jabiluka.
This report was publicly released on 20 August, and of course. I have been provided with a copy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron has provided additional information to an answer he gave to a question from Senator Forshaw during question time yesterday. I seek leave to incorporate the additional information in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The answer read as follows—

Further to a question from Senator Forshaw yesterday, I advise that discussions between the Prime Minister's office and ministers outside the cabinet are, according to longstanding convention, not matters for public discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to a question without notice asked by Senator Childs today, relating to employment.

Senator Child's question referred to the most important issue facing this country today, that is, the issue of unemployment and related to that, of course, job insecurity. Senator Childs asked Senator Vanstone for the definition of an employment placement for the purposes of the success fee for the new private employment agencies.

What we had today was a typical response from the minister. Yet again there was evasion and an attempt not only to avoid answering the question but also to avoid accepting any responsibility for the jobs crisis in Australia.

Senator Vanstone has consistently attempted to dodge responsibility and to dodge any real answer to finding real solutions to the chronic unemployment problem which faces this country. The latest attempt by Senator Vanstone, together with her ministerial colleagues, is another in a long, long list of excuses for what is emerging as an increasing unemployment problem.

We only have to look at the statistics over the last year, particularly since last August's budget, to see the worsening unemployment rates right around Australia. In March 1996, when this government was elected, the unemployment rate across the nation was 8.5 per cent, and it has been trending gradually upwards almost continuously ever since to stand at 8.7 per cent as of July this year.

One of the other interesting aspects of the worsening unemployment rate is the participation rate which, in July last year, stood at just over 63.5 per cent and, in July this year, has dropped to 63.2 per cent. Importantly, we have had, a worsening youth unemployment rate which stood at just over 26.4 per cent in July last year and is currently at 27.8 per cent.

Senator Vanstone continually attempts to dodge and weave any real solution to this issue. Her ministerial colleagues have attempted to do the same, but Senator Vanstone certainly stands out amongst the ministers opposite.

We have had a long litany of excuses. The argument was put last year that we had to get the budget into balance. That in itself, of course, has created some of the problems that this country is faced with today. That budget went a long way, Senator Vanstone, to destroying the confidence of the community, particularly with respect to small business demand. There has been a lot said about small business by this government. But if Senator Vanstone and her colleagues had been listening, over the last few months in particular, they would have found that the number one concern of business is the issue of consumer confidence and consumers spending money. They are concerned about rising unemployment and job insecurity.

Then we had the next excuse, which was the industrial relations system. The industrial relations system needed modernising. It needed to be made more flexible so that small business could employ more people. We have seen no evidence to date that the changes to the industrial relations system have contributed to that.

We had the cuts to the employment service area in that budget of last year. We have had the magic elixir of work for the dole. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, went to the United States and discovered computers. He also discovered, at least for two days, the argument that we should be lowering wages. We now have the latest excuse for unemployment, and that is the tax system. The Prime Minister has decided to invent a broad based indirect tax, commonly known as a BBIT. That is the latest excuse for this government's failure to address the increasing unemployment levels around this nation and the increasing insecurity.

BREAK.PARA: In Senator Vanstone's answer today there was yet more evasion. It is useful to serve that particular answer as yet another example of Senator Vanstone failing to address this issue. There is slashing of labour market programs and increasing youth unemployment. There are problems in regional Australia, and there are particular problems associated with the changes to the delivery of employment services—an issue Senator Vanstone failed to address in her response to Senator Child's question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of the question from Senator Sherry initially related to how you define people and how many hours they work. He was criticising the 15-hour level. Senator Sherry, under your government, if someone received one hour's work, they were suddenly defined as `employed' and were taken off the unemployment list. When we look at the record of your government on this matter, we just wonder why you have the hide to get up and take note of the answer given during question time. You talk about targets. I just wonder quite what your targets are. Have a look at the outcomes. That is an average of 8½ per cent unemployment during your 13 years in government.
—What was it like when we left office?
—Senator Sherry, you raise the point, `What was it like when we left office?'
—It was coming down.
—Senator Sherry, what about the pain that was inflicted on the—
—Senator Tierney, would you like to address your remarks through the chair, please. Then Senator Sherry would not—

—Madam Deputy President, Senator Sherry raises an interesting point about his own government's record. He refers to their last day in office. I think what the Australian people remember, Senator Sherry, is your 13 years in office and the enormous pain they endured under high levels of unemployment. When I came into this parliament in 1991, unemployment was a little over nine per cent, and then it went to 10 per cent and then it went to 11 per cent. The average right over the period was 8½ per cent. Senator Sherry, you expect us to wave a magic wand and fix this problem immediately. We are still trying to cope with your 13 years of mismanagement of the economy when you missed many golden opportunities. You took foreign debt from $20 billion up to $180 billion and created enormous problems for our economy. You then say, `Why haven't you people fixed it in 18 months?'
—They reckon churning people through Working Nation has reduced it.

—Thank you, Senator Campbell. I was going to talk about their solutions in a minute but, before I finish with their record, let me turn to the youth unemployment record, which is absolutely disgraceful.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember looking at the figures in 1986 when your government had been in power for four years, and we had 25 per cent youth unemployment at that stage. I note that you did not mention that figure, Senator. When you left office, your figure was up to 28 per cent. What a great improvement in 11 years! You actually went backwards. You did not solve this problem. You actually made the problem worse. It was actually a lot worse than the figures indicated, because you kept hiding people on the unemployment queue. You kept defining people off the queue. We have this huge pool of hidden unemployment on top of the official figure that we had to deal with.

You talked about targets in what you had to say, and I believe your target is five per cent by the turn of the century. Every economic commentator that I have read on the subject said that, unless you are running the economy absolutely full bore—therefore sucking in more foreign debt; that is, foreign debt that you helped create—you would have no chance of getting anywhere near five per cent. You were not going to make the five per cent because, as Senator Campbell pointed out, your solution was really no solution. Working Nation—what a joke!

BREAK.PARA: Have a look at the outcomes of the so-called Working Nation program. Thirty per cent of the people who undertook your programs actually got a job. Seventy per cent in Working Nation went back onto the unemployment scrap heap. What a program that was! It cost hundreds of millions of dollars. At least this government is focusing on getting the fundamentals right—something Paul Keating should have done back in the mid-1980s.

Have a look at the way the interest rates are still dropping. Have a look at the budget deficit. That is another figure you did not mention, Senator Sherry. Have a look at what the budget deficit was when you left office and compare that with the budget surplus that we are now moving towards under good financial management. Look at the micro-economic reforms that we have instigated in industrial relations in terms of small business, which is the real job generator. What this government is concerned about is not make‐work programs. This government is concerned about actual jobs. That is generated by the small business sector, and that is generated by getting the economic settings right. Senator Sherry, I was absolutely amazed you got up and spoke on this matter, given the record of your government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —This government went to the last election with a program of pathways to real jobs. They are the terms that have been consistently used by this government both to condemn the Working Nation program and to try to talk up their pretty pathetic efforts in this area. But when we look at the matters that were the subject of questions today—and we are looking at, in particular, the minister's employment services request for tender—we see that there is a proposal to pay private providers for establishing a real job for an unemployed person, a person who is eligible for benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: A real job? How many hours a week? Fifteen hours a week over five days. The job has to be no fewer than three hours per day. That is a real job. This government is going to spend, in the minister's terms, $1.7 billion between May next year and December 1999 to get people into real jobs. This is the achievement—the benchmark—that this government is aiming for. The government has the nerve to criticise Working Nation for under achievement when it has set such a low bar benchmark for its own achievements.

Paul Cleary, in the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday, 8 August—Senator Childs referred to this article in his question—was absolutely scathing in his condemnation of this program. You see, when the minister had legislation before this parliament the bar for a real job was going to be set at 20 hours. Now the minister has lowered the bar to 15 hours a week over five days. In the words of Mr Cleary:
Even for the most employable unemployed, the Government believes it must lower the hurdle to a pathetic level to make the scheme a success.
They are not my words—they are the words of Mr Cleary in the Sydney Morning Herald . They are a condemnation of this approach by the minister.

Real jobs are defined in the government's own documents as 15 hours a week. That is what they want. We are not talking about the statistician's figures—let us get the red herrings off the table. We are talking about the jobs that this government said it was going to create. These are the jobs that this government is going to pay people to arrange. In other words, they are going to get a private provider and say, `We will pay whatever you have contracted to provide. As long as the job is three hours a day over five days a week, and lasts for a minimum period, you will get paid. That is all we want.'

The mark has changed from the outcome proposed by the previous tender. Originally the minister was saying that you would pay the premium for a primary outcome of 20 hours, which would have got the person off unemployment benefit. The secondary outcome at that stage was the proposal of between 15 and 19 hours. What is now the primary outcome was, then, the secondary outcome. You really do not know what you are talking about.

But if you want to talk about waste, let us have a look at something that did come up in the estimates hearings—something that we did ascertain. Under the training for employment program this government is funding a company it knows nothing about to the tune of $800 per person per week. The company is to provide hospitality training for jobs that at this stage do not exist, on a ship that at this stage is not in Australian waters, and probably is not owned by the company in question. The government is providing this funding without checking the company. This is the record of this government. This is the record of this minister in relation to Commonwealth money that is being spent under the training for employment program. This government is going to create jobs by throwing money away possibly, by spending $800 per person per week on a training program.

This sort of expenditure makes any criticism of Working Nation, in terms of its levels of expenditure, absolutely irrelevant. This government has done nothing to create real jobs. This government's programs are demonstrably wasteful. Spending $1.7 billion over a period of 18 months on a program which is able to provide only the minimal sorts of jobs that it defines is just not good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor Party senators have a gall to come into the chamber today and talk about unemployment. They had an abysmal record on unemployment, and as far as youth unemployment goes it was absolutely abysmal. In 1994‐95, in Labor's last year in office, youth unemployment was a staggering 32.3 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Over 13 years of Labor, Hawke, Keating and Beazley presided over the virtual demise—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would you please use their names correctly.

—I am sorry. Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and Mr Beazley presided over the virtual demise of the Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system, and we have seen the outcome of that. We have young people not having the skills that they need to be in the workforce because Labor neglected this area. In 1995 apprenticeship and traineeship numbers fell to their lowest level as a percentage of the workforce in three decades. That was the sort of record, that was the sort of statistic, that was the indelible mark that you left on youth unemployment in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry got up and talked about chronic unemployment. Yes, chronic unemployment was built up over 13 years of Labor. You do not turn that around overnight. For 13 years of Labor we saw this indelible chronic unemployment. It was right that Senator Sherry talked about chronic unemployment inherited by this government from Labor. The stain of your mismanagement is still apparent, and it ought to be thrown back at you and in your face every time.
Senator Sherry talked about the unemployment trend. He failed to talk about the fact that the unemployment figures we have are a much more honest reflection and picture of unemployment.
Senator O'Brien interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You hid unemployment through the Working Nation program. We sat and listened to you in silence. But no, Madam Deputy President, they do not like being told what happened. They hid the figures. They churned people through. They took them off unemployment benefit and put them in a training scheme for six months. And what happened?
