Seventy per cent or more of them, a significant proportion of them, were back on the unemployment queue again, but this time as short‐term unemployed—churned over and over under Working Nation and not getting real jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: They did nothing about reform in industrial relations; they did nothing about encouraging small business to employ people. Every small business you went to would say, `We're not going to employ people because it's too hard. If they do the wrong thing, there is no incentive for us to employ people in small business.' They did nothing to reform. In fact, what they are going to do now is to oppose legislation which still affects small business and means that they will not employ. You go and talk to small business people; you go and talk to my father who, at 76, employs people. He will not employ them because he finds it too difficult. So small business person after small business person will not create jobs because of the industrial relations system you left. You will not actually recognise that you lost the last election. In fact, when it will get through your thick skulls that you lost the last election, I don't know.

As for Senator Sherry, who went on to say that getting the budget to balance has caused a lot of problems, he did not mention the problems that giving us $180 million of foreign debt has caused us. He did not mention the problem created by having to repay $10 billion a year on the interest on the debt that you chalked up. What about what that does to jobs, to the economy, to the impost we put on business, and the disincentives for creating jobs? He did not mention that—he did not mention the legacy of that and he did not mention that that is still the indelible stain that has been left from your mismanagement. No, he would go on a spending spree as you all did. If you get your hands on the levers again, it would be spend, spend, spend. That is what Labor's policy is—spend the next generation's money to create the sorts of programs that are in fact failed programs.

What we are on about is creating apprenticeships, not doing the sorts of things that you did. You left the apprenticeship scheme in an appalling state, you left youth unemployment in an appalling state and you left the budget in an appalling state. You chalked up $11 million to $15 million a year. You would have continued to do that and the IMF would have walked in here. But you didn't care about that; you were an irresponsible government, and you sit here now complaining about unemployment. The unemployment we now see is a legacy left to Australia by Labor, and the Australian public know that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak to the motion to take note of the answer given to the question asked by Senator Childs. I would like to go back to the point raised by Senator Sherry, which was that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) in fact evaded addressing the question. The question was that the government was changing the definition of an employment placement for the purposes of paying a success fee to new private employment agencies from 20 hours to 15 hours a week. What did the minister say? The minister referred to ABS statistics. That is irrelevant to the point; they have not been changed. There has been no change between when Labor was in government and the present government in relation to ABS statistics. The point is that the government is changing the definition of what will be regarded as a real job in relation to employment placements.

SPEECH.PARA: When the minister actually does comment about what will be regarded as a real job, she says something vague such as, `Oh, we're doing assessments on what will be regarded as a reasonable standard for someone to be independent and that is 15 hours.' She would not respond to interjections about why we are dropping from 20 hours down to 15. I do not think she had much understanding of that point at all. I challenge the government to actually give us details of how they assess whether 15 hours a week of work is enough for somebody to regard themselves, or for the government to regard them, as earning sufficient income to be independent. I know a lot of workers out there who work 15, 20, 25 hours a week and I know that they are struggling on the income they have, let alone having their definition dropped down to 15 hours a week.

One of our chronic employment problems is not just unemployment, but chronic under‐employment. This government is hoping to contribute to that further and also hoping to avoid some of its obligations in relation to employment in its election commitments by shifting people off unemployment statistically. That is what this is really about. It is a last‐minute attempt to try to do something which will shift the statistics but still not provide an answer to unemployment.

While I am on the point of the minister evading giving the Senate decent answers to these questions, I would also like in passing to refer to the answer to my question. The minister referred to seasonal work in relation to our concerns about an increase in the number of overseas workers coming in and taking jobs from young people in Australia. The minister has no idea whether seasonal workers are taking those jobs—no idea at all. Such poor answers highlight the lack of implementation of Howard's election promise to make employment the first priority. The first priority—not tax reform, not anything else; unemployment was to be the first priority. We are now—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I take a point of order. I noticed that when Senator Patterson was referring to former Labor prime ministers, you requested that she make the proper reference. I would hope that, in your normal way, you would show an even handedness and ask Senator Collins to refer to Mr Howard as Mr Howard.
—Certainly. Senator Collins, if you have not done so, would you please do so?

—Certainly, Madam Deputy President. The poor answers displayed today by the minister again highlight that Mr Howard's election promise that unemployment be the first priority is not being honoured by this government. We have an inoperative cabinet working group on unemployment which, while widely acclaimed by the government when it was established some time back, cannot even attract senior ministers to attend its summit and has come up with no plan.

SPEECH.PARA: Meantime, the government continues to run false races which again was raised in the responses to taking note today by government members. We had, firstly, the Workplace Relations Act, including unfair dismissals and how that was going to solve unemployment. I remember from chairing the hearings in relation to that act that the argument was run that it would solve unemployment, but there was no substance to that argument, as we reported.

The second race being run is: small business reforms will provide employment. We have no record from that from any of the reforms to date, similarly with respect to the Workplace Relations Act. Another claim is that more unfair dismissal changes for small business will generate employment. Through estimates we know there is no justification for those claims. There are also claims about reducing wages and, finally, the GST. The community knows these are not answers. They know the government has no solutions. They know the record is getting worse.

Yes, unemployment is a chronic problem in this country but at some stage this government has to stop harking back to the record of previous governments and take responsibility for its own actions now. This government has been in place for 17 months and unemployment is getting worse, not better. We are not even seeing marginal gains in terms of all of these claims about what was going to improve unemployment; it is getting worse. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to contribute to this debate. I remind Senator Jacinta Collins that I came to this place in exactly May 1990. When I heard then Senator Button, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, and other front bench members of the previous Hawke-Keating government, blaming the ills of the nation on Malcolm Fraser and John Howard, I thought that was stretching the realms of credibility since the Labor government had then been in power for seven years. For my sins and others' sins I had to sit out another six years in opposition.
—But this is your government's first priority.

—Senator Collins, we have been in power for 17 months. I am not making excuses; I am making a small aside. I have been in here for seven years now. Six of those years was sitting over where you are sitting thereabouts. In each one of those six years I had ministers in the previous Hawke and Keating governments lecturing us—
—Would you care to use the proper names, please?

—I was talking about their governments—Mr Hawke's government and Mr Keating's government, if you like. I refer to Mr Hawke and Mr Keating far more politely than they refer to each other, I understand.

SPEECH.PARA: To get back to the debate, up to 17 months ago members of your previous ministerial team reminded us continually that all of Australians' woes were caused by Malcolm Fraser but mostly John Howard when he was Treasurer. Senator Collins, if we do from time to time over the next few years remind you and remind the Australian people that the previous governments were not the greatest economic managers this place has ever seen, then I apologise. You can say that we are playing a bit of politics, but I think in Parliament House most people would expect that.

One of the reasons people do not have as much confidence as we would like them to have at the moment is the consumers of Australia had some fairly horrendous experiences over the last 13 years. Those horrendous experiences were caused because you had incompetent people managing the economic levers. Mr Keating, the previous Prime Minister and Treasurer, used to come into the other place and brag about how he had the economic levers so firmly in his hands and Australia was in very good shape and in very good hands. He had the Reserve Bank in his pocket, he had Treasury in his pocket, and Finance in his pocket, and it was all under control and she'll be right.

But do you know what scared a lot of Australians? When Mr Keating was Treasurer and he would say that `it is a beautiful set of numbers' or `this is the budget that brings home the bacon' and people would see interest rates coming down or employment trending down momentarily, they believed him. They believed that Mr Keating was getting it right. They would start investing in small businesses and buying homes and paying reasonable interest rates and then within a few minutes of Mr Keating coming out and saying that all of a sudden he would have to pull the brakes on. Interest rates would go down just below 10 per cent and, wham, Mr Keating when he was Mr Hawke's Treasurer and then Prime Minister would all of a sudden have to rip the brakes on and interest rates would go zooming from less than 10 per cent up to 17 per cent.

A lot of people out there remember that—people who had mortgages, who were forced to sell their homes, or lost their businesses, or went bankrupt as a result of the economic management by the previous Labor govern ment. We are not going to let them forget that because we have to bring good financial management into government.

If you want people to have income security and job security you do not do it by coming up with schemes like Working Nation which basically had the political task of churning people through the unemployment statistics just long enough to get you to the last election. That was the effect of spending billions of dollars on Working Nation. It churned particularly young people through the employment statistics. It did not create real jobs. It did not create jobs in businesses. It did not create jobs in free enterprise. It did not create sustainable jobs.

This government is committed to ensuring that you have security of employment, but you do not do that by running the national economy on bankcard. You do not do that by going across to German banks and Japanese banks and saying, `We need another $10 billion just to pay for the annual services of government.' You do that by ensuring that Australia can pay her way.

We have had to make economic adjustments. That will require adjustment amongst the households of Australia but the long-term benefit is that we will have sustainable economic growth, not a boom-bust roller coaster ride a la Paul Keating and Bob Hawke, not five minutes of sunshine and then a crash but long‐term decades of growth, sustainable jobs and employment. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 28 July 1997 of John FitzPatrick, a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Darling, New South Wales, from 1969 to 1977 and for the division of Riverina, New South Wales, from 1977 to 1980.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are still the only Australians, sent overseas on active service, whose service has not been recognised in three important areas:
1. R.A.N. casualties are not yet included on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial alongside Army and R.A.A.F. casualties;
2. R.A.N. service has not yet been recognised with the visible signs of service to Australia; the Returned from Active Service Badge and the Naval campaign medal; and
3. R.A.N. service is still not acknowledged as eligible service for the Australian Service Pension, while service by Commonwealth and allied veterans from 55 other countries is.
Members of the Army and R.A.A.F. who served during the same period in Malaya had their service fully recognised 24 hours after arriving in Malaya.

In the 1997 Budget the Government partly recognised that R.A.N. service by providing the same recognition and benefits for that service. The cost will be minuscule, being mainly a transfer of pensions from `age' as paid by the Department of Social Security, to `service' pensions, paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned request the Australian Senate implements the following:
A Senate enquiry into the use of genetic engineering in the Australian Food Supply, including the ethics of its use.
That consultations be undertaken with the general public to ask if we want this technology in our food supply and consent to its use.
That consumers be resourced to attend these consultations.
Any food that is genetically engineered or contains components that are genetically engineered are required to be labelled, including the origin of the genes.
That meaningful right to know legislation be enacted to guarantee public access to toxicology data.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned recognises the importance to Australia's retirement income policy of a stable and secure superannuation system in which people are encouraged, not penalised, for taking steps to provide for their retirement and asks that:
Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that `The Coalition is fully committed to engendering stability, security, simplicity and flexibility into the superannuation system'.

The Liberal/National Government acknowledge that the inclusion of superannuation assets and roll‐over funds in the social security means test is inequitable, erodes public confidence in the superannuation system and penalises those who have attempted to provide for their own retirement.
The Government repeal legislation including superannuation assets and roll‐over funds in the social security means test.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any legislation which undermines the co‐existence of native title with pastoral leases.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any legislation which would overturn the recent High Court Wik decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned nurses and members of the public shows their concerns with the Aged Care Bill 1997 and the accompanying changes to the funding and regulation of Aged Care announced by the Government in the 1996 Budget. In particular regarding the abolition of specific funding for the provision of nursing care to residents of nursing homes.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate amend the Aged Care Bill 1997 so as to provide a requirement that funding of aged care be in such a form that specific funds are allocated to aged care providers for the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents and that aged care providers be allowed to spend that money only on the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Allison, Sen Lyn; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Forest Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;
support incentives for nationwide composting, soil remineralisation, and planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Allison(from 503 citizens)and Senator Lees(from 503 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promotes Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

PETITION.TITLE: Timed Local Calls
PETITION.PARA: A Petition to the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain residents in the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the Senate the harsh and regressive decision by the Howard Government to allow telecommunications carriers to charge timed local calls for data communication services such as electronic mail, facsimile, the internet and other on‐line services. This measure will adversely affect business and individual users of the above services, and particularly hamper the operations and growth of small business.
Your petitioners call on the Senate to request that the Howard Government rescind their decision, and ensure local data communication services are charged on an untimed basis.

PETITION.TITLE: Cooked Chicken Meat
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned:
(i) believes that importing chicken meat into Australia carries a real risk of introducing Newcastle disease into the Australian environment;
(ii) recognises that this threatens Australia's native birds and poultry industry;
(iii) expresses concern at the negative economic impact that importation of chicken meat will have on the domestic industry and the potential job losses which will result; and
(iv) calls on the government not to allow the importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) views with concern, the prospect of the Industry Commission's recommendations on the textile, clothing and footwear industries being implemented by the Government;

(b) believes that, if implemented, the commission's recommendations would lead to at least 50 000 Australian jobs being forced off-shore with the remaining 50 000 workers forced into low-paid, backyard operations; and
(c) calls on the Government to implement a freeze on tariff reductions from the year 2000 to 2005, consistent with our international obligations.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education: Undergraduate Fees and Abstudy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Brown, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—

(a) supports the student occupation of the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology's finance and strategic planning department as part of a continuing campaign to prevent the imposition of up-front fee payments for domestic undergraduate students at Australian universities; and
(b) calls on the Government to demonstrate its commitment to Aboriginal health and education by withdrawing its planned changes to ABSTUDY.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Watson, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation on the principles relating to provisions governing the early release of superannuation benefits as contained in the Small Superannuation Accounts Amendment Bill 1997 be extended to 11 September 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, three sitting days from today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the order of 26 June 1997 that there be laid on the table by the then Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Newman), no later than midday on 27 June 1997, the full report of the independent review of section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 (also known as the Rassaby report),

(ii) the Minister's response pursuant to that order, which was tabled on 27 June 1997 and which states that, `in declining to table the report, the Government advises the Senate that the Minister for Health and Family Services has directed that the Government's response to the report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee, The tobacco industry and the costs of tobacco‐related illness , will be tabled in the Senate during the winter recess', and
(iii) that the Government's response to the committee's report was not presented during the winter recess;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) again calls on the Government to release the Rassaby report; and

(c) resolves that there be laid on the table, by the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services (Senator Herron), no later than midday on 3 September 1997, the Government's response to the report of the Community Affairs References Committee entitled, The tobacco industry and the costs of tobacco‐related illness .

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Gibson, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 be extended to 2 October 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the Private Members' Business in the House of Representatives, on 25 August 1997, regarding the Charter of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC),

(ii) that the Member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) claimed the evidence is clear that, while Australians spend 8 cents per person per day on the ABC, 6 cents of that is going to and being spent in Sydney while in fact there is no evidence to that effect because it is not the case, and

(iii) that 33 per cent of the news and current affairs budget of the ABC is spent in Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth, Hobart and Darwin, and that a minimum of 13 per cent of the ABC's budget for other programs is spent outside Sydney and Melbourne;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) to request Mr Pyne to provide him with the so‐called evidence from which he extracted this information, and to table that documentation in the Senate;
(c) is aware that the amount of money now being spent on the ABC amounts to approximately 7 cents per person per day, when funds allocated to the orchestras are included; and
(d) deplores the Government's funding cuts to the ABC, noting that these cuts will force the ABC to further cut back on programs and services to all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i) more than 100 students are currently occupying the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT) to protest against that institution's decision to introduce up-front undergraduate fees, and
(ii) fees are a financial and psychological disincentive to enter into and pursue higher education;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the university to desist from using the threat of withdrawal of student monies, at a rate of $50 000 for every day of the occupation, against the RMIT Student Union; and
(c) supports the right to financial and political autonomy of democratically-elected student organisations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on Monday, 1 September 1997, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Government appoint an independent committee, to be known as the Judicial Appointments Committee, to:

PARA.TAB: (a) draft and publish the qualifications for appointment and selection criteria for the selection of judges for the High Court;
(b) record the selection criteria in a protocol which is to be reviewed periodically by the Judicial Appointments Committee;
(c) evaluate and assess suitable candidates for positions on the High Court bench as positions become available; and
(d) recommend the selection of future High Court judges who are then to be appointed by the Governor-General in Council.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) That the committee consist of, at least, the following representatives:

PARA.TAB: (a) the Commonwealth Attorney-General;
(b) one representative nominated by the Australian Bar Association;
(c) one representative nominated by the Law Council of Australia;
(d) one academic versed in constitutional law;
(e) one community representative; and
(f) two representatives of the States nominated by the Council of Australian Governments.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the committee have the power to appoint a chairperson and deputy chairperson.
(4) That five members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(5) That in matters of procedure the chairperson or deputy chairperson presiding at the meeting have a deliberative vote only.
(6) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(7) That a message be sent to the House of Representatives acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chris Evans, at the request of Senator Mackay) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion No. 641 standing in the name of Senator Mackay for today, proposing an order for the production of documents, by the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Alston), be postponed till 28 August.
Motion (by Senator Campbell, at the request of Senator Ellison) agreed to:
That on Tuesday, 26 August 1997:
(a) the hours of meeting shall be 2 pm to 5.30 pm; and
(b) the Senate shall adjourn at 5.30 pm without the question being put.
Motion (by Senator Allison) agreed to:
That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i) of the five orca whales captured off Taiji, Japan on 7 February 1997, two have now died in captivity,
(ii) one of these whales, the youngest male of the group, died on 14 June 1997, having been separated from his mother and kept at Shirahama Adventure World, and
(iii) the other was pregnant at the time of capture, miscarried 2 months later and refused to eat the dead fish offered by aquarium staff throughout the 4 months in captivity;

PROCTEXT.PARA: (b) acknowledges that orca whales are unlikely to survive in aquariums; and
(c) urges the Japanese Government to release the three remaining orca whales.
Motion (by Senator Calvert, at the request of Senator Gibson) agreed to:

That the Joint Committee of Public Accounts be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate on 28 August 1997, from 9.30 am till 11 am, to take evidence from Mr Max Moore‐Wilton for the committee's inquiry into the Public Service Bill 1997 and a related bill.
Motion (by The Deputy President, at the request of The President) agreed to:
That the Senate resolves that the following procedures apply for the declaration by senators of their receipt of any gift intended by the donor to be a gift to the Senate or the Parliament:

(1) (a) Any senator, including any Senate officer‐holder and any senator who is a leader or a member of a parliamentary delegation, who in any capacity receives any gift which is intended by the donor to be a gift to the Senate or the Parliament must, as soon as practical, place the gift in the custody of the Registrar of Senators' Interests and declare receipt of the gift to the Registrar.

PARA.TAB: (b) A gift is to be taken as intended to be a gift to the Senate or the Parliament where:

TAB.TAB: (i) the donor expressly states that the gift is to the Senate or to the Parliament; or

(ii) the identity of the donor, the nature of the occasion, or the intrinsic significance or value of the gift is such that it is reasonable to assume that the gift was intended for the Senate or the Parliament; or
(iii) the gift has a value in excess of:
(a) $500 when given by an official government source, or
(b) $200 when given by a private person or non‐government body on any occasion when the senator is present in his or her capacity as a senator, Senate office‐holder or delegation leader or member.

PARA.TAB: (c) The Registrar of Senators' Interests is to maintain a public Register of Gifts to the Senate and the Parliament.

(d) The Committee of Senators' Interests is to recommend to the President whether, and how, the gift is to be used or displayed in Parliament House, including in the office of any senator, or used or displayed on loan elsewhere, including in a museum, library, gallery, court building, government building, government office or other place.

(e) Where a gift given to a senator is intended to be for the Parliament, the President is to consult with the Speaker prior to agreeing to a recommendation of the committee as to its use, display or loan.

(f) Where the President disagrees with a recommendation of the committee, the President is to report the disagreement to the Senate, which may determine the use, display or loan of the gift in question.
(g) In making recommendations the committee is to take into account the intention of the Senate that gifts are to be used, displayed or loaned in a way which:

TAB.TAB: (i) reflects proper respect for the intentions of the donor and the dignity of the Senate or the Parliament;
(ii) recognises the interest of the public in gifts to the Senate or the Parliament; and
(iii) takes account of practical issues including space, custody, preservation and propriety in the use, display or loan of such gifts.

PARA.TAB: (h) Where a senator is uncertain of the nature of a gift the senator may request advice from the committee.

(i) Where a senator disagrees with the advice of the committee the senator is to report the disagreement to the Senate, which may determine the nature of the gift and its use, display or loan, if any.
(j) In paragraph (1) a reference to a gift to the Parliament includes a gift given to a senator for the House of Representatives.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2) This resolution applies to a gift received by the spouse, family member or staff member of a senator on any occasion when the senator is present in his or her capacity as a senator, Senate office‐holder or delegation leader or member, as if the gift had been received by the senator.
(3) The committee:

PARA.TAB: (a) is empowered to consider any matter placed before it pursuant to this resolution, and for the purposes of this resolution the committee has the powers provided in the resolution of 17 March 1994 establishing the committee; and
(b) may make, and must as soon as practicable thereafter table, procedural rules to facilitate the operation of this resolution.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (4) Any senator who:

PARA.TAB: (a) knowingly fails to tender and declare a gift that is taken to be a gift to the Senate or the Parliament as required by this resolution; or
(b) knowingly fails to return to the Registrar a gift which it was agreed or determined the senator might use or display; or
(c) knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar or the committee,

is guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and is to be dealt with by the Senate accordingly, but the question whether any senator has committed such a contempt is to be referred to the Privileges Committee for inquiry and report and may not be considered by any other committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner):

BREAK.PARA: Dear Madam President
Pursuant to standing order number 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, to understand and defend public schools as revealed by her unprecedented attack on Australia's public education system in a recent speech to the American Chamber of Commerce.
Yours sincerely
John Faulkner
Is the proposal supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, to understand and defend public schools as revealed by her unprecedented attack on Australia's public education system in a recent speech to the American Chamber of Commerce.

Senator Vanstone, as Australia's education minister who is responsible for the public school system in this country, has betrayed every student in the system. She has betrayed every teacher in the system. She has betrayed every parent who is dependent on the system. She has betrayed every product of that school system. We know that there are lies, damn lies and statistics but, after all and after that, there is Senator Vanstone.

Senator Vanstone, using a bodgie spin on certain ABS statistics, while speaking to, of all people, the American Chamber of Commerce, concluded that private schools were a one‐way ticket to work, whereas 14 per cent of male students graduating in the public system would find themselves unemployed. She then stated, `Private schools have beaten unemployment.' They are her words: `Private schools have beaten unemployment.'

In the process, she has angered, worried and concerned parents. She has certainly worried and affected young people right across Australia who go to those selfsame public schools. I think Senator Vanstone, giving her some credit here because perhaps it was inadvertent—I hope it was inadvertent—was saying to employers that private school graduates are better than those from public schools. That was the thrust of what Senator Vanstone was saying.

Senator Vanstone has insulted those who work in the public school system. She has insulted the teachers who work in the public schools, and she has managed to do that to the point where the Secondary School Principals Association has threatened to boycott government youth programs which require the cooperation of schools. The national president of that association, Mr Duncan Stalker, stated point‐blank on ABC Radio:
It's Senator Vanstone who's grossly distorted the statistics.

I think that Senator Vanstone has forgotten that she is the minister in government charged with the responsibility for public school funding. She is the minister responsible for protecting our schools. She is the minister who is responsible for the quality of public schools. Instead of offering constructive solutions about progressing public education in this country in a positive way—public education which she is responsible for—she has made carping, negative, destructive comments and she has washed her hands of the responsibility for these schools.

Even after the minister for education, Senator Vanstone, blurted out this dubious, statistical adventure and was roundly criticised by parents, teachers, commentators and editorial writers about a fortnight ago—she copped an absolute lacing—she repeated her statistical spin on Wednesday on the A.M. radio program. It may be a source of astonishment to Senator Vanstone, but private schools do not create the jobs necessary to beat unemployment.

I was pleased to see an editorial in the Courier‐Mail on 14 August because I think it said it all. The headline was very instructive. The headline of the editorial in the Courier‐Mail was `Schools can't make jobs, Senator'. But, of course, in that madcap diatribe from Senator Vanstone, she did not mention the location advantage of most private schools. She did not mention the fact that around 70 per cent of students attend public schools in this country.

She did not mention the fact that private schools can pick and choose their students, while public schools—even in the face of this reprehensible government's policies of funding cuts—strive to provide a high quality standard of education for kids who come from all backgrounds. The public school system in this country takes all comers and it strives for excellence. It does not deserve the put‐down, smear and libel of this minister for education.

Mr Howard, the Prime Minister, in what I thought was a rather deluded moment, tried to defend Senator Vanstone. It was a very lukewarm defence, I might say. He said on 13 August that he was a product of the public school system. Let me quote what he said. He said:
. . . I won't have the public education system run down.
That is what Mr Howard said. Let me interpolate here. What was he talking about? He said:
. . . those sort of comparisons—
They were Mr Howard's words. What he was talking about were the bodgie statistical comparisons that were offered up by his education minister. He said:
. . . those sort of comparisons don't make proper allowance for some of the circumstances in which government schools have got to operate.
They are Mr Howard's words, as he was trying to repair just some of the damage that his incompetent Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs caused.

In 18 months of ideologically, hide‐bound government, Mr Howard has made it tougher for those government schools by slashing $270 million from schools funding through enrolment benchmark adjustments, with a real cut to Commonwealth secondary education of 7.8 per cent. Of course, the coalition is financing the private school sector at the expense of government schools. What we say is that this is simply just not a fair policy. These are the new found circumstances in which, under Mr Howard, public schools have got to operate. Senator Vanstone keeps on maintaining that the public school system is not delivering.

Last week, Senator Vanstone added insult to injury by stating that the statistical quirk could be because of the backgrounds of the kids that attend public schools. She said that she made the statement to focus on the fact that schools had to prepare children for life.

There is one problem background that Senator Vanstone did not bother to mention—that is, the government's own problem background, which is its lack of attention and focus on solving the youth unemployment problem. Since Mr Howard's government was elected, youth unemployment has gone up. However much we have huff and puff from Senator Vanstone about jobless statistics prior to the 1996 election, the facts are that youth unemployment was dropping under Labor and youth unemployment is rising under the coalition government. I think the government has some responsibility for preparing the economic circumstances to create jobs for school leavers in this country, and it has not done it and it is not doing it.

Senator Vanstone's arrogant disdain for the public school sector is highlighted by the inaction over the influx of extra students into grades 11 and 12 next January because of changes to the youth unemployment payment regime—that is, the common youth allowance. In a Senate estimates committee last week, she was given the rounds of the kitchen. She admitted that she had not given much thought at all to the requirements of the 27,000 grades 11 and 12 school children her department predicts will remain at school. Parents and students who might be affected by this particular measure from July next year will make the decision about whether the students should remain at school this coming January. That is only five months away.

Senator Vanstone had not carried out a state by state breakdown as to where the greatest educational need would be and where these young Australians might need extra assistance—with further attention to literacy, numeracy, vocational counselling, job placement and the like. We hear that many of these young people do not want to be in schools because, as senators know, they are uncomfortable in a teaching situation. Some of them do not have the skills to fit the requirements for grades 11 and 12. Many are young people who will need special help and, if they are not catered for properly, they are possibly likely to disrupt classrooms.

How much extra will it cost? Of course, Senator Vanstone does not know. What programs will be put in place? Senator Vanstone has not thought about it. She has not got a clue. What we in opposition say is that this attitude from Senator Vanstone and her junior minister is one of almost criminal neglect.

We know the department has thought about the problem, because of a cabinet submission that has been obtained by the opposition. Several measures costing up to $140 million were supposed to be presented by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Minister Kemp, and Minister Vanstone in that flaky exercise which was the underattended cabinet meeting held on 5 August, when everyone was either on holidays or off crook.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or couldn't be bothered.

—Or could not be bothered going. But the department recommended the expansion of the jobs pathway program; extra vocational training programs; the introduction of the students' intervention program based on Labor's students at risk program, which was previously abolished by Senator Vanstone; and an expansion of the student traineeship foundation, which was a 1994 Labor initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister Vanstone and Minister Kemp, fighting with each other of course all the time, have been silent on these proposed programs. In question time yesterday the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, brushed aside our inquiries on these issues. From the tenor of Senator Vanstone's responses to Senate estimates and in the Senate chamber, the suggestions from her department have been utterly ignored.

Instead of getting on with the job of solving the mounting problems in state schools that have been caused by Senator Vanstone, she spends valuable ministerial time in bagging the system which she is in charge of, bagging the system for which she has responsibility and calling for the system to perform better, while she cuts back on funding, while she chops resources and, from January next year, adds 27,000 more young people, who may not be suited to it, to grade 11 and 12 education.

Single-handedly, she has insulted the higher education system. We called previously for the Prime Minister to get rid of this incompetent minister, to replace her with someone else, and our request for action to the Prime Minister still stands. She is responsible for single‐handed alienation of the public school sector in 1997 through her inept handling of her portfolio. It increases the urgency on Mr Howard to sack her now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President, I was just attending to my phone.
—That would be right. You wouldn't be attending to your duties.
—Thank you, Senator, for that interjection. It is helpful if people place their phone back on the hook when they have concluded speaking.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only conclude that Senator Faulkner has not in fact looked at the whole speech in relation to his comments. He presents the speech as one attacking the government school system. He knows full well that this government is absolutely committed to choice in schools, to a strong and vibrant school system and, equally, to a strong and vibrant non‐government school system—and, for the those parents that are able to have a choice, to have that choice unhindered by government regulation.
He says that the import of the speech that I made a couple of weeks ago was, I think in his terminology, `to bag government schools'. Apparently, this is how one does it. One does it by saying:
That is not to say that some government schools are not already achieving excellent results.
Then you might pick one and say:
Salisbury High School here in Adelaide—
where the speech was made—
is one such school. I understand that they have an employment rate of something like 98 per cent for their students.
I go on:
This can only be described as excellent.

Apparently, picking out a government school, nominating the record that they have in providing what their students need, pointing out that they have a 98 per cent achievement rate and describing it as excellent is somehow engaging in a process of bagging government schools.

I invite anybody who wants to make a decision as to this government's attitude to read the whole speech. I heard Senator Faulkner say, `Lies, damn lies and statistics'. I could equally have said, `Whole speeches and simple excerpts taken from', and could have asked him to go back and have a good look.

I point out the words: `This can only be described as excellent'. I was picking out a government school—not picking out a particular private school—as the example I wanted to use of a school that could provide everything that its students needed. If that is bagging government schools, I am a loss for words.

But I went on and pointed that the need to put vocational education back into schools is very important. Earlier in the speech, I had highlighted the changing nature of the young labour force. It is a very diminished labour force, because young Australians are less and less choosing to leave school without any additional training to look for the ever decreasing number of unskilled jobs. But that only highlights that, for those students who want to do that, vocational training is very important to equip them for the choice in life that they want to make.

I went on to highlight that we are working with the states in respect of this matter. I pointed out that under the arrangements of the Victorian minister for training, Phil Honeywood, 8,000 young Australians are studying vocational subjects at school which count towards their final years and an apprenticeship or a traineeship.

I went on from that to indicate that the vocational training in schools need not be a lock‐off for students and that, as I understand it, 24 per cent of students undertaking vocational subjects at school in Victoria last year have continued on to university. I pointed out that that shows that vocational education need not block students out. That demonstrates the efforts of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training to put vocational training back into schools, particularly government schools.

I went on to mention Minister Colin Barnett in Western Australia, who has also recognised the need for schools to have closer links with industry to cater for the needs of its students; and that if you have more students who want to go into the work force, if a higher proportion of your students want to do that, then obviously you have to cater for them. Mr Barnett recognises that in Western Australia and is doing an excellent job of highlighting the importance of school to work transition with the development of multipurpose campuses. These campuses bring together schools, training providers and nearby businesses—in other words, schools providing what students want.

After about two weeks of coverage on this speech I am beginning to wonder if, irrespective of what is said in this, somebody is going to try to say that this government is anti government schools. That is not the case. I have repeated that time and time again. Minister Kemp has repeated it time and time again and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has repeated it time and time again.
The opposition can keep dragging this cat out of the bag, hoping to have a further media beat‐up of this issue—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been reading any of the editorials? You got a colossal pasting, and you deserved it.

—Thank you, Senator. You have had your opportunity. The reasoning behind the speech, the purposes of the speech were to emphasise the government's clear intention to support both government and private schools.

BREAK.PARA: As I have said, the full‐time youth labour market is now less than half what it was in the 1980s. Social and economic changes mean that the jobs that once were there for young people as entry points no longer exist. Even when the labour market as a whole picks up, the kinds of jobs that did exist will not return; they will be different sorts of jobs. The challenge now is to continue the increased emphasis on vocation and education in schools, and to establish links between schools and employers. I know that in schools where a high proportion of students is undertaking vocational education, current methods of university entrance selection can often present barriers to those particular students. This is an appropriate time to raise this point. I have allocated $1 million to address this issue.

I believe that university assessment based on a single TER score is unfairly disadvantaging some students. It is very important that, when students make their choices in senior secondary school, they keep their options open. They need to be able to choose vocational subjects without feeling that they are closing off the opportunity to go to university. I also highlighted the importance of establishing links between schools and employers so that students can get a feel for what employers are looking for and employers can get to know young people and tap their talents.

As I have indicated, in Adelaide—my own state—I pointed to the example of Salisbury High. I used that as the pinnacle example of what a school can do. Despite picking a government school as the best example around to show what can be done to cater for students, despite quoting its record of 98 per cent, despite pointing out that that is an excellent result and despite having time and time again used a government school as an example of excellent provision of what students need, some people still try to characterise both me and this government as being opposed to government schools.

So I will take the opportunity in the few minutes remaining to me to do what senators opposite should be doing if they are genuinely in support of government schools rather than simply trying to distort speeches for political purposes. They should be quoting examples of where government schools are doing so very well. There are plenty of examples of government schools which are doing very well. For example, I turn to Upwey High School in Victoria. I am advised that all but three of last year's 138 year 12 school leavers are now employed or have gone on to further education. That bears repeating: at Upwey High School in Victoria, all but three of last year's 138 year 12 school leavers are now employed or have gone on to further education. Upwey High School is a non‐selective neighbourhood school in an outer suburb of Melbourne.

Those results, like those at Salisbury High, the other government school I referred to, are outstanding. They reflect very well on the leadership of the school, the staff and the community. Bradfield College in New South Wales has had similar results. It opens six days a week, and builds on a unique partnership between TAFE and school programs. Students can get TAFE qualifications, get the benefit of industry training and complete secondary school at the same time. I have already covered the operations of Salisbury High School. These are very exciting developments in the government school system.

Rather than simply look at individual schools, I will look at some international benchmarking. At the third international mathematics study Australia did very well. In science, out of 24 countries, only Korea was ranked ahead of Australia. In mathematics, only four countries were ranked ahead of Australia. That would not be possible if we did not have a strong excellent government school system. It is a vital part of our national infrastructure, and our commitment to is unequivocal. If senators opposite want to protect, enhance and promote government schools, why don't they come in here and share examples with us as we share examples with them of just how good government schools can be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue here today is the failure of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) to understand and to defend public schools. Whilst there might have been a bit of a turnaround this afternoon, I think what we have to do today is ask ourselves what is going on when the most vehement attacks on our government education system are being delivered by the government itself. We should ask ourselves why it is that our two education ministers are capable of such muddled thinking on almost all issues related to education.
—Have you read the whole speech?
—I would encourage—
—Yes or no? No is the answer.

—I respond to Senator Patterson's repeated interjections by saying I have, indeed, read the whole speech. I intend to quote from quite a bit of it, so please bear with me. Senator Vanstone encourages us all to read the speech, and I do as well. Mind you, my own view is that it could well have been used as an exercise in clear thinking for year 8 or year 9. I am quite sure that most of those students would do better at constructing logical arguments.

SPEECH.PARA: I will get back to the question of the assault on schools. We are, I think, accustomed in this country to state governments attacking teacher unions—it is usually teacher unions. But I do not think I can recall any time in Australia's history when government schools—and I emphasise that it is government schools we are talking about here—have been blamed for everything from unemployment to withholding information from parents, failing to be competitive and preparing students for university or not preparing students for university, as the case may be on occasion.
The minister's speech to the American Australian Chamber of Commerce this month gave the message that schools play a critical role in preparing young people for life. The minister said:
They are not TER factories preparing some for universities and giving less attention to others.

Today we have heard quite a lot about the problems with TER scores and their irrelevance. As an aside, I think we all wait with some trepidation for what the announcement will be on how TER scores will be replaced. We also know that not all students go to university, and that the overall percentage of students from private schools going on to university is higher in private schools than it is in government schools. Nobody would be surprised by that information.

Most people understand the close relationship between income levels and both retention rates and university entry. Time and time again, studies have shown this. This is the reason why we have a publicly funded education system in this country. I would like to remind the minister and honourable senators of that. The handful of government schools whose intake is selective on the basis of results, for instance, also show that high correlation between ability, family background of tertiary education and success at university entry. We also know that the more prestigious private schools with the highest TER scores actively encourage those students who are unlikely to get entry into university from even participating in those final years in the first place.

I would have thought that the minister's remarks about entry should have been more particularly directed at private schools. I would have thought that the reason the government this year gave so generously—I think it was $1,730 per student—for vocational education in private schools was that it was private schools which had to be encouraged to address the question of vocational education. That is what the minister said at the time. This windfall—which, of course, we found out does not have to be accounted for in the same way as it does in government schools—was, according to her, given as an incentive to private schools to broaden their current focus on university entrance. There was no mention of that in her address to the chamber. What she did say was:
. . . putting vocational education back into schools gives students work related skills. It is something that my portfolio is encouraging.

Senator Patterson will note that I am again quoting from the speech. Minister, I think the senator and our government schools would like to know just how you are encouraging that vocational education. The minister's logic on unemployment is, however, somewhat more interesting. She says:

For boys who completed year 12 in 1995, twice as many boys from government schools chose to enter the workforce than boys from non-government schools. However, of more interest is that 35% of boys from government schools entering the workforce, that is, leaving school to look for work, couldn't get a job.

She goes on to triumphantly announce that this means that 14 per cent of all boys finishing at a government school were unemployed. I have to say that there are many parts of Australia where 14 per cent unemployment levels for young people would be very welcome indeed. In the Fairfield‐Liverpool area in New South Wales, the unemployment rate for boys aged 15 to 24 is 24.1 per cent. In Geelong in my home state, it is 20.8 per cent. In the west Adelaide region, the figure is 21.8 per cent.

The real point that the minister wants to make is the fact that non-government schools do so much better. Only two per cent of boys from non-government schools are unemployed. We do not know quite where that figure comes from. But even accepting that it is an ABS estimate and that it is accurate, what exactly lies behind this expose?

In November last year when the government's states grants bill opened the way for the expansion of the private school system, paid for by cuts to the state system, we pointed out that this represented a very serious lack of commitment to public education. We also pointed out that the government's attacks on government schools were part of a very obvious campaign to encourage all those parents who could possibly afford to do so to take their children from state schools and put them into private schools.

BREAK.PARA: Government schools in every state in this country are getting fewer resources, less choice in curriculum and, as the recent Senate education committee found, they are having to rely more and more on fees and sponsorship to pay for the most basic education facilities. We pointed out that the government was allowing its ideology of privilege over equity, of private over public, to threaten the system of education in this country, and we stand by that.

If this notion of education were some kind of minor initiative of the previous government, perhaps we could understand Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp's eagerness to demolish that system before our very eyes. But it is not some minor initiative. It is not some bright idea which did not work. I would go so far as to say that Australians believe that education is the most important public service that the government has responsibility for. You would expect a government that is there to act in the best interests of all Australians to support and defend and enhance the system of education which at the present time serves 70 per cent of Australian families. The Democrats would be very happy to see the government identify any deficiencies in education and to begin to remedy those. But is that what we are seeing? I do not think so.

I want to touch quickly on the question of literacy. Senator Vanstone said in her speech that `the lack of literacy and numeracy skills among our people is of particular concern,' and she links this to the question of unemployment yet again. This is a favourite subject of Dr Kemp's as well. The only response to this high level of concern is to reduce funding for literacy by nine per cent in real terms from previous budgets.

The other part of the government's strategy so far is to test children endlessly and to publish those results. I think the idea is that students and teachers will pull themselves up by their bootstraps, driven by competition—presumably from other schools. This is something of a departure from the previous line, which was that our curriculum was too crowded—any excuse it seems.

Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp lurch from one ill-informed statement to the next on this question of literacy. In many ways, this reminds me of the intemperate and ignorant outpourings of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). Fear is a very powerful motivator. Whether you are frightening people by telling them that we are going to be swamped by Asians or whether you are doing so by saying that children in government schools are 10 times more likely to be unemployed—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I have read Senator Vanstone's speech, and I must say that the conclusion I have come to is that the urgency motion is fundamentally misconceived. Senator Allison seems to be confusing destination rates with the unemployment rate, whereas the speech of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, addressed the importance of making both government and non‐government schools more relevant to cater for the needs of all students. That is the fundamental message of the speech. To try to draw any other message from the speech is not only mischievous; it is simply disproved by the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: This government is totally committed to the excellent government school system we have in Australia. I would like to take this opportunity to put on the record some of the initiatives and achievements of the government school system that this government and the minister support.

Firstly, referring to resources for schools, the federal government has provided a sound basis for supporting schools to meet these challenges. The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act passed last year guarantees funding for schools for the next four years to the tune of more than $14 billion over the period 1997‐2000. The Commonwealth budget papers for 1996‐97 show that funding for schools is estimated to increase by an average of just over four per cent a year.

The government's funding priorities reflect the importance we place on both literacy and numeracy. State and territory education ministers agreed in March this year to the national literacy and numeracy plan which will ensure that every child commencing school in 1998 will achieve minimum acceptable literacy and numeracy standards—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you fund it then?
—and that student performance will be monitored against national benchmarks, Senator Carr.
—Where's the money?

—A major policy initiative of this government is to provide all young people with strong foundation literacy skills. The Commonwealth Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, has worked collaboratively with state and territory ministers for education to put in place a comprehensive national plan to improve literacy and numeracy skills for all young Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth makes a significant financial contribution to schools of more than $3 billion a year—specifically, $153 million a year through the literacy program. The literacy grants to schools will provide $579 million over 1997‐2000 to be paid to government and non‐government schools and education authorities who are able to use funds in appropriate ways to achieve the broad objectives of the program.

The government takes literacy of our young people seriously. Last year it undertook the first national survey for 16 years of the literacy achievements of Australian school children. The results of the survey are shortly to be released and will provide for the very first time a national picture of literacy achievement which will clearly show where efforts need to be directed if we are to achieve the national goal for literacy.

The federal government is providing a package of funding measures to promote effective and reliable pathways for students from schooling to employment—surely one of the most important initiatives of this government. Funds are to be used to support programs for school students which combine study towards a senior secondary certificate with nationally recognised, accredited vocational education and training. The government is committed to reforms that ensure that school leavers are better prepared for continuing training and further education, or for entering the work force, whatever they are capable of doing.

At the March meeting the Commonwealth sought the support of state education ministers for a commitment to re‐examine the roles of schools, both government and non‐government, to achieve the goal that all students should find schooling relevant and valuable and that schooling leads to further education, training or full and productive employment. This would include removing barriers for schools to become employment service providers, providing incentives for all schools to develop strategic alliances with local employment service providers. Each year for four calendar years $20 million will be provided to state training authorities for allocation to school authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty million all up.

—Funds will be available for the development and delivery of programs which contribute to the expansion of vocational education in schools measured against set benchmarks. Priorities include the development of school‐based apprenticeships and traineeship arrangements, support for innovative activities and the consolidation of projects which have shown initial success.
—With no money.
—Senator Carr, you have just heard that there is $80 million in total provided for these programs. Don't be so silly.

SPEECH.PARA: Funds have been allocated to government and non‐government school systems to be used primarily to support activities at the school level. Schools, or clusters of schools, will access funding through their relevant education authority or school system.

The government is providing $23 million over four financial years to facilitate the implementation of vocational education and training in schools, including supporting greater participation of industry, vocational and educational training personnel in the delivery of these courses. I could go on and on with initiatives such as the jobs pathway program which was introduced in September to make the transition from school to work to help young people gain access to an employment broker in their area.

The Commonwealth is not favouring either school sector; the government's policy is about parents being able to choose the school that best suits their children, and providing optimum opportunities for all children in the education system. All these initiatives confirm the Commonwealth's commitment to ensure quality education for all children, whether in the government or non‐government sector.

The government is on track with its agenda for schooling that will meet the demands of parents and the broader community for the best quality education that will prepare our students for an exciting and satisfying future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an urgency motion before the Senate which calls upon the Senate to acknowledge:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, to understand and defend public schools as revealed by her unprecedented attack on Australia's public education system in a recent speech to the American Australian Chamber of Commerce.
At this point I remind the Senate of what it was that the minister said. She said:

In total, the ABS estimates that of school leavers at the end of year 12 who end up being unemployed the proportion from government schools is ten times greater than the proportion from non‐government schools.
She went on to say:
The bottom line is that for school leavers, private schools have beaten unemployment.

What nonsense! What an appalling, extraordinary attack upon the public education system! What is so appalling about that is that it in fact articulates the private views of this government. For the first time we have seen it out in the open.

It is not just the first time in the life of this government; this is the first time this century that we have seen any government make a public declaration of the private prejudices of the Tory party in this country. For the first time, we have seen this notion that the government does not have a moral obligation to ensure that there is a universal public education service of the highest quality available to all Australians. This viewpoint is thoroughly deplorable. It implies that everything which is privately owned is good and that which is publicly owned is bad. We have a picture of this Tory government which they actively seek reassurance for on a constant basis. This is a backward‐looking government which seeks to gather information to support such an outdated notion, to support this spurious claim.

What they seek to do is to provide data no matter how spurious that data is. The minister is putting the proposition, through the American Chamber of Commerce, that, no matter what damage is done to the reputations of the public institutions of this country, it does not matter, so long as it advances the narrow political agenda that this minister is seeking to promote.

The minister has sought to attack the overwhelming majority of the constituents that she should be representing; that is, the overwhelming majority of Australians who actually participate in the public education institutions of this country. In fact, what we have from this minister is ignorance and contempt. She has relied upon unpublished and qualified ABS data, advice which her own department has told her is not up to scratch, which she should not use in the way she has. Try as she might today to backtrack from her deplorable attitudes, we see her prejudice which is clearly against public education. We see before us a minister who is exposed as being ignorant and offensive.

The government, in which this minister is purporting to represent the interests of education in this country, is relying on the time honoured defence that the minister has been misrepresented, and she has done that again and again here. She has to come in here to apologise on a regular basis. How long before we see yet another apology about her offensive remarks, which we all know have been widely and roundly condemned?

They have been condemned by Liberal politicians themselves. I quote the ACT Liberal MLA, Louise Littlewood who has written that she found Senator Vanstone's remarks `not only offensive but extremely shallow'. We have seen Judith Hancock, the Chairwoman of the Association of Heads of Independent Schools of Australia, describe Senator Vanstone's comments as `unfortunate and poorly advised'. Duncan Stalker, the National President of the Australian Secondary Principals Association, has rejected Senator Vanstone's comments as `statistically inaccurate and absolute nonsense'. He went on to say:
I am sick and tired of the school system which is admired throughout the world being blamed by the Government for their own lack of planning and mismanagement.
Parents and citizens associations right around the country have expressed outrage. The New South Wales Parents and Citizens Federation has said:

Senator Vanstone clearly does not believe that she represents the 70% of Australian children who seek their education in government school systems and she is prepared to compromise their life opportunities in the pursuit of her clear desire to advantage the private sector.

The Minister of Education in New South Wales has plainly pointed out the obvious fact that this is the most savage attack upon one of the nation's great institutions and systems of schooling. He stated that she has `undermined community confidence in the system of schooling that the vast majority of Australians attend'. Dick Shearman of the Independent Education Union has made the point that:

Children from privileged backgrounds who go to elite private schools live in areas of low unemployment . . . Children in Catholic schools may have equal problems finding work—depending on where they live. You can't say it's because there is something wrong with the education.

That is quite clearly what the minister has sought to imply in this speech. Senator Vanstone conveniently fails to address the fundamental issue of the relationship between social class, social privilege and social disadvantage. Those are the fundamental principles which she has failed to address. She seeks to rely on the rhetoric of choice. She seeks to imply, somehow or another, that there should be equality, while she promotes inequality.

BREAK.PARA: I am somewhat reminded, whenever I look at Senator Vanstone and her junior minister, Dr Kemp, of George Orwell who brought to us the whole notion of newspeak.
