We have from this minister the concept of doublethink. The minister seeks to hold two contradictory ideas simultaneously. She tries to present to us the notion that she accepts both of them. What you see is a minister who has quite clearly misunderstood the very principles on which she is supposed to govern; that is, a commitment to defend public education and to defend the important role played by government in promoting public education and the critical role it plays in terms of our society as a whole.

The minister calls upon statistics which ACER has clearly demonstrated have failed to take into account three fundamental principles, the first of which is that a smaller proportion of students from non‐government schools seek employment after year 12, the rest going directly into further education. The second point which she has failed to acknowledge is that student cohorts in government and non‐government school systems differ in the ways in which they influence employment outcomes; that is, in terms of their socioeconomic status. The third point which she fails to acknowledge is that there are marked regional variations in unemployment rates in terms of government and non‐government schools.

This is a deplorable attitude which is being expressed by this government in its approach to education. The minister says that there is more money spent in education. What she fails to point out to the Senate—a failure that her own department has acknowledged in submissions to the Senate committees—is that some $270 million is being cut from the budget in terms of moneys that otherwise would have been spent as a result of the direct policies of this government. If you include the $400 million that is taken away from the states through the general assistance grants, the figure is much larger. This government has quite clearly engaged not only in doublespeak but in doublethought. The government has failed to live up to its fundamental obligations to this society.
For a generation, perhaps throughout this century, we have heard all governments express this view:

Commonwealth Government financial support for schooling has so far been about providing opportunities for all young Australians which ensure that they have life chances not fettered by the circumstances of their birth.

We are seeing this government moving away from those fundamental principles of a democratic society, moving away from those fundamental principles of a pluralist society. It is moving to a new set of values, which say that choice should be exercised no matter what the cost and no matter what the consequences. What it is moving away from is the normal principles of a universally high quality education system that values access and equity and inclusiveness.

What you have is, in fact, an understanding by this government that for them choice means that, if you have the money, you get what you want. If you have not, you do without. What you have, I might suggest to you, is as a supporter of parent choice once stated. This was published in the Review of the New Schools Policy in April last year by McKinnon. The supporter made this point:

. . . respect for parents' rights in education cannot, however, be pursued without regard for the claims of other values . . . The state may set conditions for the conduct of formal education not only to protect the individual rights of children, but to ensure the effective transmission of the knowledge and skills on which the common political, economic and cultural life of the whole society depends . . .

This is a responsibility that this minister has failed to acknowledge and has failed to understand. It is a fundamental principle. We see now, under this government, ads being put in the paper by the Smith Family. The headline reads `Amy's future would be bright—if she weren't too ashamed to go to school'. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to start off by saying that Senator Carr is living in the 1940s and 1950s. I presume that that is where he has been left with his left-wing Labor views: that members of the coalition think that everything that is private is good and everything that is public is bad. That is the old rhetoric of the 1940s and 1950s loony left, and we have Senator Carr still living it. You find that the two major speakers, Senator Carr and Senator Faulkner, are from the Left. Where are the Right? They are not there. They do not want to take on this issue. They are reliving the old debate about the private school system versus the public school system that was going on with the DOGS and other issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I could have predicted what Senator Allison was going to come in and say. If you look at her speech on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill, you know exactly what she thinks about private schools. This is what she said when speaking on this bill:

If you want to go down in history as being part of a government which places the interests of small, fundamentalist and extreme schools at the expense of Australia's public schooling system, then by all means vote for this bill.

You can imagine the reaction of the Jewish, Anglican, Christian community and Lutheran schools and some of the small Catholic schools that I visit. They were flabbergasted that in federal parliament they were being depicted as `fundamentalist' and `extreme'. We knew exactly what she was going to say. That just puts on the record and reminds people of where Senator Allison was coming from about private schools. So she should not come in here and say that. It is the pot calling the kettle black. It was totally predictable what she would say.

What Senator Vanstone has said over and over again, both inside and outside this chamber, is that schools, irrespective of whether they are private or public, need to be training young people for life, work and vocation. She has argued over and over again that a significant proportion of young people at both state and non‐government schools will not go to university and that some schools were letting young people down by not giving them vocational training.

Senator Vanstone has also been very critical about the ideological push by Labor of downgrading and closing schools which were vocationally oriented. She said that gone are the days when young people could leave school at 14, get a job in a bank and work their way up to being the managing director of the bank. Those days are gone. She is also saying that gone are the days when it was okay to educate young people in some of the manual trades, that jobs have changed and that IT, hospitality and other service industries are the areas where young people need training.

When we came into government, Labor had a scheme, the jobs pathway guarantee scheme, which was a pilot scheme. They had budgeted $2 million for this scheme. Had they begun to realise that there was a problem with vocational education? Do you know how much they had spent in their 1995‐96 budget? They had spent only $0.5 million. They had not got into it. It was in disarray and was disorganised. Minister Vanstone organised the restructuring of that program to tackle its shortcomings. She expanded the program at a sustainable rate, providing $2.9 million last financial year and $3 million this financial year. It was in disarray.

Senator Allison said that she had read Senator Vanstone's speech—and I believe her—but we did not hear one of the people on the other side say that they had read the whole of her speech. The emphasis in her speech was about the need to get schools to respond to the needs of their students, and that we were working hard to achieve that. The upgrading of the jobs pathway guarantee scheme was one of them.

In her speech, Senator Vanstone did not pull out a private school as an example. The only school she pulled out as an example was a state school in South Australia—a school that was achieving the sorts of goals that she expects of all schools, whether they be state or non‐government. She highlighted the achievement of one state school, because it was from her state. She did not choose to highlight a private school.

As she said, how can you stand here and condemn her and say that she was slamming all government schools? In fact, the very example she used was of a school that was achieving the aims that she wants to achieve; that is, getting young people job ready, being flexible, building vocational training into the school program and building in a system that does not lock in students. You need to leave open as many doors as possible so that, if they train down one pathway towards university, they should be able to then go into vocational education or vice versa.

Isn't that what everyone wants for their children? The doors should be left open so that they can go into higher education or vocational training. That is the sort of flexibility Senator Vanstone is expecting in the schools and is working towards. She was not about damning government schools. As she pointed out, she was not in any way underestimating the dedication of people who are responsible for the education of about 70 per cent of our young people. I reiterate, she pulled out one example and that example was of a state school.

As I said, if they had bothered to read the whole speech, which they did not bother to do, and had not just relied on media reports and a single quote, they would have realised that the focus of the minister's speech was on the role of vocational education. She pointed out that the youth labour market had undergone permanent change and she did not blame schools for current levels of unemployment. If the blame lies anywhere, it lies at the feet of those on the other side who have the gall to pull us up for what we are doing about young people and what we are doing about overcoming the legacy that Labor left us. They left us a legacy of entrenched youth unemployment. They left us a legacy of the apprenticeship scheme in shambles. They left us a legacy of no hope for young people.

What Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp, the two ministers, are doing is to inject hope, to inject into both state and non‐government schools a system which responds to the real needs of young people in terms of vocational education and training, towards post‐secondary education. That is what she is on about. She was not about slamming government schools, and to construe her speech in that way is totally unacceptable and wrong. I would have thought that the opposition could have focused on some of the positive things that are happening rather than carping, as they do all the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for this debate has concluded.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Faulkner's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of my visit to Japan to participate in the Conference of Presiding Officers of Upper Houses and to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Japanese House of Councillors which took place from 19 to 22 May 1997.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate nominating Senator Bob Collins to be a member of the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust.

INTERJECT.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948, the Senate appoints Senator Bob Collins as a trustee to serve on the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust on and from this day in place of Senator Colston.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives returning the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997, acquainting the Senate that the House insists on disagreeing to amendments Nos 1 to 8 and 10 to 68 inclusive insisted upon by the Senate in the bill, and requesting the reconsideration of the bill in respect of the said amendments.
Ordered that consideration of the message in committee of the whole be an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Consideration resumed from 25 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the minister and the officers from the tax department. They had a meeting with my adviser this morning on the audiovisual services. I have to say publicly that we are not totally satisfied and full responsibility lies with you, Senator Kemp, if the definition at some stage proves to be some expansion of the sales tax net. We are still struggling to identify what an audiovisual service is, given the lack of definition. But I will not be pursuing that issue any further at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1997
Bill agreed to.
Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 reported with amendments; Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Kemp) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 18 June, on motion by Senator Minchin:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 seeks to adjust for price movements the 1998 amounts payable to higher education institutions under the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 for superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals and special capital projects and to the open learning organisation. This bill seeks to give effect to the restructuring and the rationalisation plans announced in the budget. It introduces a discount of 25 per cent for up-front HECS payments of some $500 or more from 1988. It also seeks to streamline arrangements for student debts under HECS or the open learning deferred payment schemes.

BREAK.PARA: On the surface this is a bill that merely adds an additional $9.6 million for 1998 on current legislated amounts. But the truth of the matter is that it hides the true impact of this government's unprecedented assaults on our nation's university sector. It hides the savage attack on the rights of thousands of Australians, both young and old, who seek to gain the benefits of a university education.

I see Senator Kemp has come into the chamber and I have no doubt that he will be looking with some mirth at the predicament of Senator Vanstone, Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, in these difficult times. I am sure that family commitments here would not override his fundamental loyalty to cabinet and government.

Senator Kemp would also be only too well aware that this bill has to be viewed in light of the budget decisions taken both last year and of course this year. In last year's budget the government announced that it was cutting $624 million from the operating grants of universities, $215 million from discretionary funds of universities, and $1.13 billion in savings as a result of its various savings measures that it was seeking to make as a result of the changes to its HECS arrangements.

Last year's budget dealt a savage blow to education—a blow which could have lessened if this minister had been prepared to stand up and defend her portfolio and the interests of education within the ERC rather than kowtowing to the destructive demands of the various economic ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: it is appropriate that it be a free ranging debate but we know Senator Carr is a bit bitter having been dumped again today. That is no reason, Senator Carr, not to stick to the facts. I would urge you, Senator Carr, to stick to the facts rather than making wild unsubstantiated assertions.
—There is no point of order.

—What the minister would be aware of is that the fundamental fact in this debate is that the cuts to higher education can only be viewed as a damning indictment of the incompetence of the minister in a government that has absolutely no commitment to social equality, to the rights of ordinary citizens or to the obligations for the future development of this country.

BREAK.PARA: This year the minister promised that there would be no bad news for education in the budget. Amongst the platter of bad news it has been revealed that a further one per cent cut to the operating grants would apply in the year 2000, which is a further $47.3 million taken away from universities. The minister has tried to claim that the savings were small. Remember she lectured the vice chancellors that they could not be expected to be immune from expenditure cuts. She is now describing these cuts as `the removal of promised growth in the forward estimates' and calling Labor's forward estimates `not a credible base against which education expenditure can be measured'.

It was the basis on which universities were asked to plan. It was the basis on which universities were told the future growth would be funded. But, of course, this is a minister that overturns those commitments. There have indeed been massive cuts to the education sector. No matter how she tries to dress it up, she cannot hide that fundamental fact. The talk of the forward estimates brings me to this fundamental point: it highlights a great concern to the universities—that the stability of funding and the future basis of planning is dependent upon stability of funding and the commitments of government actually being honoured. This is a government that has failed that basic test.

Labor recognised this need and indeed legislated for the funding of universities to be on a rolling triennium basis. Before the election, the coalition committed itself to continue the rolling triennium funding arrangements, but this promise went the way of those of the operating grants and of not changing the HECS arrangements midstream. It was quite simply dumped by this government.

In Labor's last budget in 1995, it legislated funding for universities to cover 1996, 1997 and 1998. In the two budgets since the election, however, there has been no move by the coalition government to provide the base funding beyond 1998. This raises the question about what other unpleasantness this government has in store for the higher education sector in this country. Can we expect that the West review will in fact bring forward new measures and new acts of vandalism to be committed against the higher education sector? Will it be used as yet another excuse to find various budget measures to further hack into the higher education sector in this country?

This is an extremely worrying time for universities and for university administrators who are trying to plan ahead to cope with the already drastic cuts that have been announced. Clearly there is a lack of certainty and a lack of clarity about what the government actually stands for in relation to the forward projections and where the money will come from to fund the necessities of the higher education sector. But what we have in this bill is a measure by this government to rationalise, to cover up and to try to put a bandaid over the enormous scars and cuts that have been left by this government.

Funding cuts and a lack of planning provisions are forcing universities to change their priorities away from the quality of the education provision towards the need to raise money; turning universities away from being education centres into being businesses. Bit by bit, they are losing their status as public institutions serving the educational needs of this country. They are increasingly becoming privatised enterprises intent upon building profits. Universities are increasingly acting as big business and their need for funds subsumes all other priorities, to the detriment of Australian students who they are supposed to be serving.

Since the coalition came to office we have seen some 2,000 jobs lost in this sector. Tutorials have begun to disappear and have been replaced by so‐called optional study sessions for which universities can and do charge. We have seen the recent decision of the University of New South Wales to close the St George campus and to close the teacher education campus. We have seen Ballarat University merge with the School of Mines. We have seen faculties being shrunk and courses eliminated.

The chair of the government's own review, Mr West, has acknowledged that funding cuts had already hurt universities. The Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee, in its submission to the West review, called for an increase in government funding for higher education of over 20 per cent. The Business‐Higher Education Round Table, which includes the head of many of Australia's leading companies, warned in its submission to that review:

Without a national vision and sufficient investment in our higher education system, Australia and today's young Australians are likely to be marginalised as the region moves towards higher living standards and more advanced social and political structures.
The round table members went on to say:

Institutions are struggling to find investment capital for new technologies and teaching materials, to restructure their physical and staff resources to meet new demands. A significant increase in institutional funding to assist in this restructuring and reinvigorating process is needed and justified. Government funding will have to provide the major source.

Certainly the government is clearly not listening to such views. Whilst universities are struggling to meet new challenges, the government of the day is blithely marching ahead with major funding cuts, oblivious to and unconcerned about the potential harm to this country's future.

In that context, the 1997‐98 budget and this bill bring no comfort whatsoever. The government announced in the budget that it would provide $26 million over four years to help universities to restructure and rationalise. This is of course code for what it is really trying to do, and that is to call upon the universities to cope with massive funding cuts.

Why is this amount not reflected in the additional expenditure provided by this bill? Because even the rationalisation money is offset by yet another expenditure cut, the ending of the Commonwealth industry places scheme. The CIPS scheme is a highly successful program in encouraging industry investment in higher education. By 1999, CIPS would have been supporting about 4,700 full‐time university places Australia wide with a large number concentrated at Charles Sturt, Deakin and Swinburne universities. This was supposed to be a budget for the regions, but it has been bad news for regional universities like Charles Sturt where some 200 jobs are likely to be lost as a result of the ending of the CIPS program.

The regional and newer universities have been hit hard by this government's decision to allow full up‐front fees for Australian undergraduates. The `sandstone' universities, which can trade on their reputation, at least in the short term, are tying up their fees option as quickly as they can. They are trying to do it to provide additional sources of funding which have been lost from government sources.
Professor Gavin Brown, the Vice‐Chancellor of the University of Sydney, said on Sydney radio earlier this year:
It's the only mechanism left to fill the huge funding gap which has been bequeathed to us all by Amanda Vanstone.

I remind the Senate that recently the RMIT in Melbourne also introduced up‐front fees. Again, the vice‐chancellor is quoted as saying that they had no choice in the matter because they had to fill the funding gap left by this government. What you see is a university sector in complete chaos with occupations, demonstrations and a return to the period of the past when there was no security, no sense of quality emerging and no sense of national leadership. This government is always looking backwards, and this is yet another case.

For other universities, the outlook has been even more bleak. A bleak future for universities equals a similarly bleak one for Australian students and those whose parents do not have a spare $100,000 to spend on a full fee university education. The Vice‐Chancellor of La Trobe University, Professor Michael Osborne, has voiced a clear warning about the direction of Australian universities under the Howard government. He has predicted that the ability to pay will carry greater weight than academic merit for university enrolments, resulting in a fall in the quality of education.

The nation's largest university, Monash University, like so many others, has no faith that this government will reverse its funding cuts or provide funding security for the future. Monash University has just developed a five‐year plan that includes $20 million per year to be raised from fee‐paying Australian undergraduate students. We see in that plan that there are in fact fewer places available for Victorian students—domestic students—as the university swings away its resources to try to tap into what it sees as a lucrative Asian market.

The driving force behind the plans of Monash University is not the quality of service it can provide to Australian students but rather the need to expand its income by 60 per cent from overseas students on top of the $20 million from the fee‐paying Australian students. Monash developed this plan to reduce its reliance upon federal government funding from the current 50 per cent of operating revenue to 40 per cent by the year 2002. This is clearly an ominous sign for the university sector and should set alarm bells ringing for all people who believe that it is in this nation's interest to have a strong, publicly funded higher education sector.

We now see that this government is intent on creating two tiers of university access—one for the wealthy who, even if they underperform at school, can get a place at university by paying up‐front fees, and one for the others who are left out because of the way tertiary education has been wound back by this backward looking government. The University of Western Sydney has recently reported that 15 per cent of its students have now been discouraged from pursuing a university education. I noticed a report in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday which highlighted a DEETYA study that showed that 10 per cent of mature age students had in fact been discouraged as a result of the changes to the higher education contribution scheme.

By creating two tiers of university access, the Howard government is adding to the inequality and the fragmentation of our society. In May, the Anglican Social Responsibilities Committee of Melbourne called the introduction of up-front fees `a deliberate shift away from a commitment to . . . an egalitarian society'. In its submission to the West review, the church committee also said it was `almost certain that a free market in education will in time weaken faculties and/or departments and/or universities which are already relatively impoverished'.

The minister, of course, takes a different view. She has compared universities to a used car saleyard saying that some degrees are worth the price of a used Commodore. In truth, however, universities do not work effectively as an open market. Education is far more important than to be treated as a mere commodity, and this is something Mr Roderick West has noted. On 28 May this year, he was quoted in the Australian as saying:

There's no doubt about it, there's such a strong link between higher education participation and expenditure and economic and social wellbeing. So there are very compelling arguments for continuing substantial public support.

Of course, the minister had someone go around and tap him on the shoulder and made sure that those sorts of views were recanted. But I still believe that is essentially the view Mr West holds himself, that after travelling this country he understands the depth of feeling on this issue and understands the importance of public investment in higher education. The Business‐Higher Education Round Table has also said:
That foundation of national intellectual capital will continue to demand (and justify) substantial public funding.
They went on:
There is a further requirement for continued, robust government support for higher education.

Yet this government is taking us down the American path. It is seeking to introduce the user pays commercial principles and, of course, on a two-tiered social basis. This bill also introduces a 25 per cent discount for partial up-front HECS payments of $500 or more. Currently, the 25 per cent discount applies only to payments in full. This measure is separate from the 15 per cent discount which applies to voluntary payments of $500 or more on HECS debts already incurred. Labor supports this proposal.

Given that the differential HECS scheme introduced by this government of a full up-front payment for one student could represent only a partial payment for another student depending on the area of study, this would clearly be an inequitable arrangement. However, there are a few very important points to be made. One is that the cost to the government of this measure is estimated to be only $6.6 million over the next four years. The government has admitted in its description of this measure in budget paper (No. 2) that:
Although this initiative has a small cost, there are gains to the government in terms of net lending for HECS in the early years.

This tiny additional expenditure must be viewed against last year's budget cuts which saw $1.130 billion pulled out of government expenditure on HECS over the four years—a massive impost on students and one which has already had a negative impact on access for people, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds.

Further, the discount introduced by the bill favours those who already have the capacity to pay at least a $500 up-front fee. It does nothing for those who are unable to put together such a sum. This budget does nothing to reverse or change in any way the damage done in last year's budget to student access through the enormous cuts through HECS and, of course, the changes to Austudy.

The impact of increased course costs of up to 125 per cent, the lowering of the HECS payment threshold for some from $8,000 below average weekly earnings and the substantial reduced access to student income support can be seen in the fall in application of university entrants, which we have seen this year. Figures released by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs show a 3.4 per cent decline in applications Australia-wide. We have seen the massive disincentive that such measures have already applied, particularly for mature age groups.

It strikes me as extraordinary that, given this evidence, this government still insists on suggesting that the higher education sector is thriving. I suppose you could tell the students at the RMIT that the higher education sector is thriving. You could tell those who have been forced to occupy the buildings at RMIT that the higher education sector is thriving.

As a result of the measures taken by this government, you see a massive introduction of inequality. The opposition believes that there should be a second reading amendment carried by the Senate on these matters. Such an amendment may read:
. . . calls on the Senate to note that it is the opinion that a proper resource—

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On which dates from 1 January 1994 to the present has Beecroft Peninsula, Jervis Bay, been closed to the public.
(2) On which dates from 1 January 1994 to the present was Beecroft Peninsula being bombarded.

(3) (a) On which dates from 1 January 1994 to the present were non‐Australian military personnel involved in bombardment activity on Beecroft Peninsula; and (b) from which countries were those personnel.
(4) Does the Australian Government receive any payment from foreign governments for activities involving non‐Australian military personnel at Beecroft Peninsula.
(5) What is the expected future pattern of bombardment activity on the Beecroft Peninsula.
(6) Will the department be closing Beecroft Peninsula to the public on weekdays for the foreseeable future.
(7) Does the Minister consider it appropriate, considering the current process of Aboriginal reconciliation, to use sacred Aboriginal land on Beecroft Peninsula for bombing practice.

(8) Does the Minister consider it appropriate to offer sacred Aboriginal land on Beecroft Peninsula to the defence forces of other countries, such as New Zealand and the United States of America, for bombardment practice.
(9) Is the Minister aware that Beecroft Peninsula contains rare and endangered fauna species.
(10) Is the Minister aware that politicians from both the Coalition and the Australian Labor Party have promised Beecroft Peninsula to the Australian people as a national park.
(11) Is the Minister aware that the current Federal Member for Gilmore supports the gazettal of Beecroft Peninsula as a national park.
(12) Will the Minister work to have Beecroft Peninsula declared a national park.

(13) Given that the 1995 Royal Australian Navy (RAN) State of the Environment report fails to identify `protection of native fauna from bushfires' as an issue for the Jervis Bay range, is the Minister aware that the Australian Heritage Commission believes that fires may have severe adverse effects on endangered species and littoral rainforest communities on Beecroft Peninsula.

(14) (a) Have Defence Force activities caused fires on Beecroft Peninsula in the past; and (b) what assessment has been made of the impact of these fires on endangered species and on littoral rainforest communities.

(15) Given that the 1995 report fails to identify `fauna of sandy shorelines', `disturbance to bird colonies or rookeries by aircraft noise' and `emergency dumping of fuel in flight' as issues for the Jervis Bay range, do the Navy's activities at Jervis Bay and Beecroft Peninsula affect fauna of sandy shorelines, disturb bird colonies or rookeries, create noise, or involve the dumping of fuel.

(16) Will replacing the JINDAVIK target system with the JP7 Aerial Target System lead to an increased environmental impact on Beecroft Peninsula, given that JINDAVIK was used primarily on Bherwerre Peninsula.

(17) In regard to the proposed JP7 Aerial Target System: (a) what is the process for assessing and approving the system; (b) what role does Environment Australia's Environment Protection Group play in this assessment; (c) who is responsible for assessing each stage; and (d) what is the expected timetable for this process.
(18) Is the Government intending to carry out an environmental impact statement on the JP7 Aerial Target System.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Beecroft Weapons Range on Beecroft Peninsula is closed to the public for a number of reasons. These include: bombardment by naval guns firing ammunition including salvoes of high explosive and illuminant, artillery bombardment by Army field guns and howitzers firing similar ammunition types; practice bombing by military aircraft dropping dummy bombs or firing inert‐head (non‐explosive) rockets and cannon; mortar and small arms firing exercises; non‐firing exercises; Lighthouse Road maintenance; and feral animal eradication. The following information lists the dates that Beecroft Range was closed for the years 1994 to 1997.
(2) The following information lists the dates from 1 January 1994 to the present when Beecroft Peninsula was being bombarded.

1994: February: 9‐10, 14‐17, 21‐24 and 28; March: 1‐3, 7‐8, 14‐16; April: 13‐15; May: 3‐4, 10‐11 and 17‐19; June: 8‐9 and 15‐16; July: 12‐14, 19‐21 and 26; August: 24‐26 and 29‐31; September: 6‐8 and 13‐16; October: 17‐21, 25‐28 and 31; November: 2‐4, 8‐10 and 22‐23; and December: 2 and 5.
Total: Naval bombardment 44 days

TAB.TAB: Air to ground inert practice bombing 31 days.

ANSWER.PARA: Total: Naval bombardment 55 days

Total: Naval bombardment 18 days

TAB.TAB: Air to ground inert practice bombing 43 days.
