(4) Foreign military units conducting independent activities on Beecroft range are charged fees on a cost recovery basis. Fees are not charged when foreign units are conducting those activities in company with Australian Defence Force (ADF) units, as substantial training benefits for the ADF are achieved during such activities.

(5) Beecroft is in use for an average of 120 days per year. While levels of activity may increase as the Anzac Class ships enter service, it is believed that any increase beyond the 120 days would be minimal.

(6) Yes. Closure of the Beecroft Peninsula is done to ensure public safety. (See also answer to question 1 above). The Range is open to the public on all NSW school and public holidays, and generally weekends outside the holiday period.

Closing the Range also allows Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service environmental managers to conduct activities which normally could not be undertaken when the Range is open to the public. For example, the Range was closed for three weeks in March 1996 and two weeks in March 1997 (including weekends) to enable a strategic vertebrate pest control program (Operation Restoration) to be conducted using poison baits.

(7) The Department of Defence is committed to maintaining the Aboriginal heritage values of Beecroft Peninsula and has undertaken a number of management initiatives to ensure their protection. Navy liaises with representatives of the Jerrinja Local Aboriginal Land Council (JLALC) to determine the most appropriate ways in which sites can be protected and the cultural values interpreted. Two members of the Jerrinja community are employed as Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service Rangers on Beecroft Peninsula. They provide a unique insight into aboriginal issues pertinent to the Range and provide advice on all Defence activities which may effect any sites of spiritual or cultural significance. Defence is very receptive to such advice and activities are modified accordingly.

All live firing activities are restricted to the Impact Area which occupies 400 hectares, or 10 percent, of Commonwealth owned land on Beecroft Peninsula. Following notification by the Jerrinja community in 1986, the symbolic and mythological value of the "Drum and Drumsticks" group of islets was recognised. Consequently, this rock formation is excluded from the Impact Area. Members of the JLALC have identified as sacred sites "Devils Hole", 1.2 km south of the Impact Area, and rock art sites at "Gum Getters Gully", 0.6km north of the Impact Area. No sacred sites have been identified within the Impact Area.

All land based Defence training exercises are assessed for potential environmental impact by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service environmental managers, prior to their approval. No Defence training activities are permitted near areas of natural or cultural significance. All Defence personnel undertaking training activities are briefed on areas of cultural significance by Aboriginal Ranger staff employed with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service as part of the environmental management and advisory service provided for the Beecroft Weapons Range.

(8) My response to question 7 addresses the protection by the Department of Defence of sacred and significant Aboriginal sites. In regard to the Defence Forces of other countries, Australia has defence treaty obligations and agreements with allied and friendly nations regarding the use of weapon ranges. Such agreements ensure reciprocal ADF access to overseas facilities.

(9) Yes. Environmental management on Beecroft Peninsula aims to ensure rare and endangered fauna species are protected and monitored for adverse impacts arising from Defence as well as public activities. The Department of Defence is well aware of the high profile of the Beecroft Peninsula and actively seeks to ensure the values, for which the Peninsula is noted, are maintained and protected.

Foxes and feral cats are recognised as potentially significant introduced predators and are known to impact upon native wildlife at Jervis Bay. Operation Restoration aims to reduce the population of these predators on Beecroft Peninsula to such low numbers that their impact upon native wildlife is negligible. This will then allow the re‐introduction of such native species as the bandicoot and potoroo. Both Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and naval personnel are actively engaged in implementing this program, which is largely funded by the Department of Defence.
(10) The Minister is aware of a number of expressions of support attributed to Federal and State politicians.

(11) The Minister met recently to discuss issues pertaining to Beecroft Peninsula with the Federal Member for Gilmore. The Minister is aware that the Member for Gilmore has visited Beecroft Peninsula and has made positive comments about Defence's custodianship of the area.

(12) Beecroft Peninsula is required by the ADF for training purposes. The nature of the activities which occur on the peninsula necessitate the provision of safety buffer zones. These ensure that the land remains free of urban and pastoral expansion and experiences only restricted public access. There is little doubt historically that the reservation of Beecroft Peninsula and its management for Defence purposes have been the principal reasons that it remains in a substantially natural condition.

(13) The source document from which the question has been drawn is an internal document expressly prepared for the development of RAN environmental management policy and plans. The question relates to one of 292 questions included in an environmental checklist developed to survey environmental issues relevant to Naval activities.
In the first instance the results of the checklist were used to prepare the widely acclaimed Australian Book of Reference (ABR 6111) RAN Environmental Policy Manual, Volumes 1 and 2.

In the second instance the results were published as the RAN State of the Environment Report (RAN SoER) 1995, providing evidence of the Navy's good intent to correct any outstanding environmental management issues.

The checklist not only provided data for the development of two very important environmental base‐line documents for the Navy, but also provided a useful educational tool for the personnel of the ships and establishments involved in the survey. It was in fact a self audit of environmental management issues. That a number of issues were reported as `not identified' or `not being managed' meant that improvements to the existing management programs could be made to rectify the situation. It did not mean that nothing was being done. Beecroft Peninsula has had a Land Management Plan since 1986 and this was recently replaced with the Jervis Bay Naval Environmental Management Plan in October 1996. The new plan being an example of the Navy's continual improvement with respect to environmental policy. Throughout this period the Australian Nature Conservation Agency (now Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service) Rangers were employed to manage the peninsula on behalf of the Navy. They have provided an excellent environmental management and protection service to the Navy during that time.

The 1995 RAN SoER did not `fail' to identify the issue in question. On the contrary, the purpose of the checklist achieved its purpose in identifying areas for management action/improvement. As a result of the data provided by the checklist, policy advice on the matter of `protection of native fauna from bushfires' is now provided in the ABR 6111, RAN Environmental Policy Manual., Volume 1, Chapter 6, titled Fire Management. Section 6.2 refers to Protection of Assets and Natural Areas. Additionally, the Jervis Bay Naval Environmental Management Plan provides specific advice on these issues in Part 3, Program 3.4, Fire Management; and Program 3.5, Terrestrial Flora and Fauna.

The Jervis Bay Naval Environmental Management Plan also calls for the employment of an Environmental Manager for the Jervis Bay region. That position was advertised in the Commonwealth Gazette on 01 May 97.

Additionally, the Navy has a good history with respect to the reduction of fire hazards and the prevention of fire. Research into the Beecroft fire regime was completed under contract to Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service on behalf of the Navy. There are also long standing arrangements between the State, local and Naval fire fighters for the suppression of fires on Beecroft Peninsula. With respect to botanical issues, extensive work has been completed on the peninsula that gives the Navy and Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service a good understanding of the fire regime and the complexity of the local flora. All of these issues are further addressed in the Jervis Bay Naval Environmental Management Plan.

The Department of Defence, in cooperation with the contracted environmental managers, seeks to reduce the incidence of fires arising from either Defence activities or from other events (such as lightning strikes or wildfires). No bombardment of any kind is permitted during a Total Fire Ban. During periods of extreme or high fire danger, and whenever the drought index is at or above 40 points, the use of illuminants is prohibited. Similarly, when a moderate fire danger exists, the use of illuminants is prohibited if the wind exceeds 10 knots from the east or 20 knots from the south.

A Beecroft Weapons Range fire management plan for the Peninsula has been prepared under the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service contract by the former Fire Control Officer for the Shoalhaven region. This plan prescribes ecological burning regimes which are designed to protect the natural biodiversity of the Peninsula. Projects under the Research and Surveys Program have provided considerable information on the effects of fire upon Beecroft flora and fauna.

For example, in 1995 the CSIRO Division of Entomology was contracted to undertake an investigation of the short term effects of fire on invertebrates in the coastal heathland on the Peninsula. The survey revealed a high invertebrate species diversity, reflecting the highly diverse vegetation characteristic of heathland sites. Two new species of Collembola (Springtails) were recorded, both of which may be specific to the Jervis Bay region. The consultants made a series of recommendations from this survey which related directly to fire management. These have been incorporated into the fire management plan.

Finally, the Register of the National Estate Database Place Report states that the Peninsula is in substantially natural condition and that naval bombardment has not caused significant damage to the vegetation.
(b) The effects of fire have been documented extensively in a number of scientific reports commissioned by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

A fire management plan was prepared in 1996 which investigated and assessed fire history on the Beecroft Weapons Range. This report concluded that the primary land use has not adversely impacted on the vegetation communities.
A vegetation survey was prepared in 1994 which concluded that the vegetation communities on the Range were diverse and in relatively good condition.

In a June 1996 report to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service, concerning the conservation and management of the ground parrot, the survey identified the Peninsula as having one of the highest mainland densities of the species on the eastern seaboard. The report suggested this may be due to the varying age mosaic of the heath created by small patchy burns.

Low reptile and amphibian species diversity identified in a survey conducted in 1995, was attributed to both relatively infertile soils and a narrow isthmus connecting Beecroft Peninsula with the mainland, effectively restricting immigration.

Fires initiated by Defence activities are generally small, restricted to the Impact Area and promptly extinguished. No fires initiated by Defence activities are known to have affected the littoral rainforest. Range Standing Orders prohibit the use of solid fuel fires by both Defence personnel and the public.

(15) The general comments in response to Question 13 are iterated here, particularly the indicated lack of understanding, and drawing of conclusions, from an internal working document ex pressly prepared for the development of Naval environmental management policy and plans.

Policy advice on fauna of sandy shorelines, disturbance to bird colonies or rookeries by aircraft noise, and emergency dumping of fuel is provided in the ABR 6111, RAN Environmental Policy Manual., Volume 1, Chapter 7, Coastal Zone Management; Chapter 8, Coastal and Marine Habitats, Plants and Animals; Chapter 12, Noise Pollution, Section 12.3 Aircraft Noise, and Chapter 11, Air Pollution, Section 11.4, Airborne Release of Aviation Fuel.
In particular the Jervis Bay Naval Environmental Management Plan provides specific advice on these issues in Part 3, Programs: 3.6 Shoreline and Nearshore Areas, and 3.10 Air Pollution Control.

With respect to the impact of aircraft noise on birds, the Navy has an ongoing operational requirement in the Jervis Bay area and a certain amount of noise is an integral part of that activity. Noise was discussed as an issue during the development of the Jervis Bay Naval Environmental Management Plan but there is no evidence to suggest that the noise from Naval operations over Beecroft Peninsula is having an adverse effect on bird colonies or rookeries in the area. The Beecroft Peninsula has abundant bird life including large birds of prey. Additionally, Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has implemented a very successful threat abatement plan to reduce the impact of introduced species on the native fauna on the peninsula. All of these issues are further addressed in the Jervis Bay Naval Environmental Management Plan.

There is no ecological or visual evidence to suggest RAN activities affect sandy shoreline fauna. Logistics Over the Shore exercises at Beecroft Peninsula were discontinued in 1992 in response to concerns arising from the potential environmental impact of such activities.
Ecologically, there are no discrete bird colonies or rookeries on the Peninsula. The high density of ground parrots indicates the effect of any noise disturbance is insignificant.
Dumping of fuel is not a practice conducted over Beecroft Peninsula.

(16) The new target system, named "KALKARA", is a zero length launched system designed to be deployable and is capable of operation from any bare site to support the training requirements of the ADF. Two East Coast operating sites are being considered for KALKARA, one being the Jervis Bay airfield, and the other the present RAPIER site on Beecroft.

Whilst JINDIVIK requires a runway for launch and recovery, and can only be operated from the Jervis Bay airfield, KALKARA is able to operate from either the airfield or Beecroft. Therefore any launch of KALKARA that takes place from Bee croft will be increased activity from that site, but will not necessarily impact significantly on the environment.

(17) The new aircraft contracted for by the ADF will be treated as a Naval aircraft, and the processes for assessing and approving the system in safety and airworthiness terms will be no less rigorous than those applied to any aircraft currently operated by the RAN.

Department of Defence environmental policy requires that new projects have minimal adverse effects on the environment. The directive is given in Defence Instruction (Navy) (DI(N)) ADMIN 39‐1 Environment and Heritage Protection. The requirement covers the development of facilities as well as the provision of new equipment and the supporting infrastructure for that equipment. As well, the requirement covers operational activities and exercises.
Pursuant to the directive of DI(N) ADMIN 39‐1 the requirements are that:
(i) the Aerial Target System be launched, operated, recovered and serviced in an environmentally responsible manner;
(ii) there be no adverse effects on the users of the environment from or near where the Aerial Target System is launched, operated and recovered'; and
(iii) the operation of the Aerial Target System be managed so that any possible adverse effects are minimised.

(a) A Notice of Intention (NOI) and Environment Management Program has been prepared pursuant to paragraph 2.2 of the Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and is currently subject to further review prior to possible submission to EPG.
(b) Environment Australia's Environmental Protection Group (EPG) will be consulted regarding KALKARA environmental implications.
(c) The Department in association with the EPG is responsible for assessing and determining the appropriate way ahead.
(d) The review and determination is expected at sometime during the 3rd quarter of 1997.
(18) This cannot be judged until an environmental assessment has been completed against DI(N) ADMIN 39‐1 and a determination has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 May 1997:

BREAK.PARA: With reference to the Australian Institute of Criminology Conference, Privatisation and Public Policy: A Correctional Case Study, to be held in Melbourne on 16 and 17 June 1997:
(1) Who initiated the idea of a conference on private prisons.
(2) Was it, in fact, the Australian Institute of Criminology (AIC) or was it another organisation, including a private prison company.

(3) (a) How much sponsorship has been received by the AIC from Corrections Corporation of Australia, Group 4 Correction Services, THEISS Contractors, Victoria Corrections or others; and (b) please nominate the amounts and type of sponsorship.
(4) Have any other benefits been promised to the AIC by these other companies.
(5) What agreement was reached on what AIC would provide in the way of a conference program or other benefits in return for the sponsorship.
(6) Who determined the conference program, the speakers and the topics for discussion.
(7) (a) What proportion of the speakers are from the (i) private, (ii) community and (iii) public sectors; and (b) who are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Institute of Criminology.
(2) Yes. See answer to (1).
(3) (a) Corrections Corporation of Australia and Group 4 Correction Services have each promised sponsorship of $3,000. No other sponsorship has been offered.
(b) Two amounts of $3,000. Financial.
(5) None.
(6) The Director of the AIC, a research analyst at the AIC and a member of the AIC Board of Management.

(7) (a) of the twenty-nine speakers, (i) three were from the private sector, (ii) seven were from the community or academic sector; (iii) sixteen were Government employees, one was a judge and two were Ministers.

(b) The Hon Bill McGrath, MP, Minister for Corrections, Victoria; The Hon Patrick McNamara, MP, Deputy Premier of Victoria; Justice Frank Vincent, Supreme Court of Victoria; Dr Adam Graycar, Director, Australian Institute of Criminology, Canberra; Dr Leo Keliher, Commissioner, Department of Corrective Services, NSW; Professor Mark Considine, University of Melbourne/Deakin Human Services Australia; Ms Anne Dutney, General Manager, Operations, Corrections Corporation of Australia; Mr Bill Curnow, National Manger, Infrastructure, Research and Development, THEISS Contractors; Mr Tim Daly, Deputy Secretary (Justice Operations), Office of the Secretary, Department of Justice, Victoria; Mr Tony Wilson, Project Director, New Prisons Project, Department of Justice, Victoria; Mr Stan Macionis, Queensland Corrections Corporation Commission; Professor Richard Harding, Director, Crime Research Centre, University of Western Australia; Mr Grant Johnson, Director, Community Correctional Services, CORE—the Public Correctional Enterprise; Ms Brenda Smith, Assistant Commissioner, NSW Corrections; Ms Angela Musumeci, Regional Manager Operations and Support, Community Corrections, Queensland; Mr Alf Bamblett, Chair, Aboriginal Justice Advisory Council of Victoria; Mr Trevor Christian, General Manager, Sydney Regional Aboriginal Corporation; Mr John Van Groningen, Commissioner, Correctional Services, Victoria; Mr Denbigh Richards, Deputy Secretary for Corrective Services Tasmania, Department of Justice; Mr Paul Moyle, James Cook University, Queensland; Mr Stephen Twinn, Director of Operations and Business Development, Group 4 Correction Services; Mr Michael Burt, Department of Human Services, Victoria; Mr Michael Boswell, Department of Correctional Services, South Australia; Mr Guy Hall, Edith Cowan University, Western Australia; Ms Helen Kay, Adult Education and Vocational Training Institute; Mr Gary Wert, CORE—the Public Correctional Enterprise; Mr Bernard Meatheringham, Department for Correctional Services, South Australia; Mr Ken Penaluna, Department of Corrections, Victoria; Mr Ron Wilson, Kangan TAFE.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 11 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a National Rural Women's Forum held in Canberra from 24‐26 March 1997.
(2) What was the agenda at that meeting.
(3) Were rural women represented; if so, in what capacity.
(4) How many of the speakers were women.
(5) (a) How many delegates were at the forum; and (b) how many of the delegates were women.
(6) Are rural women setting the rural women's agenda.
(7) (a) Are rural women's concerns being heard by the Government? and (b) Are women's concerns limited by economic considerations.
(8) What economic considerations outweigh issues of domestic violence and homelessness.
(9) Is the Government acting on any of the material from the Forum; if so what action is the Government taking.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: These questions were originally directed to the Minister Representing the Prime Minister for the Status of Women in Senate Question on Notice 563. Questions (7) and (8) relate to matters which are primarily the responsibility of the Minister Representing the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, and her detailed answer was provided to the honourable senator on Thursday 29 May.

Questions (1) to (6) and (9) relate to a Forum which was conducted by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in conjunction with other State and Territory agencies represented on the Standing Committee for Agriculture and Resource Management (SCARM).
(1) Yes, a National Forum on Women in Agriculture and Resource Management was held in Canberra on 24‐26 March 1997.
(2) The Forum aimed "to recognise and support women's current and potential contribution to increased competitiveness and innovation in agriculture and sustainable natural resource management."
The Forum had a four‐part agenda:
(i) Initial keynote addresses, panel presentations, and presentations by individual rural women provided participants with information about:
‐ the nature and value of women's participation in the sector;
‐ the importance of increasing the diversity of those who contribute to decision making in Australian industries;
‐ barriers to women's greater participation; and
‐ strategies being developed by stakeholder organisations to support women's greater participation.

(ii) Workshops on the first day provided an opportunity for participants to identify issues in agriculture and resource management and the role of women in achieving improved outcomes. This discussion included a focus on the barriers experienced by women participating in decision making in the sector.
(iii) A second workshop session called for specific strategies to address these barriers.

(iv) State, Territory and national action groups then met to make specific commitments to action. Commitments made by each State or Territory and by a working group of national organisations are to be further developed post Forum.

(3) The Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management (SCARM) funded the attendance at the Forum of 91 rural women from all States and Territories. The Standing Committee comprises the Chief Executive Officers of the government agencies in the Commonwealth, States and Territories with responsibility for agriculture and resource management matters. The Standing Committee specifically sought the advice of these women about ways in which their agencies could more effectively recognise and support the work of women in agriculture and resource management.
(4) Slightly over half of the speakers at the Forum were women:
. of the six speakers on the Forum's opening night, all were women;
. two of the four keynote speakers in the Forum's opening session were women;
. one of the two speakers on private sector diversity management was a woman;
. a rural sector panel of heads of national stakeholder bodies was all male.
(5) There were 212 delegates at the Forum. 158 were women and 54 were male.
(6) Rural women are directly and indirectly involved in setting the rural women's agenda:

. Rural women have taken the initiative in holding significant national conferences in recent years to address diverse issues of concern to rural women. This includes the International Conference on Women in Agriculture convened in Melbourne in 1994, and the National Forum on Rural Women convened in Canberra in 1995.

. Rural women regularly debate issues of concern to them through women's gatherings held in the States and Territories, supported by the Rural Women's Networks of the Departments of Agriculture in individual States.

(7a) Rural women's concerns are heard in many forums within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy as well as by the Government as a whole, as indicated in the reply provided by my colleague Senator Newman:

. The Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) works closely with the national heads of rural women's non‐government organisations, including the Country Women's Association, the Foundation for Australian Agricultural Women, and Australian Women in Agriculture. Representatives of these organisations are included in the Secretary's Advisory Group on Rural Women and on a national project advisory group for research on women's participation in the sector. A similar consultative process is in place in individual State and Territory government agencies in the sector.
. Significant numbers of women participated in the National Rural Finance Summit held in Canberra in July 1996.
. Round table discussions leading to the development of a Business Plan for Australian Agriculture have involved the heads of the three national rural women's non‐government organisations.

. Primary Industries and Energy Minister the Hon John Anderson MP facilitated a meeting on World Rural Women's Day in October 1996 between rural women and Prime Minister the Hon John Howard MP, in which rural women's concerns were heard. One direct result of this meeting was the appointment by the Prime Minister of wine maker Faye McGuigan to the Supermarket to Asia Council.

. Primary Industries and Energy Minister John Anderson has strongly supported the increased involvement of rural women in decision making in the sector, and was involved in both opening and closing the recent National Forum on Women in Agriculture and Resource Management.
. The Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management (SCARM) has established a Rural Women's Working Group to report to it on:
. (i) best practice in relation to women who are clients of their agencies;

PARA.TAB: (ii) increasing women's participation in decision making in the sector;
(iii) options for increased support to rural women; and
(iv) future research directions.

ANSWER.PARA: (9) Government agencies in the Commonwealth, States and Territories have agreed to develop a National Action Plan on Women in Agriculture and Resource Management, which will provide a framework for service delivery to and consultation with women. This will include strategies for action or improved practice in:
‐ Supporting women as managers of change;
‐ Rural women in decision making;
‐ Communication;
‐ Design and delivery of policy, programs and services; and
‐ Access to appropriate information, education and training.

The DPIE Secretary's Advisory Group on Rural Women will participate in setting directions for the agency on issues arising from the Forum. Following the Forum, individual State and Territory agencies will also collaborate in strategic action at a local level.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 18 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What extra monies have been provided to Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) in the 1997‐98 budget.
(2) What is this extra money to be used for.
(3) How many spent fuel rods are presently stored at Lucas Heights.
(4) How long before the storage capacity at Lucas Heights is reached.
(5) What will be done with spent fuel rods when the Lucas Heights storage capacity is reached.
(6) What is the expected life of the Lucas Heights reactor; (b) what would it cost to extend the life of the High Flux Australian Reactor (HIFAR); and (b) by how long can the HIFAR life be extended.
(7) What measures has the Government taken to review the safety and function of the Lucas Heights reactor.
(8) Does the Government have any proposals as to what will replace the Lucas Heights reactor.
(9) Has a need been established for a replacement reactor, in view of the 1993 report of the Research Reactor Review which said that a case had not been made.
(10) (a) Is "synroc" a presently viable form of radioactive waste storage; and (b) has "synroc" been tested commercially or technically anywhere in the world.
(11) Does the Government propose to send spent fuel rods overseas for reprocessing.
(12) Is the Government considering building a new reactor, like the one at Lucas Heights, in Australia; if so, what would its size, power and type be.

(13) Is the Government considering building a reprocessing plant in Australia; if so: (a) how much will this cost; (b) what would the cost of a "synroc" plant be; and (c) would such a plant be in addition to the "synroc" demonstration plant at present at the Lucas Heights site.
(14) Does current Commonwealth legislation allow for on‐site reprocessing and or long term waste storage at Lucas Heights.

(15) Does the Government consider there is a safe way to transport radioactive material; if so: (a) how; and (b) has this been done in Australia since 1990; if so, can a list be provided of all occasions on which radioactive material has been transported.

(16) (a) In its recent environmental impact study (EIS) into the Proposed Nuclear Waste Non‐proliferation Policy Concerning Foreign Research Reactor Spent Fuel, did the United States Department of Energy (USDOE) describe the waste to be returned to Australia as high level waste; (b) does ANSTO insist that it is intermediate level waste; (c) what information does ANSTO have that the USDOE does not have in making this claim; and (d) why is there a difference in the claims.

(17) (a) Is the Minister aware that the USDOE EIS suggests the reprocessing of high enriched uranium fuel rods is actively discouraged by the US Government as being contrary to it aims of nuclear non‐proliferation as it adds to the world's stockpile of recovered weapons grade material; and (b) what is the Government's policy of increasing the stockpile of weapons grade material.
(18) What does the Government propose to do with the radioactive material from the spent fuel rods transported to the United Kingdom for reprocessing.
(19) Can the Government provide an absolute guarantee that radioactive material from spent fuel rods from Lucas Heights will not be used in weapons.
(20) (a) What are the flight limits over and adjacent to a nuclear reactor; and (b) how would these laws, if any, fit in with the Holsworthy airport, northern option.

(21) (a) What actions has the Government taken following the recommendations and conditions set out in the Research Reactor Review; (b) have all the recommendations and "onerous" conditions of the Research Reactor Review been complied with; if not: (i) which recommendations have been complied with, and (ii) why have the other recommendations not been complied with.
(22) If the go ahead for a new reactor is given, how would the siting selection be dealt with.

(23) Would the Commonwealth be obliged to carry out an EIS on a selected site; if not, will the Government provide a guarantee that it will carry out an environmental impact statement on the selected site.
(24) Would the criteria for site selection be at least as stringent as that which took place for the low level waste repository at present under review by the Department of Resources and Energy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $9.1 million.
(2) The money is to be used for implementation of a strategy for interim relief for the storage of spent nuclear fuel at Lucas Heights.

(3) As at 30 June 1997, there were 1603 HIFAR spent fuel elements in storage at Lucas Heights. In addition, there were some 27 spent fuel elements that had been discharged from the reactor and were being held in reactor operational facilities pending standard cooling periods and cropping operations preparatory to their eventual transfer to storage.
(4) Around one year.
(5) The Government is currently considering options for providing storage relief at Lucas Heights to ensure that storage capacity is not reached.

(6) The life expectancy of the HIFAR reactor has not been determined. International consultants, commissioned by the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, are currently undertaking a study to identify which of the reactor's main components are life‐limiting, and whether or not a significant life extension would be possible. Should a significant life extension be possible, the Nuclear Safety Bureau has made it clear that it would not authorise the operation of HIFAR beyond around 2003 unless the reactor's safety systems were upgraded. For scientific and operational reasons, a more extensive upgrading would be necessary, involving reactor neutron beam and radioisotope production systems also. The cost would depend on the extent of the work which was undertaken.
(7) The Government is satisfied with the safety and function of the Lucas Heights reactor.

The Safety Review Committee oversees all matters relating to safety on ANSTO's site, while the Nuclear Safety Bureau is responsible for monitoring and reviewing the safety of HIFAR and other nuclear plant. These bodies were established under the ANSTO Act 1987, and their annual reports to Parliament show that HIFAR operates safely for its staff and the public.
This view was supported by the Research Reactor Review (RRR) which, in 1993, concluded that HIFAR operates safely by an adequate margin, well within international safety standards.

On the recommendation of the RRR, the previous Government agreed that a probabilistic safety assessment would be undertaken to provide, among other things, additional assessments of safety to further reassure the public of the reactor's safety. International consultants, commissioned by the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, are currently undertaking this study.
With regard to function, ANSTO's activities were refocussed recently as a result of the ANSTO Mission Review which was undertaken by international consultants in 1994.
(8) The Government is currently considering options for an ongoing research reactor capability in Australia. However, no decisions have been taken at this stage.

(9) The report of the RRR provides a useful background for Government decisions on the question of an on‐going research reactor capability in Australia, but its recommendations and conditions are not pre‐requisites for those decisions. The RRR did not say in its report in 1993 that a case had not been made for a replacement reactor. It accepted that the Government might want to make a positive decision about a new reactor for national interest reasons. It also gave conditional approval for a positive decision after about five years (see also response to part 21(b), below).

(b) Synroc has been tested in a number of countries, and is widely recognised as a highly effective medium for the long term immobilisation of radioactive waste. However, as yet, it has not been used commercially.
(11) This is one of the options which the Government has under consideration at present.

(12) The Government is considering options for the future of neutron science and technology in Australia. If it were to decide on a new research reactor, the Government would seek a small reactor of a modern design. Details would depend on the bid of the successful tenderer against the required technical specifications.

(13) This is one of the options which the Government has under consideration at present. A plant to process spent nuclear fuel in Australia would be functional only if it included a facility to immobilise intermediate level radioactive waste products. That facility would be a synroc plant. The cost, including the synroc plant, would be dependent upon the outcome of design studies, and a competitive tendering process. The existing synroc demonstration plant uses only non‐radioactive simulants of waste to develop and test process technologies for application to a variety of waste streams. It will continue to be used as long as it serves a useful purpose in developing these technologies. Hence, the synroc component of a spent fuel processing plant would be separate from, and in addition to, the present plant.

(14) Current Commonwealth legislation allows for on‐site reprocessing and long term waste storage at Lucas Heights. However, reprocessing would be subject to a permit being issued under the provisions of the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987.

(15) Yes. Transportation can be undertaken safely if the relevant international and national standards are satisfied. National standards are applied in all Commonwealth, State and Territory jurisdictions and, for many years now, radioactive materials have been transported safely throughout Australia on a daily basis, in accordance with these standards. Many of the flights which leave Sydney each day, for example, carry packages of radioactive materials as part of their cargoes. Since 1990, more than 250,000 packages of radioactive materials have been transported within Australia in the Commonwealth jurisdiction alone. It is not practicable to list the occasions when radioactive materials have been transported in Australia in this period.

(16) The recent environmental impact statement (EIS) of the United States Department of Energy (USDOE) on the Return of Foreign Research Reactor Spent Fuel did not say that high level waste would be returned to Australia. The EIS makes it clear that, if spent fuel rods were repatriated to the United States, no radioactive waste would be returned to Australia.

(17) (a) Yes. However, the US Government has decided to continue to reprocess in excess of 188 tonnes of aluminium‐clad research reactor fuel from US and Taiwanese reactors which has deteriorated too far to continue to be stored safely over the next decade. Reprocessing is considered by the US Government to be the most appropriate technology for stabilising this material (see DOE/EIS‐0220, October 1995, Interim Management of Nuclear Materials (IMNM) EIS; decision was announced by USDOE on 19 December 1995). Also, the EIS to which Senator Stott Despoja refers makes explicit provision for the option of reprocessing the foreign research reactor fuel returned to the United States under the return of spent fuel policy.

(b) The Government is in agreement with the thrust of the US Government's policy. Nevertheless, the spent fuel rods in storage at Lucas Heights cannot be stored indefinitely, as their aluminium cladding may corrode leading to the escape of radioactive material. The most responsible way of conditioning these rods for the long term is to extract the uranium, which is re‐useable as either reactor fuel or for radiopharmaceutical production, and to encapsulate the waste in a form which is suitable for ongoing storage or disposal. If a plant were to be established in Australia to process the spent fuel, it would be subject to the strictest international safeguards regimes. Indeed, the continued stockpiling by Australia of spent high enriched uranium (HEU) fuel rods could appear to other countries to be contrary to our strong stance on nuclear non‐proliferation. Reprocessing would make it possible to consume the HEU by recycling, thereby reducing Australia's stockpile of this sensitive strategic material.

(18) It will be many years before the return of the intermediate level radioactive waste from the spent fuel rods which were processed in the United Kingdom last year. The precise management arrangements will need to be addressed closer to the event.

Nevertheless, at this stage, Australia does not have a national storage facility for intermediate level radioactive waste. The Government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste accepted, in principle, the Committee's recommendation for a national above ground storage facility for long lived intermediate level waste which is not suitable for near‐surface disposal. The waste to be returned from the United Kingdom is of this type. Establishment of such a storage facility will be raised with the Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee on Radioactive Waste Management. Consideration will be given to the possible co‐location of the storage facility with a national near‐surface repository for low level and short‐lived intermediate level radioactive waste.

(19) Full international safeguards arrangements would apply to uranium recovered from the processing of the Lucas Heights spent fuel rods. Among other things, these arrangements ensure that uranium is not diverted from civil to military uses. All other radioactive materials would be retained in the waste stream.
(20) (a) The flight limits around the reactor at Lucas Heights apply within a radius of one nautical mile (1.85 kilometres) around the reactor and below an altitude of 2000 ft.
(b) In developing the design for the Holsworthy airport, northern option, the Department of Transport and Regional Development has taken account of the flight limits around the reactor.
(21) (a) The Government has been keeping under review the recommendations and conditions set out in the report of the Research Reactor Review (RRR).

(b) The RRR was established by the previous Government and reported to it. The report, in 1993, recognised that the Government might want to make a positive decision about a new reactor for the same reasons and in the same way as it does for defence and other national interest issues. It also said that there was no need to make a final decision immediately, and it set out a number of conditions which it considered, if satisfied, would make it appropriate for a positive decision to be made on a new reactor after about five years.

In its response to the report, the previous Government said that it broadly accepted the RRR's findings. It kept HIFAR operating, and it provided funding for the probabilistic safety assessment of HIFAR which is now nearing completion. It also accepted that a final decision on replacing HIFAR should be deferred for about five years.

However, the previous Government did not endorse the recommendation that work be commenced with a view to the establishment of a high level radioactive waste repository for the management of the spent nuclear fuel generated by HIFAR. Nor did it provide funds specifically for access for scientists to international advanced neutron scattering facilities.

The present Government, also, does not accept the view of the RRR on the matter of a high level radioactive waste repository. Given the advice of the Nuclear Safety Bureau that a major upgrade of HIFAR's safety systems will be required by around 2003, and the lead times involved for reactor‐related construction/refurbishment activities, the present Government considers a decision should be taken as soon as possible on the question of an on‐going research reactor capability in Australia.
The situation regarding the conditions given in the report is outlined in detail in the response to Parliamentary Question No 561 (Hansard, 29 may 1997). Briefly, the present position is as follows:

. the first condition related to what the RRR saw as a need for a high level waste repository to manage spent nuclear fuel. An alternative strategy, which will not result in the generation of high level radioactive waste, is being developed for the management of spent nuclear fuel;

. the second condition related to spallation technology. This technology is still developing and, at this stage, does not meet Australia requirements for neutrons for both neutron beam science and for the production of radioisotopes. In short, the technology has not developed significantly since 1993. The RRR acknowledged that even if a spallation source were to be acquired, a reactor would still be needed for the production of radioisotopes;

. the third condition was that there had been no practical initiation of a cyclotron anywhere in the world to produce technetium 99‐m, the most commonly used radiopharmaceutical in nuclear medicine. The Government is not aware of the practical initiation of a cyclotron anywhere in the world today to produce technetium 99‐m, or of any plans to do so. Indeed, the Government understands that research to prove the concept has been scaled back considerably because results have not met expectations, and the utilisation of cyclotrons for the commercial production of technetium-99m will not be practical in the foreseeable future;

. the fourth condition related to strong and diverse applications of neutron scattering. Between 1993 and 1996, the number of university research projects using HIFAR increased by about two‐thirds. Access to the key neutron scattering instruments on HIFAR was fully booked in 1993 and continues to be fully booked today even though data collection is much faster than in 1993. Further, there has been a trebling in the use of overseas neutron scattering facilities by Australia's top research scientists; and
. the fifth condition was that the national interest remains a high priority, and that continues to be the case.

(22) As no decision has yet been taken on a replacement reactor, it is premature to consider siting issues. Nevertheless, if Australia were to acquire a small replacement research reactor, the site selected for it would need to satisfy a number of relevant technical and operational criteria.

(23) Whatever decision the Government makes about an ongoing research reactor capability, the actions will be subject to the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. The need for, and level of, any assessment under that Act will be determined in accordance with the normal processes of the Act.

(24) See reply to part 22 (it should be noted that the process for the selection of a national near‐surface repository for low level and short‐lived intermediate level radioactive waste repository has not yet been completed).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 16 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is a synthetic pyrethroid called bifenthrin, a pesticide which is restricted for use in the United States and known to be acutely toxic to aquatic organisms, freely available in Australia.

(2) Will the availability of bifenthrin be suspended until full ecotoxicological studies can be conducted into its impact on aquatic organisms, including the likelihood of poisoning by ingesting toxic sediment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Products containing bifenthrin are registered for use in Australia for underslab treatment of termites, and as an insecticide in a range of agricultural uses. Additionally, a few products containing very low concentrations of bifenthrin have been approved for use in home garden applications. Assessments of full environmental studies, including studies involving aquatic sediments, were carried out by the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA) prior to registration.

Because bifenthrin is, like other members of the synthetic pyrethroid family of chemicals, known to have relatively high aquatic toxicity, statements on the labels of bifenthrin products specifically warn users of this fact as a condition of registration. The range of uses and restrictions on the use of bifenthrin products are similar in Australia and the USA.

As part of its normal operational systems the NRA, including specialist agencies providing technical assessment, keep abreast of the latest developments in relation to all chemicals registered with it. There is currently no evidence to warrant the suspension of products containing bifenthrin.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to a news report carried on Channel Ten, Sydney, on 21 May 1997, which featured an interview with the Manager of the Penrith Panthers Club, Mr Roger Cowan, and Senator Murray's adjournment speech of 5 March 1997:

(1) In light of the threats by the club to cancel support for charities and sporting organisations, and in view of the club's reported revenues in excess of $80 million for 1996, is it the intention of the Federal Government to review the mutuality principle which provides tax exemption on so‐called member income for clubs such as these.

(2) Will the Minister, in light of the historical basis for the tax exempt status accorded to club member income under the mutuality principle, advise how marketing activities at a gaming conference in Las Vegas in 1996 undertaken by the club using the name `Panthers World of Entertainment', can be of benefit to Australian sporting and charitable organisations in the Penrith area.

(3) (a) Is the Minister aware of the attendance of approximately 1,000 officials of registered clubs at the World Gaming Expo in Las Vegas in 1996; and (b) how is such activity in maintaining tax exempt status for clubs under the mutuality principle regarded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's position on the mutuality principle is as set out in its response of 27 June 1997 to the Industry Commission's report into tourism accommodation and training, namely; "The Government also notes that the mutuality principle is not a taxation concession but is, rather, an application of a common law principle about the nature of income.
The Commissioner of Taxation has no discretion as to the applicability of the principle. Whether or not it applies is decided solely on the facts of each case."

(2) The mutuality principle is that where persons join together as a non‐profit organisation to contribute to a common fund created and controlled by them for a common purpose, any receipts that can be properly identified as being paid in that regard are not treated as income for tax purposes. Any other receipts will be taxable as income unless the organisation has a statutory income tax exemption. The question of whether marketing activities are consistent with this test is a matter for the Commissioner of Taxation.

(3) (a) I was not aware of this. (b) As noted above, the test under the mutuality principle is whether members of the clubs in question have contributed to a common fund created and controlled by them for a common purpose. Again, the issue of whether attendance by club officials at the World Gaming Expo is consistent with this test is a matter for the Commissioner of Taxation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 18 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports of reduced whale shark numbers in 1997 in the joint Commonwealth/Western Australian Government managed Ningaloo Marine Park.
(2) How many licences has the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) issued to local dive operators in 1997.
(3) How many dive operators were operating before CALM issued licences.
(4) What process did CALM undertake to make its decision about the number of licences to offer.
(5) What factors did CALM consider when making its decision about the number of licences to offer.
(6) Are there any ecological studies into the impact of dive operations on whale shark popula tions; if so, please provide details if not, on what did CALM base its decision.
(7) What involvement does the Commonwealth have in the joint management of Ningaloo Marine Park.
(8) Did the Commonwealth provide input or advice into the issuing of licences to dive operators.
(9) Does Environment Australia have eco-tourism guidelines for dive operators.
(10) Does CALM have eco-tourism guidelines for dive operators.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) officers at Exmouth confirm that the number of Whale shark sightings in the waters off Ningaloo have been fewer than in previous years. However the period over which these sightings have been recorded is so short that it is not possible to draw any conclusions from yearly statistics, given that natural seasonal variations have not yet been precisely determined.
(2)-(6) & (10) The information sought by the honourable senator does not fall within my portfolio responsibilities. They are a matter for the Western Australian Government.

(7) Under the terms of a Memorandum of Understanding, signed in September 1994 by the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, CALM and WA Fisheries, the day to day management of the Ningaloo Marine Park is undertaken by CALM officers. Under the terms of the MOU, the joint management process, including a level of funding input from the Commonwealth, is implemented through the Ningaloo Marine Park Liaison Committee, which meets at six monthly intervals to coordinate the management functions of the Ningaloo Marine Park.
(9) No. There is no recreational diving activity undertaken in the Commonwealth Waters area of the Ningaloo Marine Park.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 19 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to interests held by the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey):
(1) What was the date when the loan from Westpac was drawn down in order to facilitate the purchase of the Camden property.
(2) In whose name or names is the Westpac loan that is secured over the Camden property.
(3) Is the Westpac loan an interest only loan or a reducing balance loan.
(4) Is the loan a normal home mortgage loan or is it an investment property loan.
(5) What is the name of, or what are the names of the registered owners of the Camden property as contained on the title to the property.
(6) Has the Westpac loan used to purchase the Camden property been declared in Mr Fahey's pecuniary interest register; if not, why not.
(7) Has Mr Fahey complied in full with the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct in regards to all matters involving Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd and the Westpac loan.

(8) Has Mr Fahey or the Government requested or received any advice from the Australian Taxation Office regarding the tax implications of the company director's loan from Lochreagh to Mr Fahey in the context of the Government's announced changes to section 108 of the Tax Act; if so, what was the nature of this advice.
(9) Did Mr Fahey declare to cabinet that he had an interest in the proposed changes to section 108 of the Tax Act by virtue of having a private company's director's loan from Lochreagh to himself.
(10) Why did it take Mr Fahey until December 1996 to have Lochreagh reinstated with the Australian Securities Commission after it was deregistered in December 1992.

(11) Did Mr Fahey as a director of Lochreagh receive any official correspondence during the period 1986 to 1992 notifying him that annual returns for Lochreagh were outstanding; if so, what action did he take in regard to receiving that correspondence.

(12) How does the personal repayment of the loan to Westpac in regard to the Camden property negate Mr Fahey's legal responsibility under both the Tax Act and the Corporations Law to repay the company director's loan from Lochreagh to himself.
(13) When was the company director's loan granted from Lochreagh to Mr Fahey and on what basis was it given.

(14) Was the private company director's loan from Lochreagh to Mr Fahey approved by all shareholders and directors at the time of the granting of the loan or was it a unilateral decision made by Mr Fahey.
(15) Do any documented company records exist by way of a loan agreement or company minutes approving the private company director's loan to Mr Fahey; if not, why not.
(16) Was the granting of the company director's loan to Mr Fahey an arms length transaction.
(17) Is the company director's loan from Lochreagh to Mr Fahey on a fully commercial basis and does Mr Fahey pay a commercial rate of interest on that loan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: I made a statement in relation to this loan some months ago.
The Lochreagh loan to me has been repaid through the assumption by me of Lochreagh's debt to Westpac.
For ten years, I have paid Lochreagh's loan at the rate of $344 a month and will continue to do so while my mother is alive and capable of independent living.
Records in respect of Lochreagh Investments with the ASC are up‐to‐date.
The loan is a commercial loan, larger than the loan to myself. I am repaying it and have repaid it for a decade at bank Commercial Interest rates.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Federal Financial Assistance Grants: Funding Cuts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why were the Federal Financial Assistance Grants (FAGs) to local government cut by $15 million in the 1997-98 federal budget and by $60 million over the next 4 years.

(2) Does this mean that the 1995 Council of Australian Government's agreement to implement national competition policy, which states `the Commonwealth will maintain the real per capita guarantee of the FAGs pool', no longer applies.
(3) What consultation and negotiation took place with local government prior to the budget announcement.
(4) What financial benefit will local government in Victoria, for instance, derive from the Commonwealth by implementing compulsory competitive tendering.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1997-98, the general purpose assistance entitlement for local government will be increased in line with the Consumer Price Index and hence be maintained in real terms. The estimated entitlement for 1997-98 is $1,213 million (excluding adjustments for an overpayment in 1996-97 and an underpayment in 1995-96), an increase of $9.3 million on 1996-97. As shown on page 51 of 1997-98 Budget Paper No. 2, this represents an estimated saving of $14.7 million in 1997-98 against the forward estimates.

The provision of general purpose assistance to local government is linked to the provision of financial assistance grants to the States and Territories through the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995. This Act provides for the increase in general purpose assistance to local government to be determined in line with the underlying movement in general revenue assistance provided to the States and Territories. In 1997‐98 the increase in general purpose assistance to local government will be more commensurate with trends in general revenue assistance provided to the States taking into account the fiscal contributions which the States are making to the Commonwealth. Nevertheless, local government will continue to be relatively well treated by the Commonwealth.

(2) Under the Agreement to Implement the National Competition Policy and Related Reforms, the Commonwealth agreed to maintain the real per capita guarantee of the State financial assistance grants pool on a rolling three year basis, subject to the States meeting their obligations under the Agreement. The Agreement states that local government will benefit from the link between the State and local government financial assistance grants pools. The Government's determination of the 1997-98 general purpose assistance entitlement for local government is in accordance with this link as established by the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995. This link does not require that changes in local government funding be in direct proportion to changes in the State financial assistance grants but, as noted above, that they be in line with the underlying movement in general revenue assistance provided to the States and Territories.

(3) The decision relating to local government general purpose assistance was taken in the 1997‐98 Budget context. Consistent with the nature of budget decisions, the measure was not discussed with local government prior to the Budget announcement.

(4) Local government will not derive financial benefits from the Commonwealth by implementing compulsory competitive tendering. However, local governments are generally likely to benefit due to better value for money outcomes where they participate in a competitive tendering process.

The Competition Principles Agreement (CPA) provides that principles set out in the CPA will apply to local government, although they are not parties to the Agreement. Each State and Territory is responsible for applying the principles to local government. The CPA does not refer to State or local government participation in competitive tendering. However, governments choosing to undertake competitive tendering must do so in a manner consistent with the principles of competitive neutrality.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the passenger motor vehicle inquiry to the Productivity Commissioner.
(2) How many witnesses gave evidence.
(3) How many days of hearings were involved.
(4) What process was employed to tender for outside consultants to provide advice on the economic modelling undertaken by the Commission.
(5) How much was paid to these consultants.
(6) Are those consultants being used again in the textiles, clothing and footwear inquiry.
(7) What process of selection was undertaken resulting in the same consultants being selected.
(8) What staff assistance was provided to Mr Ian Webber to enable him to prepare his dissenting opinion.
(9) Can a complete list of the names and addresses of all participants in the inquiry be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question :

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by the Industry Commission that the answers to the senator's questions are as follows:

(1) The Industry Commission has preliminary inquiry cost estimates available at present. (Final accounting will be reported in the usual way in the Annual Report.) The preliminary estimate of the non‐salary expenditure of the automotive inquiry is $204 700, which includes travel, printing, consultants and other costs. Expenditure on salaries and fees is estimated to be $793 000 (preliminary figure).
(2) The Commission received evidence from 173 participants:
. 152 organisations made submissions;
. 54 organisations attended public hearings; and
. 47 organisations attended round table discussions.
Most of the organisations that gave evidence at public hearings or round table discussions also made submissions. In addition, the Commission gathered information from visits and published reports.
(3) The Commission held seven days of public hearings. This does not include the round table discussions arranged with key participants for which public transcripts are also available.
(4) The Commission considered that the economic model used in the automotive inquiry should:
. be based on a highly disaggregated industry structure to capture detailed industry linkages;
. include the economy's adjustment path over time to tariff proposals;
. be capable of disaggregating the economy wide effects of tariff reductions down to the State level; and
. be able to be fully documented, allowing for greater transparency.

The only computable, general equilibrium model available in Australia that satisfies these criteria is the MONASH model, developed by the Centre of Policy Studies at Monash University. For this reason, the Commission contracted the Centre of Policy Studies to provide economic modelling for the automotive inquiry. The lack of suitable alternative models prevented the Commission from tendering out this work. The Commission was able to consider also three other modelling submissions, as well as critiques submitted on modelling.
(5) The Commission paid $46 000 to the Centre of Policy Studies for the economic modelling work done for the automotive inquiry.
(6) The Commission has also contracted the Centre of Policy Studies to provide economic modelling for the textiles, clothing and footwear inquiry.

(7) The same criteria as those used for the automotive inquiry guided the selection of economic models for the textiles, clothing and footwear inquiry. In addition, given the concentration of the TCF industry in some regional areas, the Commission considered it would be desirable if the model could disaggregate the national effects of tariff reductions down to a regional level. Only the MONASH model could meet all these criteria, and for this reason, the Commission was not in a position to tender out this work.

(8) It is a common practice for the Commission to provide research and secretarial support for all Commissioners, including where Commissioners wish to express different views in inquiry reports. In accordance with this practice, the Chairman of the Industry Commission offered to assist Mr Ian Webber in the development of his minority report. Mr Webber declined the Chairman's offer. All Commissioners were given successive working drafts of material prepared in response to their comments.

(9) A complete list of the names of all parties who made submissions, or gave evidence at round tables and public hearings is provided in Appendix A of the Commission's final automotive report (copy attached).

Many participants have provided their address on their public submission, and therefore their address is already in the public domain. For privacy reasons, the Commission would normally seek the permission of other participants prior to divulging their addresses. The Commission will facilitate access to this level of detail if required.
This Appendix outlines the inquiry process and the organisations and individuals that participated in the inquiry.

On 12 August 1996 the Commission received the terms of reference for this inquiry into the Australian automotive industry. The reference directed the Commission to report within nine months on assistance arrangements for the automotive industry from January 2000. The reference also asked the Commission to report on a number of other matters, including the potential for further development of the industry, and measures which could be undertaken to remove impediments or otherwise contribute to the industry's efficiency. The full terms of reference are reproduced on page XVIII.

Following receipt of the terms of reference, the Commission placed a notice in the national press inviting public participation in the inquiry and released an issues paper to assist participants in preparing their submissions. The Commission received 92 submissions prior to the draft report, and an additional 114 submissions following the draft report. A list of the parties that made submissions is provided in Section A.2.

The Commission also held informal discussions with organisations, companies and individuals to gain background information and to assist in setting an agenda for the inquiry. Those visited by the Commission are listed in Section A.3.
The trade union movement declined the personal offer made by the Chairman of the Commission to be involved in the inquiry.

Due to inquiry time constraints, the Commissioners convened a number of round table discussions, rather than holding public hearings to gather information for the draft report. These discussions enabled the Commissioners to exchange views with small groups of key industry members on major issues. A transcript of the round tables was kept and made publicly available to maintain the transparency of the Commission's processes. Round table participants are listed in Section A.4.

The Commission held public hearings in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide in late February and early March 1997, and received evidence from 54 organisations. A list of the parties that gave evidence at the public hearings is provided in Section A.5. A transcript of the public hearings was made publicly available.

The Commission engaged the Centre of Policy Studies/Impact project at Monash University to assist it in modelling the economic effects of past and future developments in the automotive industry. No other consultants were engaged.

The Treasurer agreed to a two week extension of the reporting date for the inquiry to 26 May 1997, following a request by the Commission's Chairman, Mr Bill Scales. At that time the Commission was still waiting on the results of three separate modelling studies of the effects of proposed automotive industry tariff reductions. Given the high profile that some participants had placed on economic modelling, and given the late delivery of the studies, extra time was needed to thoroughly evaluate the various models.
