QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of research being carried out be a doctor at the Royal Adelaide Hospital which involves cutting the tails off fat‐tailed dunnarts in an attempt to study obesity in humans.

(2) Is this research funded through the Australian Research Council (ARC); if so: (a) how much finding has been provided and in what years; (b) does the ARC believe the research provides significant potential medical benefit for humans; (c) what is the value to humans which is expected to be gained from the research; and (d) has the research been evaluated as valuable and necessary by an appropriate body of peers; if so, which body did the evaluation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the question refers to research which is being conducted by Dr G A Wittert and his team at the University Department of Medicine, Royal Adelaide Hospital. Dr GA Wittert is studying the regulation of food intake, energy balance and fat storage in the Sminthopsis Crassicaudata (Fat‐tailed Dunnart). This project was originally to be under taken at the University of Adelaide, but it has moved to the Royal Adelaide Hospital.

This animal is a small marsupial native to Australia, which stores a large proportion of fat in the tail. Fat‐tailed dunnarts used in Dr Wittert's research project were bred at Animal Services, University of Adelaide, not obtained from the wild. This species is not listed as endangered or vulnerable in the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 Schedules 1, 2 and 3 May 1996. Two species of dunnarts are on this list: the Sminthopsis douglasi (Julia Creek Dunnart) is listed as endangered and the Sminthopsis psammophila (Sandhill Dunnart) is listed as vulnerable.

The research into the regulation of fat stores is unique and feasible because of the characteristics of fat‐tailed dunnarts; that 25% of fat stores are in their tail. Tail removal is a fast simple procedure performed under anaesthesia. The tail removal procedure and condition of the animals has been found to be satisfactory by the veterinarian in charge of Animal Services at the University of Adelaide.

(2) (a)This research was funded through an Australian Research Council (ARC) Small Grant awarded in 1996 and is currently being funded by an ARC Large Grant for 1997‐1999 in the Biological Sciences field of research. The funding for each year is as follows:

(b) The ARC is funding this research because it will provide new basic knowledge. Currently, there is very little information about appetite regulation in marsupials and the research will provide integrated data about the interactions between food intake, fat storage and energy balance and the mechanisms by which these occur.

(c) The value of the research is that it will provide basic knowledge about appetite regulation in marsupials and fat tailed dunnarts as well as an opportunity to focus international attention on Australian native wildlife. The proposed studies are likely to have direct application because factors that are shown to be important for appetite in such divergent species as Sminthopsis and rodents are also likely to be involved in regulating appetite in humans. The animals are bred primarily for research purposes and the findings may ultimately be of benefit to our understanding and continued preservation of the species.

(d) Ethics requirements for ARC grants have been met by the evaluation of the research by the University of Adelaide Animal Ethics Committee. Initial approval for this project was given on 13 April 1995 and approval for the continuation of this work at the Royal Adelaide Hospital was given by the Animal Ethics Committee on the 22 May 1997.

Aside from ethical evaluation, ARC Large Grants are also peer reviewed. The research project was assessed as outstanding by independent assessors (both Australian) and was subsequently recommended through the relevant ARC discipline panel and ultimately the ARC Research Grants Committee.

The assessors consider that the project is interesting, well designed, internationally competitive and will promote the use of a unique Australian marsupial in research relating to the biology of fat metabolism. Aside from examining an animal model for understanding weight regulation in humans, the project should provide a direct understanding of energy balance in a marsupial unique to Australia. It is relevant not just to medical scientists, but to zoologists and ecologists as well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 24 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister visited any Australian National workplaces since March 1996; if so: (a) which workplaces did he visit; and (b) when did those visits take place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (a & b) Since March 1996 the Minister has visited three Australian National (AN) work sites, and has met AN staff in Adelaide and Port Augusta. In addition, during this time the Minister has met AN union representatives in Adelaide, Port Augusta, and Canberra.
While in Opposition the Minister visited a number of AN work sites and facilities, and met AN staff and union representatives in Adelaide, Port Augusta, and Canberra.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 26 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Indian Supreme Court has issued a ban on the importation of all hazardous wastes.
(2) Is the Minister aware that this ban supersedes that issued in 1996 in a lower court, the Indian High Court, during which period imports doubled.
(3) Is the Minister aware that, under the previous ban, Indian Government figures show that 565 tonnes of hazardous lead and battery waste was exported from Australia to India.
(4) Did Environment Australia issue any hazardous waste export permits for that period; if so, what were they; if not, how does the Minister account for the exported waste
(5) Does the Minister undertake to respect and uphold the Indian Supreme Court ban on the importation of hazardous wastes.
(6) Does the Minister undertake to pay for the return to Australia of any hazardous waste exported from Australia to India without a permit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Whether the ban supersedes the ban in the lower court, is a matter for Indian law. I understand that the orders relate to separate cases and that it is not necessarily the case that the Supreme Court order supersedes the order made in the Delhi High Court.

(3) I have not seen the Indian Government's statistics covering trade in hazardous wastes. Australian Bureau of Statistics data indicate that in the calendar year 1996 Australian exports of lead acid battery waste to India amounted to 110 tonnes. It is not clear whether other Australian exports of lead wastes to India would be considered hazardous for the purpose of the Basel Convention.

(4) Since the amendments to Australia's Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 commenced on 12 December 1996, no permits have been issued for the export of hazardous waste to India. Any exports prior to 12 December 1996 arose because of inadequacies at that time in Australia's hazardous waste laws. Exporters of battery waste were not legally obliged to seek a permit or inform the Australian Government of any trade in valuable hazardous recyclables and the Government had no legal authority to restrict or prevent these exports. The amendments to the Hazardous Waste Act require all exports of hazardous waste, including hazardous wastes such as lead acid battery scrap destined to recycling facilities, to be granted a permit prior to shipment.

(5) Consistent with the requirements of the Basel Convention, Australia will not permit the export of hazardous wastes to Parties which have prohibited the import of such wastes. Environment Australia is currently clarifying the legal status, intent and scope of the Indian Supreme Court order.

(6) Any illegal exports of hazardous waste to India will be dealt with in accordance with the Hazardous Waste Act. Section 35 of the Act allows the Minister for the Environment to order that the waste be imported to Australia. Generally, in such instances, the import costs would be met by the exporter concerned and not the Australian Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 26 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that P&O Ports, Australia, has signed an agreement which is likely to lead to the construction of a major port facility at Vadhavan. India. in an area of great environmental significance.

(2) Is the Minister aware that such a port would contravene laws protecting what is a designated protected area, and would also be in contravention to nine separate orders from the Indian Supreme Court.
(3) Is the Minister aware that many local people have been arrested opposing the development of the proposed port.

(4) Will the Minister examine the matter and raise the concerns of both Australian environmental organisations and their Indian counterparts with P&O, particularly in the context of an Australian registered company acting in a manner which would be unacceptable in Australia.
(5) Is there any current involvement by any Australian Government or semi‐Government agency in the proposed construction of the port; if so, what is that involvement.
(6) If there is any Government involvement, will the Minister seek to cease that involvement, in order to protect the environment in India and respect its laws.

(7) Does an Australian Coal trading company, Glencore Australia, have contracts to ship coal to Bombay Suburban Electricity Supply Company, despite Supreme Court orders in India ordering the power company to switch the relevant power station to gas firing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1—3) I was not aware of the matters raised in the senator's question.

(4) I understand the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has sought information regarding the matters raised by the honourable senator. It appears that the matters raised by the honourable senator are between the company and the relevant Indian authorities. So far as I am aware, the Government of India has not sought any intervention by the Australian Government.
(5) There is no current involvement by my Portfolio.
(6) Not applicable to my Portfolio.
(7) I am not aware of such contracts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 27 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government considering sites outside the Sydney basin for construction of a second international airport for Sydney; if not, why not.
(2) Is the Government committed to constructing a second international airport in the Sydney basin; if so, why.

(3) Has the Government considered, or undertaken any analysis, of the benefits which the establishment of a second international airport outside the Sydney basin can have in terms of regional development; if not, why not.
(4) Have contracts been negotiated for construction work on an airport on the Holsworthy range.
(5) Has there been any decision to commence work in March 1998.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Major airports recently built or currently being built at major cities overseas are generally located no more than 50 kilometres from the central business district.

There are major disadvantages with locating a second airport at a site which is far removed from the centre of travel demand. The distance from Sydney would have major adverse implications for travel times,cost and convenience, and connection with Sydney's existing airport. As a consequence, there would be a strong likelihood that passengers and airlines would be unwilling to use the second airport thereby further increasing the pressures on Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. For some sites, there would also be very significant costs associated with providing suitable road and rail access and linkages to other support services (such as a fuel line).

(2) The Government is committed to building a second major airport for Sydney up to a full international standard. While Badgerys Creek remains the Government's preferred site, subject to a favourable outcome of an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), the Holsworthy Military Area is being considered as a possible alternative.
(3) The Government is not considering possible sites outside the Sydney basin for the second major Sydney airport for reasons outlined in (1) above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: World War I: Tasmanian Aboriginal Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 30 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any records or statistics for the period 1921 to 1930, inclusive, for the cancelling or reduction of disability pensions arising out of conditions or injuries caused by or related to World War I service; if so, where are those records held.
(2) Are there any records or lists held of how many "Islanders" from the Furneaux Group enlisted or served with the 12th Battalion in World War I; if so, where are those records held.
(3) How many individuals of Tasmanian Aboriginal extraction served at some stage with the 12th Battalion immediately before, during and after World War I.
(4) Did any individuals of Tasmanian Aboriginal extraction sit as members of the State Repatriation Board in the 1920s.
(5) Did any individuals of Tasmanian Aboriginal extraction sit as Commissioners on the War Pensions Entitlement Appeal Tribunal in the 1920s.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Some information on cancellations and reductions of disability pensions in the period 1921 to 1930 is contained in the Annual Reports of the Repatriation Commission. However, this information does not differentiate between States nor does it differentiate between the pensions of members of the forces, their wives, children, or widowed mothers.
(2 & 3) These questions fall within the portfolio responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel.
(4) The ethnic origins of members of the Tasmanian State Repatriation Board in the 1920s are unknown.
(5) The ethnic origins of members of the War Pensions Entitlement Appeal Tribunal in the 1920s are unknown.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Customs & Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 2 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role do Customs officers play in the inspection of imported food.
(2) How many Customs officers were employed in monitoring imported food in the 1994, 1995, 1996 and 1997 calendar years.

(3) What was the level of expenditure by the department on monitoring imported food in the 1994-94, 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years and what level of funding has been allocated for the 1997-98 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Customs does not have primary responsibility for the inspection of imported food.

In respect of commercial consignments, Customs assists the Imported Food Inspection Program (IFIP) of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS) in identifying consignments which may require inspection.

Customs, through its profiling capability, passes details of commercial food importations to AQIS. Importers of certain foods are then required to lodge quarantine entries with AQIS, who in turn make decisions on the level of inspection required. Customs may in some cases conditionally release consignments of food subject to IFIP certification, provided all Customs requirements have been met.
In relation to non-commercial importations of food, including through international passengers and private consignments via cargo and mail, the goods are referred to AQIS for inspection.
(2) and (3) Customs does not allocate staff specifically for the purpose of monitoring imported food, nor does it allocate expenditure specifically for this purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Mr David Wilson visit Thailand in late 1990 or early 1991 to inspect chicken processing facilities.
(2) What was Dr Wilson's position in the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) at that time and what are his qualifications.
(3) Who accompanied Dr Wilson on that visit and what were their qualifications and experience.
(4) How many plants were inspected and how many of those plants had hazard analysis of critical control point (HACCP) systems in place.
(5) Was a draft report provided to the Thai authorities for comment and amended as a consequence of those comments.
(6) Can copies be provided of the draft report, the comments received from the Thai authorities and the final report.
(7) Was the draft report also provided to the Australian Chicken Industry; if so, was it amended as a result of comments from the local industry.
(8) (a) When did the joint AQIS/chicken industry delegation visit Thailand to inspect that country's export chicken processing plants; and (b) how long was the delegation in Thailand.
(9) Who were the members of that delegation and what are their qualifications and experience.
(10) Were all plants seeking to export product to Australia visited by the delegation; if not: (a) how many plants were inspected; and (b) how were they selected.
(11) Were HACCP systems operating in all the plants inspected.
(12) If HACCP systems were in place, how long had they been operational.
(13) Has a draft report on the visit been completed; if so, can a copy of the draft report be provided.
(14) Has the draft report been sent to the Thai authorities for comment; if so: (a) to whom was the draft sent; and (b) when was it sent.
(15) When was the draft report provided to the chicken industry and to whom was it provided.
(16) Can copies be provided of the comments received from the Thai authorities, and the chicken industry, to the draft report.

(17) Has the inspection of the Thai plants now been completed or are further visits planned; if so: (a) when will these further inspections take place; and (b) will the same officials undertake the inspections to ensure continuity in the assessment process.
(19) When will the final report from the inspection of the Thai plants be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Dr David Wilson visited Thailand from 12 to 21 February, 1990.

(2) At the time of Dr Wilson's visit to Thailand, he was the head of the Development and Review Section, Animal Quarantine and Exports Branch, AQIS. Dr Wilson has a BVSc degree and has worked in AQIS and its predecessor organisations since 1981.
(3) Dr Wilson was not accompanied on the visit.

(4) 10 plants were visited. Dr Wilson did not formally inspect any plants with regard to approval to export to Australia. To Dr Wilson's knowledge none of the plants he visited had HACCP systems in place.
(5) Inspection of available files gives no indication that a draft report was provided and Dr Wilson does not recall providing a draft report to the Thai authorities for comment.
(6) A copy of Dr Wilson's final report is provided.
(7) Dr Wilson's draft report was not provided to the Australian poultry industry.
(8) (a) The joint AQIS/chicken industry delegation visited Thailand in April 1997.

(b) Dr Peter McGregor and Dr Linda Corner of AQIS were in Thailand from 1st April to 22 April. Dr Margaret Mackenzie, an employee of Inghams Pty Ltd., was in Thailand from 7 April to 12 April. Dr Heloisa Mariath, of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy was in Thailand from 16 April to 18 April.

(9) The chicken processing establishments were inspected by Dr McGregor and Dr Corner and the industry representative, Dr Mackenzie. In addition, Dr Mariath conducted an evaluation of Thai residue management programs for chicken production.

Dr McGregor has a BVSc degree and has been trained in quality assurance auditing, HACCP implementation and canning procedures. He has worked in AQIS and its predecessor organisations since 1972 and has 25 years experience associated with the red meat and poultry slaughtering and further processing industries.

Dr Corner's qualifications are BVSc, MSc (Epidemiology), PhD (Virology) and Grad Dip. (Admin.). She has completed training in Approved Quality Assurance and Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points and passed the exam conducted by the Australian Organisation for Quality (NSW) on Quality Assurance Auditing. She has worked for two years in the Animal Quarantine Policy Branch of AQIS.
Dr MacKenzie's qualifications are BSc. MSc. and Ph.D. She has worked for Inghams since 1977 and is presently the National Technical Services Manager, Inghams Enterprises Pty. Ltd.

Dr Mariath's qualifications are BSc (Biological Sciences), MSc ( Genetics ) and PhD (Agricultural Sciences). Dr Mariath is presently the manager of the National Residue Survey of poultry, eggs, fish, molluscs, crustaceans, aquaculture products and honey and is responsible for program design, implementation and evaluation of chemical contaminants in Australian poultry. She has worked for 7 years in the Bureau of Resource Sciences.
(10) All plants nominated by the Government of Thailand were inspected.
(11) & (12) HACCP systems were not in place in any of the plants.
The Thai Department of Livestock Development (DLD) was in the process of assessing the company HACCP manual of each of the establishments inspected for approval.
(13) A draft report has been prepared but not yet finalised.
(14) On 19 June 1997 the draft report was provided to the DLD for correction of any errors of fact that may have arisen due to reasons such as language barriers.
(15) The draft report was examined by Dr Mackenzie on 11 June 1997.
(16) The DLD have yet to comment on any errors of fact in the draft report. The draft report was not circulated to the chicken industry other than to Dr MacKenzie.
(17) Further actions will depend on decisions arising out of the report on the inspection of nominated Thai plants and on further information from Thailand.
(19) The report from the inspection of the Thai plants will be finalised after a response from the DLD is received.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 4 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the crane rates, containers moved per crane per hour, by quarter, in each of the 1991 to 1996 calendar years and for the first two quarters of 1997, achieved at the following ports: (a) Melbourne; (b) Sydney; (c) Adelaide; (d) Brisbane; and (e) Fremantle.
(2) (a) What was the variation in the number of containers handled by a man shift; and (b) what was the average delay per ship call for the ports in (1) over the same period.
(3) What were the average container terminal charges for the ports in (1) over the same period.

(4) What were the crane rates, by quarter, achieved in each of the 1991 to 1996 calendar years and for the first two quarters of 1997 in the following ports: (a) Wellington, New Zealand (NZ); (b) Trieste, Europe; (c) Laem Chabang, Thailand; (d) Baltimore, United States (US); (c) Zeebrugge, Belgium; (f) Klang, Malaysia; and (g) Oakland, US.
(5) (a)What was the variation in the number of containers handled by a man shift; and (b) what was the average delay per ship call, for the ports in (4) over the same period.
(6) What were the average container terminal charges for the ports in (4) over the same period.

(7) What was the cost per visit for vessels discharging break bulk cargo for each of the 1991 to 1996 calendar years and as at June 1997 at the following ports: (a) Melbourne; (b) Fremantle; (c) New Westminster, Canada: (d) Sydney; (e) Long Beach, US; (f) Brisbane; (g) Tacoma, US; (h) Richmond, US; and (i) Tauranga, NZ.

(8) How many people were employed in stevedoring in each of the 1991 to 1996 calendar years and as at June 1997 at the following ports: (a) Melbourne; (b) Sydney; (c) Adelaide; (d) Brisbane; and (e) Fremantle.

(9) How many people were employed by the port authorities in each of the 1991 to 1996 calendar years and as at June 1997 in the ports of: (a) Melbourne; (b) Sydney; (c) Adelaide; (d) Brisbane; and (e) Fremantle.
(10) What was the average Australian tug crew size in each of the 1989 to 1997 calendar years.

(11) (a) What was the average loading time in each of the Australian grain ports in each of the 1989 to 1997 calendar years; and (b) what were the average manning levels at the ports in (9) over the same period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The following table provides average crane rates for container terminals in each port. The data is provided in TEUs per hour as data in lifts or containers per hour is available only back to December 1995.
Table: Australian container terminal crane rates, selected ports, 1991‐1996
TEUs per hour
Source: Waterline, Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, various issues, Australian Government Publishing Service, Canberra.
(2) (a) Data showing the variation in containers handled per man shift over the period 1991‐1997 is not available.
(b) Data showing the average delay per ship call over the period 1991‐1997 in the ports of Melbourne, Sydney, Adelaide, Brisbane and Fremantle is not available.

The BIE report Waterfront 1995: International Benchmarking reported average delays per ship call for selected container ports for 1994 in the context of a case study of P&O Containers Pty Ltd. During 1994, that company reported average delays of around 8 hours in Adelaide, 16 hours in Fremantle, 21 hours in Melbourne and 35 hours in Sydney.

(3) Previously, figures for average container terminal charges at major Australian container ports were compiled by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA), which has since been absorbed into the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Stevedoring charges were published periodically by the PSA in the form of national weighted‐average revenue per TEU.
Disaggregation on a port‐by‐port basis is not possible due to confidentiality arrangements for the collection of data.
The table below shows the national average stevedoring cost for the period 1991‐1995. Figures for 1996 and 1997 are unavailable at this stage.
Table: National weighted‐average stevedoring revenue—per TEU, 1991‐1997.

ROW.ENTRY: National weighted‐average stevedoring revenue per TEU

BREAK.PARA: Notes.
1. The 1995 figure is a preliminary estimate obtained from the ACCC and published by the BTCE in Waterline.

Source: Monitoring of Stevedoring Costs and Charges and Terminal Handling Charges, Prices Surveillance Authority, various issues, PSA, Melbourne. Also Waterline, BTCE, Issue no.8, September 1996, p.8, AGPS, Canberra.

(4) Time series crane rates for these overseas ports are not available. However, the report Waterfront 1995: International Benchmarking, published by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE), conducted comparisons of port performance, including most of the overseas ports listed, based on a 17,000 grt vessel exchanging 600 boxes and using each port's ship rate.

The BIE noted, for example, that the time taken for Australian terminals to work 600 boxes is generally the longest of the ports examined. The Report indicated that while crane rates at most Australian ports fell during 1994, this was in contrast to the overseas ports where available evidence indicates crane rates continued to improve.
Currently, the Productivity Commission is preparing an update of this report due for release later this year.

The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics (BTCE) has published articles in Waterline comparing port charges and performance in Australia and overseas. These articles have concluded that, for the ports studied, container ship handling rates are higher in ports in New Zealand, Europe and Asia than in ports in Australia. The trend of these conclusions supports the findings of the BIE report.
(5) (a) Information on the variation in the number of containers handled by a man shift at the overseas ports listed is not available.
(b) Detailed information on ship delays at the overseas ports is not available.

The Bureau of Industry Economics report Waterfront 1995: International Benchmarking surveyed delays experienced by ships from P&O Containers Pty Ltd at various ports around the world. The survey found that delay times varied across Australian ports, with Sydney being the worst of all 16 ports surveyed, while Fremantle and Melbourne were equivalent to the worst of the overseas ports.
However, the sample of overseas ports in the survey varied from the list in the question.
(6) Time series figures for average container terminal charges at these ports are not available.

The BIE report Waterfront 1995: International Benchmarking contained a comparison of terminal charges per twenty foot equivalent unit (TEU) by container port for 1995. It noted that the five major mainland Australian container ports had similar charges to Singapore, were cheaper than Wellington, Hong Kong and the North American ports examined and more expensive than the other New Zealand ports and the Malaysian, Thai and European ports.

(7) Time series discharging costs for break bulk cargo at these ports is not available. However, the Bureau of Industry Economics report Waterfront 1995: International Benchmarking provides an overview of a break bulk cargo benchmarking study undertaken by BHP Transport which compares non‐terminal charges for ports on the Australian‐North American west coast route during 1994. The west coast route includes the ports of Melbourne, Fremantle, New Westminster, Sydney, Long Beach, Brisbane, Tacoma, Richmond and Tauranga.

Based on a 14 275 grt vessel carrying a mixture of typical break bulk, the report found that Australian ports were amongst the most expensive ports visited on the west coast service. The cheapest port, Tauranga in New Zealand, was half the cost of Melbourne, Australia's most expensive port. The charges at Brisbane, Australia's cheapest port on this trade, were equivalent to the more expensive of the American west cost ports.
(8) Detailed figures on stevedoring employment on a port‐by‐port basis are not available as employment levels are a matter for the various companies concerned.
In September 1989 (pre‐WIRA) there were 8 872 stevedoring employees Australia‐wide. In its Review of the Waterfront Industry Reform Program, the BTCE estimated that in early 1994 the
stevedoring workforce was close to its post‐WIRA level of around 3800.

(9) The BTCE's Waterline regularly publishes figures for total port authority employment in each of the five major mainland capital city ports. Overall, Australian port authorities reduced their staffing from almost 8000 in 1985/86 to around 1500 by 1995.
Table: Average annual port authority employment, selected ports, 1991‐1997
Notes
a. First six months only. Second half figures not available due to the subsequent restructuring of the Port of Melbourne Authority.

b. The Port of Melbourne Authority reported an employment level of 287 at 30 June 1996. Average employment for July‐December 1996 was 69, but this applies to the Melbourne Port Corporation only, excluding Melbourne Port Services Ltd. and remaining Port of Melbourne Authority Employees. The figures for the two half‐years are not comparable.
Source: Waterline, BTCE, various issues; and port authority annual reports.
(10) In 1989, the crew size on Australian tugs was up to eight. In March 1990, crew size was reduced to five and then again to four in June 1992, which is the current level.
(11) (a) Time series data for the average loading time in each of the Australian grain ports from 1989 to 1997 is not available.

In its Waterfront 1995: International Benchmarking report, the BIE reported significant variation in loading times for wheat at 16 Australian ports during 1993/94. Loading times varied from less than 10 hours per ship at Gladstone and less than 15 at Brisbane to nearly 50 at Geelong and Wallaroo.
The average loading per man shift has generally doubled compared with levels prior to the early 1990's.
(b) Detailed information on manning levels for grain loading at the major ports for the 1989‐1997 period is not available.

The WIRA reforms provided prescribed reductions in manning levels of between 50‐80 per cent. In its Review of the Waterfront Industry Reform Program, the BTCE concluded that, from the three grain ports it consulted, manning levels had been reduced by almost 75 per cent compared to pre‐WIRA levels.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 8 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. How many samples of imported pig meat were tested by Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) officers as part of the Imported Foods Inspection Program in the 1996/97 financial year.
2. What were the results of the tests.
3. How many companies in each Australian State are currently approved by AQIS to import Canadian pig meat.
4. (a) How many of these companies have been audited by AQIS; (b) how many of the audits were random; and (c) in which States are the audited companies located.

5. (a) How many companies were found to be in breach of the quarantine protocol; (b) what was the nature of the breaches; (c) what action was taken by AQIS; and (d) in which States were the companies found to be in breach of the protocols located.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Eighty-seven samples of imported pig meat were tested by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, Imported Food Inspection Program during the 1996-97 financial year.
2. Of the eighty-seven samples tested, eighty-one passed, one failed and five test results are outstanding as at 17 July 1997.
The one (1) failure was for labelling, (it omitted mandatory information)
IFIP Tests on Imported Canadian Swine 1996—97
* Test results outstanding at time of report.

(3) Importers are not required to be approved in order to import Canadian pig meat or other commodities. Therefore, there is no register of approved importers. Any organisation or individual can apply to AQIS for a permit to import Canadian pig meat
into any state or territory. The import permit is valid for a period of two months and is for one shipment only.
The number of importers currently holding valid permits to import Canadian pig meat are as follows:

ROW.ENTRY: Total number of importers holding valid permits

ANSWER.PARA: 4. (a) Every consignment of imported Canadian pig meat is subject to full inspection of documentation and product.
(b) No random audits of importers occurred during financial year 1996/97 as all consignments are subject to full inspection of documentation and product.
(c) Importers of Canadian pig meat consignments inspected during financial year 1996/97 are currently located in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, and South Australia.
5. (a) A total of two processors and two importers were found to be in breach of the quarantine protocol during the financial year of 1996/97.

(b) The breaches by the importers involved a failure by one importer to obtain a movement direction for a single carton of imported pig meat. The other breach related to the inadequacy of the records maintenance system of another importer.

The incidents involving processors included a breach of AQIS requirements for ensuring adequate staff training in relation to handling Canadian pig meat. The second breach involved the failure of the processor to maintain documentation relating to the movement of uncooked Canadian pig meat.

(c) Following each of the non-compliance issues relating to the two pig meat importers and the two processors, AQIS issued letters asking each of the parties to show cause as to why they should be able to continue to import or process this commodity. The matters were then referred to AQIS's Compliance, Legal and Evaluation Branch. As a consequence of the subsequent investigations and periods of suspension for the processors, letters of warning were issued to each of the parties.

Corrective action taken by AQIS involved amending import permits to include the requirement for a declaration to be provided by the importer stating that they understand and will comply with all AQIS import requirements that relate to this commodity. This declaration must be signed before the consignment is released to the importer. The smallgoods processors in breach of AQIS Quarantine requirements were required to amend their manuals to add additional controls and ensure that breaches would not recur.
(d) All breaches of quarantine protocol during the 1996/97 financial year occurred in New South Wales.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Federal Government supportive of the idea that there should be an expansion of community housing in Australia, given the current shortage of public housing and the difficulties faced by many tenants in the private market.
(2) With reference to the fact that community housing currently represents less than 5 per cent of total housing in Australia, or about 12 000 units:

Given that the previous Government advocated that numbers of community housing units should be doubled by the year 2000 to around 25 000: (a) is this a reasonable target; (b) what percentage target would be considered appropriate; (c) will the Federal Government continue to fund community housing under the Community Housing Program over the next 3 years and will funding be maintained at current levels; and (d) under the new housing proposal, would expansion of the numbers of community housing units in Australia be a Federal or State initiative.
(3) On a per unit cost basis, which is more costly for governments to provide, community or public housing.
(4) Will the Federal Government encourage competition between the public and community sectors for tenants in the future.

(5) Can a statistical profile of the social circumstances of people living in community housing, that is, age, marital status, ethnic background and special circumstances such as disabilities, be provided.
(6) Is there a code of practice in Australia for the management of community housing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is supportive of the continued development of community housing and has maintained the Community Housing Program identified funding stream to the end of the current CSHA.

(2) (a) & (b) The National Community Housing Forum estimates that there are currently 24,606 units of community housing that have been funded through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement. (.37% of housing stock in Australia)
It is expected that the number of units of community housing will exceed 25,000 before the year 2000.
(c) The Commonwealth has maintained Community Housing Program funding at 1995‐96 levels until June 1999—the end of the current CSHA.
(d) Details of housing assistance arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States after June 1999 are still being discussed by Housing Ministers.

(3) The unit cost of public and community housing varies according to the particular circumstances in which housing assistance is being provided. Performance reporting that will enable comparison of average unit costs and administration is being implemented under the COAG Review of Government Service Provision.

(4) The institutional framework in which providers of public and community housing operate is the responsibility of State and Territory governments. The Commonwealth supports the principle that competitive supply arrangements are beneficial.
(5) It is not possible to provide a statistical profile of the social circumstances of people living in community housing.
(6) Housing Ministers are developing separate Codes of Practice for community housing in each State and Territory, through the 1996 Commonwealth State Housing Agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: on 24 June 1997 (Official Hansard page 4956) asked Senator Kemp a question without notice concerning whether a user friendly Windows based interface of the Treasury's PRISMOD model of the tax system would be made available to interested members of the public so that taxpayers themselves can work out whether they are better or worse off under any proposed tax changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No such version of PRISMOD exists and there are not plans, at this stage, to produce one.

TALK.START.PARA: on 18 June 1997 (Official Hansard page 4486) asked Senator Hill, as Minister representing the Treasurer a question without notice concerning those families affected by recent changes to the youth allowance that may have to allocate an increased share of their taxable income to supporting their children. He also asked whether the income tax legislation would be further amended.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction of the Common Youth Allowance rationalises a range of existing payments and puts in place a framework which deals with the changing youth market more appropriately and encourages young Australians to pursue further study to improve their employment prospects. To ensure that this allowance is only obtained by those in genuine need, it is subject to a parental means test.

The simple answer to the Senator's question is no, the Government will not make tax exempt what is taxable income. The Government does not have a policy of introducing concessional tax treatment to the taxable income of those who may lose entitlements for direct outlay benefits.
